did.unittitle: Tamiment Library Web Collection on Organizations

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

did.abstract: The Tamiment Library Web Collection on Organizations, established in 2007 in conjunction with the California Digital Library’s Web Archiving Service (WAS), contains webpages of organizations and other entities concerned with issues related to economic, civil, and social justice from a left and/or progressive perspective. These entities focus on issues ranging from corporate accountability, immigrant rights, unemployment, homelessness, urban justice, healthcare reform, wealth redistribution, and other issues, including a focus on the Occupy Wall Street movement and the Guantanamo Detention Camp. Tamiment also archives political websites, focusing on political parties of the far Left, including Marxists, Communists, Socialists, and Trotskyists. Website contain a variety of formats and materials, including pdfs, images, multimedia, event listings, and blogs.
did.langmaterial: Websites are mostly in English, with some Spanish, Chinese, German, and other languages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Tamiment Library Web Collection on Organizations, first began by Tamiment in 2007, contains webpages of organizations and other entities concerned with issues related to economic, civil, and social justice from a left and/or progressive perspective. This is an assembled collection, the websites were selected by the archivists. These entities focus on issues ranging from corporate accountability, immigrant rights, unemployment, homelessness, urban justice, healthcare reform, wealth redistribution, and other issues. The collection also contains websites related to environmental and green movements, prisoner rights, the Jewish American Left, peace movements, art and cultural organizations, education and youth movements, animal rights, feminism, housing rights, and other websites related to the Left movement. Tamiment also archives political websites, focusing on Marxian inspired entities, including political parties that identify with or are inspired by Communist, Socialist, or Trotskyist perspectives.

In addition, there is a huge focus in this collection on the Occupy Wall Street Movement, established in September 2011. Occupy Wall Street is a social movement, started in New York City, that works to reform both the private and public sector. The websites in the collection focus on different aspects and working groups of the movement. Another huge focus of the collection contains websites of those critical of U.S. policy in relation to Guantanamo Detention Camp and its representation governing enemy combatants, prisoner interrogation, the related legal processes and issues, the global detention system established by the Bush administration, including efforts to secure civil and human rights for detainees. Contents include prisoners' testimony and documents from attorneys defending them.

These websites contain a huge variety of media, which include videos, pdfs, blog postings (including Tumblr and Wordpress blogs), petitions, news feeds, message boards (or forums), and audio. These websites often act to document and update upon the organizations’ activities, schedule upcoming events, build awareness of their cause or organization, information on projects the organizations are working on, writings and articles by members of the organization or party, or other activities.

The web collection documents the publicly available content of the web page, it does not archive material that is password protected or blocked due to robot txt exclusions. Although Tamiment attempts to archive the entirety of a website, certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. This can include videos (Youtube, Vimeo, or otherwise), pdfs (including Scribd or another pdf reader), rss feeds/plug-ins (including twitter), commenting platforms (disqus, facebook), presi, images, or anything that is not native to the site.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Tamiment Library, New York University began web archiving in 2007 as part of a grant given by the National Digital Information Infrastructure and Preservation Program (NDIPP) of the Library of Congress. As most unions, left movements, progressive organizations, and others stop creating ephemeral material and paper based collections and move most of their administrative and informational material to the web, Tamiment continued to document the changing face of the labor and left movement into the web era. Tamiment uses the California Digital Library’s Web Archiving Service (WAS) as their tool to capture and preserve websites. WAS was created in 2007 and Tamiment is one of its earliest partners. The California Digital Library provides the storage and infrastructure for the project.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Archived websites are open to researchers without restrictions. Archived websites are made publically available 6 months after the initial capture.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Tamiment does not own the copyright to these websites. Copyright to these websites resides with each website's author. Tamiment Library and Web Archiving Service (WAS) operate in observance with Section 108 Study Group’s Report on Web Archiving. Tamiment archives websites for preservation and research purposes only. Tamiment respects robot txt exclusions and requests from websites with robot txt exclusions to allow our crawler to capture their website. Tamiment will also honor a website owner’s request to remove a website from the collection.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. This can include videos (including Youtube and Vimeo), pdfs (including Scribd or another pdf reader), rss feeds/plug-ins (including Twitter), commenting platforms (disqus, Facebook), presi, images, or anything that is not native to the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Robot txt exclusions also change the formatting of websites from their original display, websites with robot txt exclusions often display as an index.

Keyword and file-type search are also available to archived websites through the Web Archiving Service (WAS). To search for keywords within archived websites, click a site name link in the container list. From that page, click the "search" tab on the top left corner. From the search page, you can search by keyword, URL, and file type across all captures of one site or all the sites in the project.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Websites are selected by archivists and captured through the use of the California Digital Library's Web Archiving Service (WAS). WAS uses a web crawler to copy the website at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy of the website.

accruals.head: Accruals note
accruals.p: In general, crawls of sites are added quarterly. New sites are added to finding aids upon completion of 6 month embargo.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials
relatedmaterial.p:
Tamiment Library Web Collection on Individuals

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: Clicking on the links provided in the container list will take the user to the Web Archiving Service (WAS) page for the website. Sometimes the original website is still available on the live web and the original URL may be available. To get to the original web page, click the live link provided in the "Latest Starting URL" field on the WAS page.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Tamiment Library uses the California Digital Library’s Web Archiving Service (WAS) to capture websites for historical purposes. Tamiment archivists select websites for capture based on Tamiment’s collecting policy. After the site is added, the title of the site is sometimes changed to better reflect the name of the organization/project/event/site.

Sites are copied by what are commonly known as spiders, robots, or crawlers to index the website. WAS uses the Heritrix web crawler to copy (or capture) the website at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy of the website. In general, the host page of website is captured for up to 36 hours. The initial capture of a website often includes the archived version of websites that have been linked to by the host website. Websites are crawled quarterly, unless contemporary events cause rapid change to content on a website.
The archivist describes each site using subject headings, a brief description of the site and its contents, and tags. WAS arranges the websites alphabetically and preserves the websites.

In 2014, finding aids were created from the 23 original projects. Original projects were collected by topic and continue to be maintained by the archivists. Three finding aids were created based on Tamiment Library's Printed Ephemera collection categories, to provide better access across websites and collections in Tamiment Library. These finding aids were created using the XML export tool in WAS and manipulated to create DACS-compliant EAD finding aids.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: "Page Title." Archived month/day/year. Tamiment Library Web Collection on Organizations, Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive and Tamiment Library, New York University. ArchivalURL. (Accessed month/day/year).

appraisal.head: Take Down Policy
appraisal.p: Tamiment respects robot txt exclusions and requests from websites with robot txt exclusions to allow our crawler to capture their website. Tamiment will also honor the website owner’s request to remove their website from the collection. To request a site removal, please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: #occupywallstreet is a tumblr blog that contains updates related to the September 17, 2011 occupation of Wall Street by New York City protestors. The website contains news, audiovisual media, and other articles.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.

Occupy Wall Street (Movement).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This website is the call to action for the Occupy Wall Street movement’s September 17, 2012 event, to commemorate the first anniversary of Occupy Wall Street. The event was a four day event made up of assemblies, concerts, talks, and other programs. The website contains a schedule, multimedia, a news blog, and outreach materials.

did.unittitle: 100 Days to Close Guantánamo and End Torture Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: 100 Days to Close Guantanamo & End Torture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: We support President Obama's executive order to close the Guantanamo prison. But it must be closed not just on paper, but in reality. After seven years of detaining hundreds of men without trial, a one year timeline for closing Guantanamo is unacceptable. For the over 70 men currently on hunger strike in Guantanamo, it has been seven years too long. We want justice now. Witness Against Torture announces a campaign to close the U.S. detention facilities at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, and end torture and rendition by the U.S. within the first 100 days of the new administration. With Barack Obama taking office, we have a historic opportunity to reverse the disastrous policies of the last eight years.

dao.ns2:title: 100 Days to Close Guantánamo and End Torture

daodesc.p: 100 Days to Close Guantánamo and End Torture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 123 was a community space in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn that was formed by formed by four grassroots groups - A New World In Our Hearts, Freegan Bike Workshop, Misled Youth Network, NYC Anarchist Black Cross. The organization held daily programs, had a screen-printing studio, a food co-op, a lending library, and support groups. The goal of 123 was to create a community center for the people of Bed-Stuy to organize and make their voices heard. 123 closed down in 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An international website to raise support internationally for the Occupy Movement. The website contains information on global actions that took place in October 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 3.11 Action New York is the website for a march in New York City planned on March 11, 2012. March 11 marks the anniversary of the tsunami in Japan, which triggered the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accident. The march is an anti-nuclear energy campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 350.org is a grassroots movement that works to solve the climate crisis through organizing online campaigns and mass public actions. 350.org raises awareness and works to reduce the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere from its current level at 392 parts per million (ppm) to 350 ppm.

did.unittitle: 99% Power, People's Rights Over Corporate Wrongs Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: 99% Power, People's Rights Over Corporate Wrongs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The 99 Power: People’s Rights over Corporate Wrongs was a grassroots campaign, established in Spring 2012, united to build a new economy and democracy. The campaign called for nonviolent direct action against corporations, including Wells Fargo, GE, Verizon, Sallie Mae, Wal-Mart, Bank of America, and Verizon. The coalition that sponsored this campaign included unions, environmental groups, and other social justice organizations.

dao.ns2:title: 99% Power, People's Rights Over Corporate Wrongs

daodesc.p: 99% Power, People's Rights Over Corporate Wrongs, Dec 4, 2012-Jun 1, 2014

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 99 Pickets, a working group from Occupy Wall Street, works to build the worker's movement in New York City using picket lines. The website contains a blog, action alerts, campaigns, and organizational information.

did.unittitle: A.J. Muste Memorial Institute Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The A.J. Muste Memorial Institute is a nonprofit charitable foundation established in 1974 to honor the legacy of pacifist leader A.J. Muste (1885-1967) and to further nonviolent action as the means to achieve social and economic justice. They provide grants, resources and a wide range of support to activist organizations that use nonviolent strategies to oppose war and promote justice and by publishing and distributing educational materials about nonviolence. The website contains publications and information on grants and scholarships.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ABC No Rio was founded in 1980 by artists committed to political and social engagement in the Lower East Side. It is a collectively-run center for art and activism, and features a gallery space, a zine library, a darkroom, a silkscreening studio, and public computer lab. ABC No Rio seeks to be a community center for the Lower East Side, hosting and sponsoring projects and benefits for the community, promoting volunteerism, art and activism, without giving-in to corporate sponsors.

controlaccess.subject: Art |x Political aspects.
Artists |z New York (State) |z New York.
Hispanic Americans |z New York (State) |z New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ABOLITION 2000, founded in 1995, is a network of over 2000 organizations in more than 90 countries working for a global treaty to eliminate nuclear weapons within a time-bound framework. The Network aims at providing groups concerned with nuclear issues a forum for the exchange of information and the development of joint initiatives. The Abolition 2000 Network meets once a year and communicates on an ongoing basis via list serves, conferences, teleconferencing, and periodic mailings. The website contains information on member organizations, working groups, and information on conferences.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Abolitionism of Specieism’s main goals are to provide a clear statement of a nonviolent approach to animal rights that require the abolition of animal exploitation, animals rights based upon only animal sentience and no other cognitive characteristic, and regards veganism as the moral baseline of the animal rights position.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Abortion Clinic Defense is a tumblr blog that operates as a news source and support group for individuals defending abortion clinics from agitators. The website contains resources.

did.unittitle: Abraham Lincoln Brigade: Spanish Civil War History and Education: Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives (ALBA) is dedicated to preserving and communicating the history and memory of those Americans who participated in the Spanish Civil War on the Republican side. It is also successor to the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. The ALBA archives are housed at the Tamiment Library, New York University. They also publish the quarterly journal, The Volunteer.

dao.ns2:title: Abraham Lincoln Brigade: Spanish Civil War History and Education: Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives

daodesc.p: Abraham Lincoln Brigade: Spanish Civil War History and Education: Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives

did.unittitle: Access: Mobilizing for Global Digital Freedom Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2009, Access is a non-profit organization premised on the belief that the realization of human rights and democracy in the twenty-first century is increasingly predicated on access to the internet and other forms of information communication technology. Access unites with digital activists and civil society groups internationally to build their technical capacity and to help them advocate globally for their digital rights and provides thought leadership and practical policy recommendations in the broader field of internet freedom, and based on that expertise mobilizes its global movement of citizens to campaign for an open internet accessible to all. Access publishes news related to internet censorship and other campaigns.

dao.ns2:title: Access: Mobilizing for Global Digital Freedom

daodesc.p: Access: Mobilizing for Global Digital Freedom

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Access Strategies Fund is a philanthropic foundation that supports organizations fighting for social justice and expanding the democratic process within underserved communities. They provide training and support for infrastructure to help overcome organizational barriers and build partnerships. The website contains information about funding, programs, news, and resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now (ACORN), formed in 1970, was a collection of community-based organizations in the United States that advocated for low- and moderate-income families by working on neighborhood safety, voter registration, health care, affordable housing, and other social issues. In 2010, ACORN filed Chapter 7 liquidation and closed the organization. The organization consisted of 400,000 member families organized into more than 1,200 neighborhood chapters in 110 cities across the country.organizations that are committed to social and economic justice, and won victories on thousands of issues of concern to our members, through direct action, negotiation, legislative advocacy and voter participation. ACORN helps those who have historically been locked out become powerful players in our democratic system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Act Against Torture is a coalition of activists based in the San Francisco Bay Area working to abolish torture and indefinite detention, to end U.S. intervention in Iraq and Afghanistan, and to prevent future wars. Our work is guided by radical, systemic analysis of war, torture and detention; the connections between these and other forms of oppression are the reason we support other movements for social justice as an integral part of our mission. We use strategic, campaign-based organizing to link individual actions in pusuit of larger goals. We work to build strong coalitions and are committed to democratic and participatory organizing. Act Against Torture is not affiliated with any party or organization.

controlaccess.subject: Iraq War, 2003-2011 |x Prisoners and prisons, American.
Torture |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Action Resource Fund (ARF), formerly known as the May Day Fundraising Affinity Group, is a collection of Occupy Activists who joined together to fund raise for protests and actions. ARF raised funds for MayDay 2012- 2013 actions, as well as raise money for those affected by Hurricane Sandy in the fall of 2012. The website contains fundraising reports and a blog.

did.unittitle: Activist Poet's Roundtable with Dennis Brutus | The Socialist Party - USA, Greater NYC Local Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Activist Poets’ Roundtable with Dennis Brutus was an event in New York City on March 16, 2008. Dennis Brutus was a banned poet and political prisoner on Robben Island with Nelson Mandela and 1000 others before the fall of Apartheid in South Africa.

dao.ns2:title: Activist Poet's Roundtable with Dennis Brutus | The Socialist Party - USA, Greater NYC Local

daodesc.p: Activist Poet's Roundtable with Dennis Brutus | The Socialist Party - USA, Greater NYC Local

did.unittitle: Act Now to Stop War and End Racism (ANSWER) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Act Now to Stop War and End Racism (ANSWER), was formed on September 14, 2001. ANSWER is a coalition of organizations and individuals across the United States, campaigning against US intervention in Latin America, the Carribbean, the Middle East and Asia. Partner organizations have campaigned for civil rights and for social and economic justice for working and poor people inside the United States. They work through direct action, protests, and other forms of demonstration. The website contains news listings, news analysis, information about regional offices, and event listings.

dao.ns2:title: Act Now to Stop War and End Racism (ANSWER)

daodesc.p: Act Now to Stop War and End Racism (ANSWER)

did.unittitle: Act Up New York Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Act Up NY was founded in New York City in 1987 and is a diverse, non-partisan group of individuals united in anger and committed to direct action to end the AIDS crisis. AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power (ACT UP), founded in New York City in 1987, and is a diverse, non-partisan group committed to direct action to end the AIDS crisis by bringing about legislation, medical research, treatment, and policies to bring an end to the disease. The website has not been updated since 2007.

controlaccess.subject: AIDS activists |z New York (State) |z New York.
Gay liberation movement |z New York (State) |z New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Based in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, Adbusters Media Foundation is a not-for-profit, reader-supported, magazine concerned about the erosion of our physical and cultural environments by commercial forces. Adbusters offers philosophical articles as well as activist commentary from around the world addressing issues ranging from genetically modified foods to media concentration. Adbusters is an ecological magazine, dedicated to examining the relationship between human beings and their physical and mental environment. The website is made up of back issues of the magazine, spoof ads, blogs, and videos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Aesthetic Realism Foundation’s goal “is to meet the urgent need for people throughout America and the world to see each other and reality fairly” based on Eli Siegel’s philosophy. The Foundation offers classes every semester, workshops, public seminars, outreach programs, and consultations. The foundation also supports a theatre company and gallery. The website contains information on Eli Siegel, their programs, library, and other resources on aesthetic realism.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Alliance of Charter Teachers and Staff

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Alliance of Charter Teachers and Staff (ACTS) is community of charter school employees organized by the Federation of Teachers. The alliance works to mobilize charter school employees around issues such as expanding professional development, bettering wages and benefits, improving teaching and learning conditions, and strengthening their voice in school-level decision making.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ACT (Against Child Trafficking) is a student anti-child trafficking coalition at New York University that raises awareness about child trafficking and the continuing existence of slavery, advocates for strong anti-trafficking laws, fundraises for anti-trafficking organizations, and works toward combating child slavery today.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Against Pornography is a feminist anti-pornography website which aims at raising the awareness about the harms of pornography in and outside of the industry to women and children. They work against the sexual objectification of women and view pornography as a threat to female equality. The website features resources and a FAQ.

did.unittitle: Against the Current | Solidarity Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Against the Current is Solidarity-US.org's bi-monthly analytical journal. This capture has not been scheduled for future crawls, future captures will be made only at Solidarity-US.org's main entry here: http://webarchives.cdlib.org/site/sw1639kf2j.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Against the Grain is a daily radio program and web media project whose aim is to provide in-depth analysis and commentary on political, economic, social and cultural matters important to progressive and radical thinking and activism. It is based at the studios of Pacifica station KPFA-FM in Berkeley, California and co-hosted and co-produced by Sasha Lilley and C.S. Soong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The A-Infos Radio Project, formed in 1996, is a free service to share radio programs created by activists and other alternative radio journalists. Contributors donate their programs and are responsible for their content. The project’s goal is to expand the movement for democratic communications and to be an alternative to corporate and government media. The website contains thousands of archived radio shows available for download, free of charge.

did.unittitle: Aisling Irish Community Center Archived Site

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Aisling Irish Community Center is located in Yonkers, New York. Established in 1996, the Center serves to assist Irish immigrants moving to the United States. The Aisling Center also provides services for the elderly Irish and Irish-American community in Yonkers and Woodlawn. The website contains event and classes schedules, a photo gallery, and news listings.

controlaccess.subject: Immigrants |z United States
Irish Americans |x Social life and customs.
Irish Americans |z New York (State) |z New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: AK Press is an anarchist, worker-run collective that publishes and distributes radical books, visual and audio media, and other material. AK Press’s goal is supplying radical words and images to as many people as possible. The books and other media distributed are published by independent presses and AK Press makes them widely available to work to help make revolutionary changes in the world. They also have a blog, Revolution by the Book, which informs people about anarchist publishing in general and AK Press in particular.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Center for Media and Democracy (Madison, Wis.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ALEC Exposed is a wiki website, established by the Center for Media and Democracy in 2011, showcasing 800 "model" and resolutions secretly voted on by corporations and politicians through the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC). Some bills were introduced in legislatures on the state level without disclosing that they were previously drafted and voting on by corporations and politicians. ALEC bills address a host of issues, including worker and consumer rights, education, taxes, health care, and immigration, often directly benefiting large corporations. The website works to analyze and annotate the bills to make them understandable to readers and provides factsheets and reasoning as to why the bills are harmful to the democratic processes of the United States. The website separates the bills into topics, including worker and consumer rights; tort reform and injured Americans; privatizing schools and higher education policy; health and pharmaceutical, and safety net programs; environment, energy, and agriculture; democracy, voter rights, and federal power; taxes and budgets; and guns, prisons, crime, and investigation. The website contains the bills, background information on ALEC, news, and analysis.

did.unittitle: ALIGN: Alliance for a Greater New York Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: ALIGN: The Alliance for a Greater New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ALIGN: The Alliance for a Greater New York was formed in 2011 through the merger of New York Jobs and Justice and Urban Agenda and is a coalition building organization that works to create jobs, publish policy research, and train community leaders. The website sponsors environmental, economic accountability, and workers’ rights projects. The website contains news listings, action alerts, petitions, publications, and other resources.

dao.ns2:title: ALIGN: Alliance for a Greater New York

daodesc.p: ALIGN: Alliance for a Greater New York

did.unittitle: Alliance for Nuclear Accountability Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1984, Alliance for Nuclear Accountability is a national network of 35 organizations working to address issues of nuclear weapons production and waste cleanup. They have worked to open up the operations of the U.S. Department of Energy to help shut down polluting, obsolete and unsafe facilities, and to stop nuclear weapons testing as well as the construction of many new bomb production plants. The website contains information on their issues and member organizations, articles, news, and resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1969 at Carleton College in Northfield, MN, the Alternative Press Center (APC) is a non-profit collective and periodicals library that works to provide access and increase awareness of the alternative press. Currently located in Chicago, IL, the APC publishes the Alternative Press Index (API), a guide to the alternative press in English, French and Spanish and available in print or online form. The API provides access to articles from 300 magazines, newspapers and academic journals. Since 1969, the API has indexed 948 periodical titles. The APC also publishes Annotations: a Guide to the Independent Critical Press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Alternative Radio (AR), founded in 1986 and based in Boulder, CO, is a weekly one-hour public affairs program offered free to all public radio stations in the United States, Canada, Europe, South Africa, Australia, and on short-wave on Radio for Peace International. AR provides information, analysis, and views that are ignored or distorted in other media. AR reaches over 125 radio stations and millions of listeners. AR is part of the non-profit Institute for Social and Cultural Change.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: AlterNet, founded in 1998, is a news magazine and online community that publishes original journalism and creates awareness of other independent media sources. AlterNet’s goal is to provide free content and to inspire action and advocacy on the environment, human rights, civil liberties, social justice, and other issues. AlterNet is an aggregator website, and features 12 special coverage areas, each with its own hub site, editor, and weekly newsletter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Association of Alternative Newsmedia (AAN), founded in 1978, is a group of 130 alternative news organizations covering every major metropolitan area and other less-populated regions of North America. AAN has a combined weekly circulation of over 6.5 million as well as a print readership of nearly 17 million. AAN focuses on local news; culture and the arts; an informal and sometimes profane style; an emphasis on point-of-view reporting and narrative journalism; a tolerance for individual freedoms and social differences; and other news that is ignored by mainstream media. The website contains national and local newswires, a directory of member news organizations, conferences, and resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Amalgamated Housing Cooperative, founded in 1927, is a limited equity housing cooperative in the Bronx, New York, originally sponsored by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union. Their goal is to provide affordable housing and community, while living in accordance with cooperative ideals. The cooperative provides housing for 1500 families. The website contains a photo gallery, an activities committee page, and a community guide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Ameinu (Hebrew for "Our People"), previously the Labor Zionist Alliance, formed in 2003, is a national organization of progressive American Jews that fosters social and economic justice in Israel and in the United States. Ameinu supports a two state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and peace between Israel and its neighboring countries.

did.unittitle: American Civil Liberties Union, Accountability for Torture, Restore the Rule of Law, Enhanced Interrogation Techniques, Waterboard Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: We are finally beginning to learn the full scope of the Bush administration's torture program. Government documents show that hundreds of prisoners were tortured in the custody of the CIA and Department of Defense, some of them killed in the course of interrogations. Justice Department memos show that the torture policies were devised and developed at the highest levels of the Bush administration. The ACLU is committed to restoring the rule of law. We will fight for the disclosure of the torture files that are still secret. We will advocate for the victims of the Bush administration's unlawful policies. We will press Congress to appoint a select committee that can investigate the roots of the torture program and recommend legislative changes to ensure that the abuses of the last eight years are not repeated. And we will advocate for the appointment of an independent prosecutor to examine issues of criminal responsibility.

did.unittitle: American Civil Liberties Union, Safe and Free Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: National Security: SAFE AND FREE AT HOME There has never been a more urgent need to preserve fundamental privacy protections and our system of checks and balances than the need we face today, as illegal government spying, provisions of the Patriot Act and government-sponsored torture programs transcend the bounds of law and our most treasured values in the name of national security. Throughout U.S. history "national security" has often been used as a pretext for massive violations of individual rights. The terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 mobilized our country in the fight against terrorism. However, this also launched a serious civil liberties crises. The ACLU continues to challenge policies like the USA Patriot Act, and creates campaigns like Safe and Free.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The American Constitution Society for Law and Policy (ACS) is a progressive legal organization that promotes the U.S. Constitutional values of individual rights and liberties, genuine equality, access to justice, democracy and the rule of law. ACS was formed in 2001 at Georgetown Law Center by then-law professor Peter J. Rubin, in part as a counterweight to the conservative Federalist Society’s “original intent” interpretation of the U.S. Constitution. ACS has 13,000 members, 165 student chapters and lawyer chapters in 32 cities. The organization promotes and facilitates discussion and debate of progressive public policy ideas and issues, providing forums for legal scholars, lawmakers, judges, lawyers, public policy advocates, law students and members of the media.

did.unittitle: American Friends Service Committee Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The American Friends Service Committee carries out service, development, social justice, and peace programs throughout the world. Founded by Quakers ( A pacifist Christian denomination) in 1917 to provide conscientious objectors with an opportunity to aid civilian war victims. AFSC's work is based on the Quaker belief in the worth of every person and faith in the power of love to overcome violence and injustice. The organization's mission and achievements won worldwide recognition in 1947 when it accepted the Nobel Peace Prize with the British Friends Service Council on behalf of all Quakers. Some of the American Friends Service Committee’s campaigns include withdrawing US troops, eliminating nuclear weapons, transforming the criminal justice system, reforming immigration policy, and other campaigns to foster peace in communities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The American Prospect is a liberal and progressive magazine, founded in 1990 by Robert Kuttner, Robert Reich, and Paul Starr. Since then, the Prospect has grown into a print journal with an average monthly readership of some 100,000, a special in-depth report in most issues, and a daily Web magazine with nearly 1 million unique monthly visitors. The magazine's goals are to demonstrate that progressive ideas could animate a majority politics; to energize civic democracy and give voice to the disenfranchised; and to counteract the growing influence of conservative media.

did.unittitle: Americans for Democratic Action Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Americans for Democratic Action (ADA), founded in 1947 by Eleanor Roosevelt, John Kenneth Galbraith, Walter Reuther, Arthur Schlesinger, and Reinhold Niebuhr, is a liberal lobbying organization. ADA works for social and economic justice through lobbying, grassroots organizing, research, and supporting progressive candidates. The website contains publications, information on issues, and action alerts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Amnesty International at New York University is a student affiliate of AI whose activities mostly consist of letter-writing campaigns directed at freeing prisoners of conscience, granting prisoners fair trials, and ensuring that they are not subjected to torture. Other campaigns include petition signing and rally and vigil organizing on other human rights issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Anarcha is an online resource for anarchist feminist news, articles, images, and discussion. Anarcha was initially an info-distribution center for the Anarcha Interview Project, but soon added the SallyDarity Anarcha-Feminist and Gender Anarchy Resource Guide. The Anarcha Project is a collection of interviews of primarily women and transgendered anarchist and anti-authoritarian people in the United States, conducted from 2003 to 2005. Currently, the collection is unavailable on the website.

scopecontent.p: The Anarchist Black Cross Federation (formerly known as Anarchist Black Cross Network), was created in 1995 when the North American Anarchist Black Cross collectives from New Jersey, New York, and Washington DC merged into a federation. The aim of the ABCF is to build an organization capable of offering support for class war political prisoners and prisoners of war, defined as someone who is imprisoned for actions deemed revolutionary. The Anarchist Black Cross Federation is an American chapter of the Anarchist Black Cross.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Animal Legal Defense Fund, founded in 1979, with more than 100,000 members, works to protect animals by filing lawsuits to stop animal abuse and expand the boundaries of animal law; providing free legal assistance to prosecutors handling cruelty cases; working to strengthen state anti-cruelty statutes; encouraging the federal government to enforce existing animal protection laws; nurturing the future of animal law through the Student Animal Legal Defense Fund chapters and our Animal Law Program; and providing public education through seminars, workshops and other outreach efforts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Animal Liberation Front (ALF) consists of small autonomous groups of people all over the world who carry out direct action against animal abuse in the form of rescuing animals and causing financial loss to animal exploiters, usually through the damage and destruction of property.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Animal Liberation Front (ALF) carries out non-violent direct action against animal abuse in the form of rescuing animals and causing financial loss to animal exploiters, usually through the damage and destruction of property. ALF's goal is to save as many animals as possible and directly disrupt the practice of animal abuse to eventually end all animal suffering by forcing animal abuse companies (agribusiness, laboratories, etc.) out of business. Because ALF actions may be against the law, activists work anonymously, either in small groups or individually, and do not have any centralized organization or coordination. The ALF also advocates veganism or vegetarianism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Animal Liberation Frontline (formerly known as Voice of the Voiceless), created by Peter Young, publishes news on the Animal Liberation Front and other direct action in the animal liberation movement and publishes resources for legal animal rights activism. Peter Young is a veteran activist and former animal liberation prisoner.

did.unittitle: Animal Rights: The Abolitionist Approach Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Animal Rights: The Abolitionist Approach’s main goals are to provide a clear statement of a nonviolent approach to animal rights that require the abolition of animal exploitation, animals rights based upon only animal sentience and no other cognitive characteristic, regards veganism as the moral baseline of the animal rights position, and promote activism in the form of creative non-violent vegan education.

The documentary uses interviews, archival footage, and photography to give insight to the anti-communist left critical scene in New York City in the 1930s-1960s. The documentary was made by PBS. The website contains information on the documentary, the individuals, reviews, and crew credits.

AMO provides support to cultural workers who seek to impact the national conversation on the Economy, including production grants, distribution, and PR support. AMO supports artists of all mediums, including visual artists, filmmakers, street theatre and other art forms. scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Asian Pacific Forum was founded in 1998, when Samori Marksman, program director of WBAI, and Sybil Wong, former business director of WBAI, brought together a group of journalists and activists to organize a weekly program focused on New York's Asian communities. In 2006, APF began podcasting and making its weekly broadcasts available as downloads on the web, allowing the show to reach a broader audience both nationally and globally. The website contains programs on activism, immigration, civil and human rights, politics, and other topics. The website also has a listing of songs on the station, book recommendations, news, and event listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Asian CineVision (ACV) is a non-profit media arts organization that develops, promotes and preserves media made by or about peoples of Asian descent. Asian CineVision was founded by grassroots media activists in New York's Chinatown in 1976 to raise social and cultural awareness of the Asian American experience, both in the Asian American community and among the general public. CineVue Online is ACV’s media arts journal established in 1986. The website contains their media arts journal, information on their Asian American International Film Festival, news listings, event listings, and press releases.

did.unittitle: Asian American Arts Centre Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Asian American Arts Centre, founded in 1974 as Asian American Dance Theatre, is one of the older community arts organizations in New York City Chinatown. The current name, Asian American Arts Centre, was adopted in 1987 to encompass both the dance company (Asian American Dance Theatre) and the visual arts program, Asian Arts Institute, initiated in 1984. In 2007, the Asian American Art Centre created a new archive, the AAAC Artist Archive. 150 artists who exemplified the major issues that compose the subject of Asian American art were selected and their materials processed for long-term archival preservation. The website contains a blog with details on past and current exhibitions, the digital archive of art, and information related to community organizing in Chinatown.

ANHD’s mission is to protect neighborhoods and provide affordable housing for all New Yorkers. ANHD provides training, technical assistance and advocacy for and on behalf of member organizations. scopecontent.p: The Association of Filipinas, Feminists Fighting Imperialism, Re-feudalization, and Marginalization (AF3IRM, evolved from the Gabriela Network, GABNet), is a national organization of women engaged in transnational feminist, anti-imperialist activism. AF3IRM is committed to militant movement-building from the United States and effects change through grassroots organizing, trans-ethnic alliance building education, advocacy and direct action. The website contains information on their action campaigns, chapters, events, and resources.

did.unittitle: Attica is All of Us Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Attica is All of Us is a group of Attica Correctional Facility survivors from the 1971 prison riot, their attorneys, friends, family and allies that raise awareness of prison conditions, call for the reform of the prison system and the end of mass incarceration, and racism in the prison system. The website contains a petition to close Attica, resources, an events calendar, and information on their Attica is Now program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1984, Autonomedia is a North American publisher of radical theoretical works, especially in the anarchist tradition. Autonomedia publishes books on topics such as anarchism, Marxist works, cyberfeminism, drug literature, turn of the 21st century queer individualist anarchist novels, and other works. They are known for publishing the "Autonomedia Calendar of Jubilee Saints," in which every day of the calendar recalls a deceased person of some significance to progressive movements or thought. They also maintain the Interactivist Info Exchange, an online forum for discourse and debate on themes relevant to the books that they publish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Axis of Logic is a news website that publishes news and commentary that is not presented in major news outlets. Axis of Logic publishes both original writing from its readers, as well as news and article submissions. Axis of Logic advocates world peace, self-governance by the people, and noninterference in the domestic affairs of any nation by foreign governments and, identifies "Corporate Global Empire" as our common foe and the enemy of the people.

CMD is a national organization based in Madison, Wisconsin, founded by John Stauber in 1993 as an independent, non-profit, non-partisan, public interest group. CMD's mission includes promoting transparency and informed debate by exposing corporate spin and government propaganda, they also inform and assist grassroots citizen activism in promoting economic justice, public health, ecological sustainability and human rights. BanksterUSA is a watchdog group on financial service institutions and to help average citizens be informed and help shape policy solutions for re-regulation of Wall Street.

scopecontent.p: Because We Must (formerly VeganThis, found in the Animal Rights web archive) is an environmental group that focuses on the idea that all forms of oppression are connected and fights against "white supremacist, patriarchal, capitalist culture" on the planet. The website operates as a newswire, posting information about animal rights, environmental issues, women’s rights, and queer rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Behind the Homefront, produced by the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press in 2003, was a daily chronicle of news in homeland security and military operations, civil liberties issues, affecting newsgathering and access to information; in response to the creation of the Department of Homeland Security. Funding for the site was provided by The Robert R. McCormick Tribune Foundation. The website has not been updated since 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bend the Arc was formed from a merger of the Jewish Funds for Justice and the Progressive Jewish Alliance in 2011. Both of those archived websites can be found in the Jewish American Left web archive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Beyondmedia Education is a social justice organization that collaborates with under-served and under-represented women, youth and communities to tell their stories and organize for social justice through the creation and distribution of media arts. The website contains information on their programs, information on client services, merchandise, and news updates.

controlaccess.subject: Feminism and the arts |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Billboard Liberation Front, founded in 1977, is a culture jamming organization. The organization attempts to disrupt or subvert mainstream cultural institutions, mass media, and advertising to critiques the media's manipulation of reality, lampoon consumerism, or question corporate power. The BLF adulterates billboard advertising, often employing satire and irony. The website last appeared to be active in November 2008.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Billionaires for Bush, founded by Andrew Boyd as "Billionaires for Forbes” in 1999, is a culture jamming political street theater activist group that satirically purports to support George W. Bush for those activities which are perceived to benefit corporations and the super-wealthy and expose politicians who support corporate interests. The organization has 100 chapters nationally. The website was most active during the George W. Bush presidency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: B-Word Worldwide, affiliated with Bitch Media, is the nonprofit organization best known for publishing the magazine Bitch: Feminist Response to Pop Culture. Bitch Media’s mission is to provide and encourage an engaged, thoughtful feminist response to mainstream media and popular culture. The magazine was launched in 1996 by Lisa Jervis, Benjamin Shaykin, and Andi Zeisler.

daodesc.p: Bitch Magazine Archived Website, Nov 11, 2009 - ongoing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bite Back Magazine was set up in 2001 by Nicolas Atwood, an animal rights activist in West Palm Beach, Florida. Bite Back promotes the cause of the animal liberation movement, publicizes the cases of those imprisoned for taking direct action to defend animal rights, and also acts as a forum for activists to take part in direct action in the animal rights movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2006, Black Agenda Report is a newswire that contains news, commentary, and analysis from the black left. The website contains their radio show, Black Agenda Radio commentaries, blogs by featured writers, other audio and video, and world and US news.

did.unittitle: Black Left Unity Network Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Black Left Unity Network is a network in solidarity with the Black Liberation movement, which opposes racist and anti-immigrant laws. The website publicizes information about strikes and other actions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Blackout Arts Collective (BAC), founded 1997 in New York, is a grassroots coalition of artists, activists and educators working to empower communities of color through the arts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Black Radical Congress (BRC), founded in 1998 in Chicago, is a radical African American activist coalition of organizations and individuals focused on advocating for broad progressive social justice, racial equality and economic justice goals within the United States. The BRC holds conferences and other programs. The website only gives information on the BRC’s history and biographical information on notable individuals relating to the BRC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bloombergville Now!, established in 2011, is a group against budget cuts in New York City against libraries, education, affordable housing, and other services provided in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The BlueGreen Alliance, established in 2006, is a national partnership between labor unions and environmental organizations dedicated to expanding the number and quality of jobs in the green economy. They seek to raise awareness of job-creating potential of environmental investments, including solutions to global warming. The alliance accomplishes their work through legislation, education, conferences, and campaigns. The organization is affiliated with numerous labor unions and environmental organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: BlueNC is an independent, collaborative website for culture and politics in North Carolina, not affliated with the Democratic Party. The website contains satirical writings and a blog. The website features a section on Voter Suppression in North Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bluestockings is a radical bookstore, fair trade cafe, and activist center in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. The bookstore is also an educational and activist event space to support movements that challenge hierarchy and oppression. The website holds events listings.

did.unittitle: Bradley Manning Support Network Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Bradley Manning Support Network was an organization dedicated to freeing Private Chelsea (formerly Bradley) Manning from serving a 35 year prison sentence for providing classified information to WikiLeaks. In August 2013, the organization changed its name to the Private Manning Support Network when Manning announced she would like to begin to be known publicly by the name of Chelsea Elizabeth Manning, pursue hormone therapy, and be referred to with female pronouns. The website became the Private Manning Support Network in August 2013.

controlaccess.subject: Leaks (Disclosure of information)
Whistle blowing |x Law and legislation |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1963, the Bread and Puppet Theater is a touring puppet theatre company that focuses its performances radical, political issues, based out of Vermont. The website contains information on their tours, their cheap art philosophy, and their press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: BreaktheChains.info is a news and discussion forum for supporters of political prisoners, prisoners of war, politicized social prisoners, and victims of police and state intimidation, established in 2006. The forum is updated by members of the disbanded Break the Chains Prisoner Support Network, formerly based in Eugene, Oregon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Brecht Forum, originally located at 451 West Street in Manhattan, now at 388 Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, is a Marxist cultural and educational center. The Brecht Forum was founded in 1975 as The New York Marxist School. In 1984, the founding collective incorporated as The Brecht Forum with The New York Marxist School as the Forum's core project. In addition to the New York Marxist School, it also offers other programs, language classes, and arts and cultural events. The website contains information on their curriculum and classes, as well as economic news analysis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Brighton Beach Neighborhood Association, founded in 1977, is the housing association of the Brighton Beach neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York City. The association provides housing and health advocacy, landlord assistance, homeowner counseling, tenant organizing, social services, youth services, and economic development. The website contains event listings and action alerts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brights’ Net is the website of the Brights movement, which aims to promote public understanding and acknowledgment of the naturalistic ((free from supernatural and mystical elements) worldview, including equal civil rights and acceptance for people who hold a naturalistic worldview. It was co-founded by Paul Geisert and Mynga Futrell in 2003. The website also provides a community for the movement.

did.unittitle: Brit Tzedek v'Shalom - Jewish Alliance for Justice and Peace Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brit Tzedek v’Shalom, founded in 2002, is a Jewish peace organization that advocated a two-state resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The organization consisted of approximately 40,000 members organized into a national chapter network, working to educate and advocate for within the Jewish community for a two-state solution and peace in the Middle East. As of January 1, 2010, Brit Tzedek v’Shalom has integrated within the J Street Education Fund.

dao.ns2:title: Brit Tzedek v'Shalom - Jewish Alliance for Justice and Peace

daodesc.p: Brit Tzedek v'Shalom - Jewish Alliance for Justice and Peace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brooklyn For Peace was founded in 1984 as Brooklyn Parents for Peace, in response to the U.S invasion of Grenada. Through education on international and domestic issues, the organization works to empower the Brooklyn community to secure a peaceful future for generations to come by building a world where peace is the first response to conflict. They promote U.S. foreign policies based not on coercion and violence, but on peace, justice, democratic advancement, human rights and respect for international law. Their goals include transferring military funds to human needs funds, eliminating nuclear weapons, and resolving conflicts through the United Nations. The website contains information on their working committees, events, and current activities.

controlaccess.subject: Peace movements |z New York (State) |z New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A situationist website, largely consisting of situationist writings in several languages, apparently edited by Ken Knabb.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Business of Detention is a U.S.-based online publication created by reporters Stokely Baksh and Renee Feltz, launched in 2007. The website publishes contemporary immigration detention coverage that grew out of their investigative report on the Corrections Corporation of America in 2008. They sought to present a picture of how the nation’s largest private prison company had partnered with the federal government to detain close to a million undocumented immigrants until they were deported, and in the process fill their empty beds and increase revenue. The website aggregates news on immigration detention.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: BuzzFlash, founded in 2000, is a progressive newswire that provides headlines, commentary, and news analysis to five million people a month. The website contains a link to their parent site, Truth-Out, news, videos, and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Café Progressive is a social justice and environmental activism resource center that provides a guide to progressive sources online. The website displays resources by tags and categories. The website contains social justice and environmental activism sites, blogs, organizations, visionaries, movements and sources for alternative news and information.

did.unittitle: Campaign for America's Future Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Institute for America’s Future is part of the Campaign for America’s Future, is a strategy center for the progressive movement, whose goal is to create a progressive majority to realize the America of shared prosperity and equal opportunity. The campaign pushes progressive agenda issues that address problems that working families face and educates progressive thinkers, organizers, and community activists. The Institute for America’s Future equips Americans with the tools and information needed to drive issues into the national debate, challenge failed conservative policies and build support for the progressive vision of a government that is on the side of working people. For future captures, please see Campaign for America's Future.

did.unittitle: Campaign for Peace and Democracy Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Campaign for Peace and Democracy, founded in 1982, works to advance a progressive and non-militaristic U.S. foreign policy and is opposition to current U.S. foreign policy. Orginally, the campaign engaged Western peace activists in the defense of the rights of democratic dissidents in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, and enlisted East-bloc human rights activists against anti-democratic U.S. policies in countries like Nicaragua and Chile. The majority of the Campaign’s work has been its efforts to work with dissidents and social justice movements worldwide, and to forge alliances between them and progressive movements in the United States. The website contains petitions, endorsements, action alerts, news analysis, and endorsements.

did.unittitle: Campaign to End the Death Penalty Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Campaign to End the Death Penalty

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Campaign to End the Death Penalty (CEDP) is a national grassroots organization dedicated to the abolition of capital punishment. CEDP works with specific cases to free innocent men on death row through education, outreach, protests, and events, like their "Live from Death Row" event. They also hold an annual convention. The website contains information on chapters, their newsletter, action alerts, multimedia, information on prisoners, and other news.

dao.ns2:title: Campaign to End the Death Penalty

daodesc.p: Campaign to End the Death Penalty

did.unittitle: Campaign to Stop Killer Coke Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Campaign to Stop Killer Coke is a worldwide movement based on the efforts of thousands of volunteers. Ray Rogers is the director of the Campaign to Stop Killer Coke. His organization, Corporate Campaign, Inc., created the Campaign to Stop Killer Coke to hold The Coca-Cola Company, its bottlers and subsidiaries accountable and to end the gruesome cycle of violence including the systematic intimidation, kidnapping, torture and murder of union leaders and members of their families in efforts to crush their unions, particularly in Colombia and Guatemala.

did.unittitle: Camp Delta Standard Operating Procedure Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains the United States Dept. of Defense Joint Task Force Guantanamo (JTF-GTMO) standard operating procedures (SOP) for Camp Delta (Guantanamo Bay prison), 2003 and related documents. This is the primary document for the operation of Guantanamo bay, including the securing and treatment of detainees. The document is extensive and includes, in addition to text various forms, identity cards and even Muslim burial instructions. It is signed by Major General Miller, who Donald Rumsfeld later sent to Abu Ghraib to "Gitmoize it". The document is also the subject of an ongoing legal action between the ACLU, which has been trying to obtain it, and the Department of Defense, which has withheld it in full. Wikileaks is a multi-jurisdictional organization to protect internal dissidents, whistleblowers, journalists and bloggers who face legal or other threats related to publishing. Wikileaks provides a forum for the entire global community to relentlessly examine any document for its credibility, plausibility, veracity and validity.

controlaccess.subject: Iraq War, 2003-2011 |x Prisoners and prisons, American.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Camp Kinderland was founded on Sylvan Lake in Hopewell Junction, NY in 1923 by members of the Workmen’s Circle who worked in the organization’s New York City schools. The camp’s founders sought to create a summer youth camp that would not only provide a recreational escape for the children of working people from the tenements of New York City, but also one whose culture would encourage and foster a commitment to socially progressive activism and the embracing of a rich Jewish secular tradition. The website contains news and event listings, camper and parent resources, and information about renting their facilities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: CampusActivism.org, established in 2002, operates as a networking tool and database for student activists. The website works with activists to share contact information, event information, ideas, and resources. The website contains tools to add and browse email lists, campaign notices, issues, events, contacts, groups, and resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Campus Progress is a national organization that works with and for young people to promote progressive solutions to key political and social challenges, with a special emphasis on access and other issues related to college education.

did.unittitle: Center for American Progress Action Fund Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Center for American Progress Action Fund, founded in 2003, is a progressive public policy research and advocacy organization. Their mission is to transform progressive ideas into policy through rapid response communications, legislative action, grassroots organizing and advocacy, and partnerships with other progressive leaders. Their projects include ThinkProgress [captured in Alternative Media collection], the American Worker Project, and the Campus Progress Action project [captured in Education and Student Movements collection]. The website contains news and publications related to the organization and event listings.

did.unittitle: Center for Constitutional Rights Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Center for Constitutional Rights (New York, N.Y.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR), founded in 1966 by attorneys who represented civil rights movements in the South, is dedicated to advancing and protecting the rights guaranteed by the United States Constitution and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. CCR is a non-profit legal and educational organization committed to the use of law as a force for social change. Some issues CCR works on is illegal detention and Guantanamo, surveillance and attacks on dissent, criminal justice and mass incarcerations, corporate human rights abuse, government abuse of power, racial and gender justice, and international law and accountability. The website lists news and current cases. Note that the CCR’s records are at the Tamiment Library.

did.unittitle: Center for Democracy & Technology Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Center for Democracy and Technology is a non-profit public interest civil liberties organization working to keep the Internet open, innovative, and free, using its expertise in law, technology, and policy. CDT works to enhance free expression and privacy in communications technologies while protecting civil liberties, and develops and works to implement policies that will keep the Internet open, innovative and free.

did.unittitle: Center for Media Justice Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2002, the Center for Media Justice is a progressive communications strategy and media policy tank for grassroots organizations serving communities of color and America’s poor. Their mission is to create media and cultural conditions that strengthen movements for racial justice, economic equity, and human rights. The Center has three main programs, the Justice Communication Program, MAG-Net, and the Media Justice Policy Program.

did.unittitle: Center for Popular Economics (CPE) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Center for Popular Economics, founded in 1979 based in Amherst, MA, is a non-profit collective of over 80 economists, dedicated to building a just, sustainable and viable economy. They examine root causes of economic inequality and injustice including systems of oppression based on race, class, gender, nation and ethnicity. They work to make education on economics more understandable and accessible. The website publishes a newsletter and other publications, news, and hosts workshops and institutes. NOTE: This site's capture schedule has been turned off. More current captures can be found in our Economic and Social Justice web archive.

did.unittitle: Center for Popular Economics Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Center for Popular Economics is a non-profit collective of progressive political economists, all dedicated to building a just, sustainable and viable economy. The center is based in Amherst, MA and was founded in 1979. The center hosts workshops and institutes and produces publications that demystify the economy and give economic tools to people fighting for social and economic justice.

did.unittitle: Center for Story-based Strategy Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2002, the Center for Story-based Strategy (CSS) offers tools, training, and strategy support to organizations and movements working for social and ecological justice and social change. The Strategy and Training Project is a nonprofit collective that works to apply meme theory and a narrative analysis of power to strengthen social change efforts. The website contains a blog, training materials, and information on projects. They were formerly known as smartMeme.

did.unittitle: Center for the Study of Political Graphics Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Center for the Study of Political Graphics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Center for the Study of Political Graphics collects, preserves, and exhibits posters relating to historical and contemporary movements for social change. CSPG demonstrates the power and significance of these artistic expressions of social change through traveling exhibitions, lectures, publications, and workshops. They have over 75,000 posters from the Russian Revolution to the present day. The website contains virtual exhibits, weekly poster posts, and a print shop.

dao.ns2:title: Center for the Study of Political Graphics

daodesc.p: Center for the Study of Political Graphics

did.unittitle: Center for The Working Poor Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2006, The Center for the Working Poor is an inter-faith intentional community inspired by the Catholic Worker movement and New Monasticism, and which is committed to strategic non-violent social change. The Center shares a vision of non-violent social change to benefit the most oppressed in our society. Volunteer members run the Center for the Working Poor, which is a non-profit that provides social services, and organizes protest, including civil disobedience actions, hunger strikes, and other forms of strategic non-violence. Also part of the website is their newspaper, the Burning Bush.

did.unittitle: Central New York Reds Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Central New York Reds is the website for the Socialist Party of Central New York. The organization holds regular Socialist forums to discuss and debate important topics and to include radical perspective, organize protests, and other activities. The website contains event listings, information about their platform, resources, and a blog.

did.unittitle: Chelsea Manning Support Network Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Chelsea Manning Support Network is an organization dedicated to freeing Private Chelsea (formerly Bradley) Manning from serving a 35 year prison sentence for providing classified information to WikiLeaks. In August 2013, the organization changed its name when Manning announced she would like to begin to be known publicly by the name of Chelsea Elizabeth Manning, pursue hormone therapy, and be referred to with female pronouns. In 2014, the organization changed its name from the Private Manning Support Network to the Chelsea Manning Support Network. The organization raises funds for Manning, posts news about Manning and on other cases related to government surveillance and whistle-blowing, as well as a campaign to pardon Manning. The website also contains a significant amount of information on the trial that took place in 2013.
