did.unittitle: Citizens For Tax Justice Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Citizens for Tax Justice (CTJ), founded in 1979, is a public interest research and advocacy organization focusing on federal, state and local tax policies and their impact upon the United States. CTJ works to give citizens a voice in new tax laws, fairer taxes for middle and low income families, closing corporate tax loopholes, reducing the federal debt, promoting funding for government services, and other campaigns promoting tax justice.

did.unittitle: Climate and Capitalism: An Ecosocialist Journal Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Climate and Capitalism is an online journal focusing on capitalism, climate change, and the eco-socialist alternative. Its goals are to provide news and analysis to inform, educate and develop the green left; to contribute to building an international movement against capitalist destruction of the environment and for eco-socialism; and to encourage and facilitate collaboration and exchanges of views among socialists and ecology activists.They are affiliated with the Monthly Review. The website contains back issues and resources.

dao.ns2:title: Climate and Capitalism: An Ecosocialist Journal

daodesc.p: Climate and Capitalism: An Ecosocialist Journal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Climate Crisis Coalition, founded in 2004, is a climate control organization, whose goals are to reduce atmospheric CO2 to 350 ppm; enact legislation that will drive the transition to renewable energy; and enacting an escalating and equitable carbon fee. The website contains resources and a blog called Earth Equity News.

did.unittitle: Climate Pledge of Resistance Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: BeyondTalk.net sponsors the Climate Pledge of Resistance, in which members pledge to engage in non-violent civil disobedience to raise awareness of climate change and promote solutions to the climate crisis. The website helps organize nonviolent resistance actions. The other initiating groups of Beyond Talk were 350.org; Alliance of Community Trainers; Center for the Working Poor; Global Justice Ecology Project; Indigenous Environmental Network; Mobilization for Climate Justice West; Rainforest Action Network; Rising Tide North America; Ruckus Society; Yes Men.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: CODEPINK is a women-initiated grassroots peace and social justice movement working to end the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, stop new wars, and redirect resources into healthcare, education, green jobs and other life-affirming activities. CODEPINK rejects foreign policies based on domination and aggression, and instead calls for policies based on diplomacy, compassion and a commitment to international law. The website sponsors events and is made up of action alerts, a blog, and a media center.

controlaccess.subject: Iraq War, 2003-2011 |x Protest movements |z United States.
Peace movements |z United States.
Women and peace |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Coffee Party is a democracy movement of citizens who recognize that the federal government is not the enemy of the people, but the expression of their collective will, and that people must participate in the democratic process in order to address the challenges that Americans face. The movement supports leaders who work toward positive solutions, and hold accountable those who obstruct them. The Coffee Party’s objective is to give a voice to Americans looking for a way to participate in the political process without adhering to any partisan or ideological framework. The website contains a blog and a book club.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Collapse Network, created in 2010, is a news desk that is the successor to both http://mikeruppert.blogspot.com/ and http://www.fromthewilderness.com/. Collapse Network features blog postings by Michael C. Ruppert and news updates on peak oil and other political issues. The website was also established to build sustainable communities throughout the world. Some articles and features on the website are pay to view only.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1998 as a print magazine, Colorlines.com is a daily news site offering reporting, analysis, and solutions to current racial justice issues.Colorlines.com is produced by a multiracial team of writers whose daily reporting and analysis serves as a voice on issues including politics, immigration reform, the economy and jobs. Other topics include pop culture and action alerts. Colorlines.com is published by the Applied Research Center (ARC) a racial justice think tank using media, research, and activism to promote solutions. ARC and Colorlines host the bi-annual Facing Race conference, a multi-racial gathering in the country for organizations and individuals committed to change.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: ColorOfChange.org works to strengthen Black America’s political voice, make government more responsive to the concerns to Black Americans and to bring about political and social change. ColorOfChange.org is comprised of Black Americans from every economic class, as well as those from all backgrounds who seek to help Black Americans be heard. Members are united to make sure all Americans are represented, served, and protected regardless of race or class.

Other documents and audio recordings of testimony for HVD can be found on the Detainee Affairs webpage of DefenseLint at: http://www.defenselink.mil/news/Combatant_Tribunals.html.

did.unittitle: Committee Against Anti-Asian Violence (CAAAV) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Committee Against Anti-Asian Violence (CAAAV) works to build grassroots community power across diverse poor and working class Asian immigrant and refugee communities in New York City. Through an organizing model constituted by five core elements- basebuilding, leadership development, campaigns, alliances, and organizational development- CAAAV organizes communities to fight for institutional change and participates in a broader movement towards racial, gender, and economic justice.

did.unittitle: Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism (U.S.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Committees on Correspondence was organized in 1992 after the 1991 Communist Party USA convention as a non-Leninist, democratic socialist organization to dispute the policies and leadership of CPUSA head, Gus Hall. The movement centered around veteran communist and former leading CP official, Gil Green (1906-1997). The Committees on Correspondence sought to reach out to others on the left outside the Party, and held conferences in 1992 and 1994 to formally establish the new organization. Around 2000, the Committee on Correspondence changed its name to the Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism. The website contains information on their conventions, publications, including their newsletter, the Mobilizer, by- laws, and other materials.

dao.ns2:title: Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism

daodesc.p: Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Common Cause is a nonpartisan, nonprofit advocacy organization founded in 1970 by John Gardner to give citizens a voice in the political process and hold elected leaders accountable. Common Cause focuses on campaign finance reform, election reform, ethics in government, government and media accountability, health care, and environmental and defense topics. They work to accomplish their goals through grassroots organizing, coalition building, research, policy development, public education, lobbying and litigation to win reform at all levels of government. The organization has 400,000 members and supporters and 35 state organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Common Courage Press, founded in 1991, publishes books for social justice and provides a platform for progressive ideas to spread to ordinary citizens and activists. They have sold over one million copies since their founding. Their authors include Noam Chomsky, Howard Zinn, Jean Bertrand Aristide, Jennifer Harbury, Philip Berrigan, Norman Solomon, Judi Bari, Sheldon Rampton and John Stauber, Physicians for National Health Care co-founders David Himmelstein and Steffie Woolhandler, Edward Said, Mike Males, Peter Breggin, Phyllis Chesler, and Paul Farmer. The website contains a search engine and listing of authors and book titles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: CommonDreams.org, founded in 1997 by Craig Brown and Lina Newhouser, is an activist organization that also publishes breaking news, ideas, opinions and in-depth analysis by progressive writers, thinkers and activists. CommonDreams advocates peace, equal opportunity, and works to bring activists together in an online community, and has millions of monthly readers.

did.unittitle: Common Struggle: Libertarian Communist Federation Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Common Struggle / Lucha Común is a bilingual (English and Spanish) organization of revolutionaries from the northeastern region of North America who identify with the communist tradition within anarchism. Common Struggle was founded in 1999 as Northeastern Federation of Anarchists Communists (NEFAC), and changed its name to Common Struggle Libertarian Communist Federation in 2011. Their work includes anti-war activism, international solidarity, prisoner support, workplace and community organizing, anti-fascist struggles, and anti-poverty work. The purpose of the federation is to connect local activity to a larger strategy of social revolution of a libertarian communist future. The website contains a newswire and their publications.

did.unittitle: Communist Party of Great Britain Bibliography Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Communist Party of Great Britain (CPGB) Bibliography was created in 2008 by David Cope, and documents the CPGB through primary and secondary source materials. The website contains a significant amount of material written on the CPGB, as well as materials produced by the CPGB, including national and local publications, national and local magazines, Young Communist League publications, and other documents. The website is a bibliography, and does not directly display documents, but provides the sources to those documents.

daodesc.p: Communist Party of Great Britain Bibliography

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Communist Party of the United States of America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA) is a Marxist-Leninist political organization that was founded in Chicago in 1919. The CPUSA played a pivotal role in many significant political and social movements of the 20th century. Its Party platform focused largely on working class issues such as fair wages and unemployment, civil rights for racial and ethnic minorities, civil liberties for politically persecuted communities, economic justice for the poor, the unemployed and for immigrants, and international peace efforts. The Party’s work left an indelible mark in the arena of progressive politics and made it an influential force in the labor movement, particularly from the 1920s to the 1940s. Its varied political, social, and cultural initiatives attracted the support of a number of prominent artists, intellectuals, and activists, including Woody Guthrie, Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, W.E.B. Du Bois, and Angela Davis. Though the CPUSA’s strength and size declined sharply following World War II and the advent of the Cold War and McCarthyism, it remains committed to socialism, peace, economic and social justice, and civil rights and liberties. Today, the CPUSA continues its struggle for socialism, peace, and social and economic justice, and publishes a newspaper, the People’s Weekly World (http://webarchives.cdlib.org/site/sw11834j9g), a monthly journal, Political Affairs (http://webarchives.cdlib.org/site/sw1r49hs90), and through its Labor Commission, the online periodical Labor Upfront (captured here: http://webarchives.cdlib.org/site/spec:0000000z7). The website contains a blog, event listings, action alerts, and other writings.

did.unittitle: Communities United for Police Reform Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Communities United for Police Reform is a campaign to end discriminatory policing practices in New York, and includes dozens of community organizations. Communities United for Police Reform was a key supporter of the Community Safety Act, a groundbreaking reform to the New York Police Department that was signed into law in 2014. The website includes news, resources, and campaign summaries.

daodesc.p: Communities United for Police Reform, Dec 10, 2014-ongoing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Community Voices Heard (CVH), founded in May 1994, is an organization of low-income people, predominantly women with experience on welfare, working to build power in New York City and State to improve the lives of member families and communities, including public education, grassroots organizing, leadership development, training low-income people about their rights, political education, civic engagement, and direct-action issue campaigns. They are currently working on welfare reform, job creation, public housing and other economic justice issues that affect low-income people, particularly low-income women of color. They publish reports on housing and other materials.

controlaccess.subject: Community organization |z New York (State) |z New York.

did.unittitle: Conference of Socialists Economists Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Conference of Socialists Economists (CSE) is an international, democratic membership organisation committed to developing a materialist critique of capitalism, unconstrained by conventional academic divisions between subjects. CSE has organised and supported conferences and seminars and since 1977 publishes Capital and Class three times a year. Capital and Class is a peer-reviewed, independent source for a Marxist critique of global capitalism, pioneering key debates on value theory, domestic labour, and the state, it reaches out into the labour, trade union, anti-racist, feminist, environmentalist and other radical movements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cooperative Village is a community of housing cooperatives on the Lower East Side of Manhattan sponsored, organized and built by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union, as well as the United Housing Foundation, a development organization set up by the unions in 1951. The Cooperative Village manages four smaller corporations, Hillman Housing Corporation, East River Housing Corporation, Seward Park Housing Corporation, and the Amalgamated Dwellings. The cooperatives followed strict Rochdale Principles, with one vote per member. The website contains information on cooperative services and the corporation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Cooper Square Committee (CSC), is a housing association of the Lower East Side, which works with area residents to contribute to the preservation and development of affordable, environmentally-friendly housing and community/cultural spaces. They provide housing and social services, including tenant counseling and eviction prevention; community and tenant organizing; social services and referrals; and community development. The website contains news updates, tenant rights resources, and project information.

controlaccess.subject: Low-income housing.
controlaccess.geogname: Lower East Side (New York, N.Y.) |x Social conditions.
controlaccess.subject: Tenants’ associations.

scopecontent.p: Cooper Union Student Action to Save our School, was a protest in the fall of 2012 to organize against the Board of Trustees and the Administration at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art charging tuition at the school for the first time in 110 years. The website contains news updates on the protests and actions by current students at the college.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Corporate Accountability International, originally founded in 1977 as Infant Formula Action Coalition, Infact, works to end corporate abuse by creating campaigns that safeguard public health, human rights, and the environment. They challenge the food industry, corporate control of water, the tobacco industry, and the weapons industry through mass mobilization, media visibility, shareholder activism, and participate in negotiations with regulatory agencies. The website contains their action campaigns, media center, and a blog.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Social responsibility of business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Corporate Action Network is a non-profit hub to support campaigns that work to expose, end, and prosecute corporate abuse. These abuses include wage equality, financial industry oversight, the environment, consumer rights, food safety, healthcare, and education. The organization partners with citizens and groups by providing value-added services, such as organizing strategy, technology tools, expert research techniques, litigation strategy, and additional online and grassroots strategic campaign advice to promote their campaigns. The website contains a listing of causes and news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: CorpWatch, launched in 1996, is a site that uses investigative research and journalism to monitor and expose corporate malfeasance and to advocate for corporate accountability and transparency. They work to foster global justice, independent media activism and democratic control over corporations and promote human, social, environmental, and workers rights. They publish investigative reports on their website and they are affiliated with Friends of the Earth International.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Counterpunch is a radical news web site, created by author and journalist Alexander Cockburn, and Jeffrey St.Clair. Counterpunch also publishes a bi-weekly print newsletter. The goal of CounterPunch is to publish stories that are ignored by mainstream media

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Courage to Resist is a group of veterans and military families that support military objectors to war and oppose U.S foreign policy. Through GI resistance, counter-recruitment, and draft resistance, Courage to Resist fights against war and occupation in Afghanistan, Iraq, and other countries. Courage to Resist is also focused on supporting public GI resisters. The website contains newsletters, news related to GI resisters, and action alerts.

did.unittitle: Crimes of War Project Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Crimes of War Project (established in 1999 as a private, non-profit corporation) is a collaboration of journalists, lawyers and scholars dedicated to raising public awareness of the laws of war and their application to situations of conflict. Their goal is to promote understanding of international humanitarian law among journalists, policymakers, and the general public, in the belief that a wider knowledge of the legal framework governing armed conflict will lead to greater pressure to prevent breaches of the law, and to punish those who commit them. They seek to raise raise the level of understanding about the law among those reporting on war and war crimes; provide information for journalists, scholars, and the policy community about critical issues in modern armed conflict; encourage wider appreciation of international law as a framework for understanding and responding to conflicts around the world; promote consultation among journalists, legal experts and humanitarian agencies about how to increase compliance with international humanitarian law; and provide a forum for accessible debate about the current state of international law. The website contains a glossary, commentary arranged by region, and other articles. The website last updated in 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: CrimethInc. Ex-Workers Collective (CWC), began in the mid-1990s, is a decentralized anarchist collective. CrimethInc. cells have published books, released records and organized national campaigns against globalization and representative democracy in favor of radical community organizing. The website contains their journal, Rolling Thunder, a reading library, videos, and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Critical Resistance is a national grassroots organization committed to ending the Prison Industrial Complex system, and the use of prisons and policing as an answer to social problems. They publish a blog called the Abolitionist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Critical Sociology is an organization of left sociologists, largely in the United States, and publishes a scholarly journal of the same name. The site principally consists of otherwise unpublished articles by members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cryptome, founded in 1996, functions as a repository for information about freedom of speech, cryptography, spying, and surveillance. Cryptome welcomes documents for publication that are prohibited by governments worldwide, in particular material on freedom of expression, privacy, cryptology, dual-use technologies, national security, intelligence, and secret governance—open, secret and classified documents—but not limited to those. Cryptome hosts documents, consisting of over 54,000 files, including suppressed photographs of U.S. soldiers killed in Iraq, lists of people believed to be MI6 agents, detailed maps of government facilities (based on publicly available mapping and aerial photography), and 4,000 photos of the Iraq War killed and maimed.

did.unittitle: Cuban American Alliance Education Fund Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Cuban American Alliance Education Fund, Inc. (CAAEF) is a nonprofit national network of Cuban Americans that educates the public on issues related to hardships resulting from United States-Cuba relations. The Alliance is a vehicle for the development of mutually beneficial engagements which promote understanding and human compassion. The website contains news and legislative updates, event listings, reader commentary, and gallery.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Center for Cuban Studies Cuban Art Space

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Cuban Art Space, located in New York City, was founded in 1999 as a part of the Center for Cuban Studies. The Space’s goal is to educate the U.S. public about Cuban art and culture, promote the work of Cuban artists and work toward the resumption of full educational and cultural exchanges between our two countries. The website holds an archive of current and past Cuban art exhibitions.

did.unittitle: Cypress Hills Local Development Corporation Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Cypress Hills Local Development Corporation (CHLDC), formed in May 1983, is a nonprofit community-based organization, serving approximately 8,000 residents per year through a comprehensive array of community service programs and neighborhood development projects in the Cypress Hills neighborhood in Brooklyn. Their mission is to revitalize the Cypress Hills community through housing preservation, economic development, and the positive development of youth and families. The website contains event and program listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Dumba Collective (1998-2006) was a non-profit arts collective in the Brooklyn NY, solely devoted to the contemporary art practices of the queer community. They offered space to local and international artists, primarily queer, and gave the majority of the profit back to the artist. The website was primarily a social networking one.

did.unittitle: Daily Kos: State of the Nation Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in May 26, 2002, (by Markos Moulitsas Zúniga), Daily Kos is an online political community that operates as a news organization and activist hub. The website receives 2.5 million unique visitors per month and contains 250,000 registered users. Notable users posting diary entries on the website include Jimmy Carter, Barack Obama, Harry Reid, Nancy Pelosi, Keith Olbermann, in addition to regular American users. The website offers blog posts, news articles, videos, and cartoons.

dao.ns2:title: Daily Kos: State of the Nation

daodesc.p: Daily Kos: State of the Nation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Daily Occupier is an online publication affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street movement. The writers are all citizen journalists who are also participants in the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website contains articles, coverage of actions, and analysis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Daisy Alliance is a grassroots peace organization seeking global security through nuclear nonproliferation, disarmament, and the elimination of all nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons of mass destruction. They raise funds to educate the public on WMDs and publish a newsletter and other materials. The website contains a blog, videos, and event listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Deep Dish TV was launched in 1986 by Paper Tiger TV as a distribution network, linking independent producers, programmers, community-based activists and viewers who support movements for social change and economic justice. The network has produced and distributed over 300 hours of television series that challenge the suppression of awareness, the corruption of language, and the perversion of logic that characterizes so much of corporate media. Deep Dish TV is committed to democratizing media by providing a national forum for programming created by community-based organizations and independent producers. Their programs are shown on over 200 public access cable stations around the country, on selected PBS stations, and received by thousands of satellite dish viewers nationwide on Free Speech TV channel 9415 on the DishNetwork and LinkTV on DirecTV.

did.unittitle: Deep Dish TV Waves of Change Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Waves of Change: The Many Voices of the Global Village is a multimedia project by Deep Dish Network designed to survey community media around the world by compiling and archiving the creative use of participatory communication globally. Waves of Change acts as a platform to share pieces that do not get seen outside of local coverage. The website includes an interactive map individual projects from their location on a world map and other media.

dao.ns2:title: Deep Dish TV Waves of Change

daodesc.p: Deep Dish TV Waves of Change

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2009, the National Committee to Defend Public Education is a loose coalition of students, workers, teachers, community members and activists working to build a national movement against austerity measures and cuts to public education. Defend Public Education supports rallies and other events, including a month of action in March.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Defenders for Freedom, Justice and Equality, founded in 2002, is an all-volunteer organization based in Richmond, Virginia that works to change the physical conditions of Virginia prisons, and other social justice initiatives in the Richmond area. The website features their projects, calendar, and other events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Demand Progress is a political organization that works to win progressive policy changes on issues of civil liberties, civil rights, and government reform through organizing, lobbying, and elections in the United States. Their main work is run through online campaigns to rally people to take action on the news by contacting Congress and other leaders, funding pressure tactics, and spreading the word in their own communities. The website contains a blog and campaign information.

did.unittitle: Demarcations Journal of Communist Theory and Polemic Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Demarcations: A Journal of Communist Theory and Polemic is a communist journal that contains revolutionary theory, Marxist thought, and applies communist theory on contemporary issues. The website contains articles. The last update was in 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Democracy for America (DFA), founded by Howard Dean, is a political action committee with over one million members nationwide working doe progressive change in the United States and the Democratic Party, in particular by supporting the nomination and electoral campaigns of progressive candidates. DFA provides campaign training, organizing resources, and media exposure so members have the power to support progressive issues and candidates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Democracy Now!: Radio and TV News, is a daily progressive, independently syndicated TV/radio news program, hosted by Amy Goodman and Juan Gonzalez, airing on over 750 stations. Began on WBAI, in New York City in 1996, the program is funded entirely through contributions from listeners, viewers, and foundations and does not accept advertisers, corporate underwriting, or government funding. Democracy Now! is the flagship program for Pacifica Radio network.

did.unittitle: Democratic Socialists of America Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Democratic Socialists of America (DSA) was founded in 1983 as the result of the Merger of the Democratic Socialist Organizing Committee, founded in 1973 by Michael Harrington (1928-1989). He led the DSA until his death, and the New American Movement, a New Left organization founded in the early 1970s. DSA is affiliated with the Socialist International. The party’s platform calls for reforms that weaken the influence of corporations in politics and give more power to working people. The website contains information on their campaigns and programs, which include student debt alleviation, immigrant rights, and the protection of social programs. The website also contains meeting minutes, chapter information, their publication, Democratic Left, their blog, Talking Union, their scholarship fund, and event listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Democratic Strategist, founded by William Galston, Stan Greenberg and Ruy Teixeira in 2006, is a monthly publication that believes that Democrats must begin to develop political strategies that look beyond the standard two- and four-year time horizons set by the American electoral calendar. Democrats must develop a set of concrete and coherent political strategies for regularly winning elections and over the longer term -- perhaps over a decade or more -- winning new areas of support and creating nothing less than a stable Democratic majority in the country. The Democratic Strategist also seeks to be a forum for discussion of long-term political strategy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Democratic Underground is a liberal newswire and discussion forum, founded in 2001. The website contains news, analysis, forums, discussion threads, and video and other multimedia.

did.unittitle: Democrats.com | The Aggressive Progressives! Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Democrats.com, founded in 2000 by Bob Fertik and David Lytel, is an independent community of Democratic Party and progressive activists. Democrats.com publishes news through a blog from the progressive base of the Democratic Party and acts as a community website for progressive Democrats. Democrats.com works to end wars and elect more progressive Democrats through campaigns and petitions. The email list of supporters consists of 635,000 users.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Design Action Collective, established in 2002, as an independent design and communications collective, formerly part of Inkworks Press Collective. Design Action provides graphic design and visual communications for progressive, non-profit and social change organizations. It is a worker-owned and managed cooperative and a union shop, affiliated with the Pacific Media Guild, Local 39521 Communication Workers of America, AFL-CIO. They are also active members of Graphic Alliance, the Network of Bay Area Worker Cooperatives, and the U.S. Federation of Worker Cooperatives.

did.unittitle: Despres, Schwartz, & Geoghegan, Ltd. Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Despres, Schwartz, & Geoghegan, Ltd. is a law firm that serves as counsel to legal counsel to unions, employees, and other plaintiffs who have had their rights as workers violated. They represent labor unions in cases for individual union members before federal courts and at arbitration; negotiating collective bargaining agreements, ensuring fair working conditions; and helping unions get started or organize employees at new companies. The firm also represents individuals in civil rights actions, whistle blowing, and consumer litigation. The website contains information about the lawyers in the firm, previous cases, and the history of the firm. This website was Thomas Geoghegan's personal website, which became the firm's site in 2014.

scopecontent.p: The FBI on January 2, 2007 released documents related to an internal inquiry in 2004 of FBI personnel who had served at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba since September 11, 2001 and had observed any aggressive interview techniques, interrogations, or mistreatment of detainees by representatives of law enforcement, the military, or the FBI. There were no documented incidents involving FBI personnel. These documents include summaries of what FBI personnel observed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Detention Watch Network, founded in 1997 by the Catholic Legal Immigration Network, Inc., the Florence Immigrant and Refugee Rights Project and Lutheran Immigration and Refugee Service, is a national member-led coalition that works to educate the public, media and policy makers about the U.S. immigration detention and deportation system and to advocate for reform. In February 2010, they launched their main campaign, Dignity Not Detention, which called for the restoration of fundamental human rights and due process in the U.S. immigration detention and deportation system and the repeal of mandatory detention. The website contains information on the campaign, a map of US detention centers, and a blog.

did.unittitle: Direct Action to Stop the War (San Francisco Bay Area) Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Direct Action to Stop the War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Direct Action to Stop the War was formed initially in 2003 to shutdown the San Francisco financial district, in protest of President Bush’s decision to attack Iraq. In 2008, the organization re-formed to hold a protest against the Iraq War. The organization continued holding demonstrations until 2009. The website contains information about the events and demonstrations, reports, and other promotional materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dissent Magazine, founded in 1954 by Irving Howe, is a quarterly leftist/social democratic intellectual magazine of politics and culture edited by Michael Kazin and Michael Walzer. Dissent’s website contains direct links to articles from current issues and back issues, a blog, online articles, videos, and topical issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Doctors for the 99% (D499) is a coalition of physician activists working in solidarity with the Occupy Wall Street movement. D499 calls attention to doctors’ roles as passive components of the United States’ healthcare system and calls for a change toward more affordable and equitable healthcare. The website contains a solidarity statement, action alerts, and other media.

did.unittitle: Dominion of New York Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dominion of New York, founded in 2011, is an online international magazine of black "intellectual swagger." The magazine goes beyond news headlines to profile, investigate and satirize thinkers, problems and ideas of significance to the African Diaspora. The website separates articles into different categories, which include politics, arts and culture, justice, history, humor, money, lifestyle, profiles, and memoir. The website also contains blogs.

origination.corpname: Fight for the Future and Center for Rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Don’t Let Our Right to Privacy Expire is a petition campaign to the Senate to update the Electronic Communications Privacy Act of 1986 to protect Fourth Amendment rights and uphold the integrity of law enforcement in the digital age. The website contains links to partner organizations, the petition letter, and a FAQ.

did.unittitle: DRUM Desis Rising Up and Moving Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Desis Rising up and Moving (DRUM), founded in 2000, is an organization of working class South Asian immigrants in New York City. DRUM works with families fighting deportation and supports South Asian low-income families and youth as well. They organize through political education and membership-led action for immigrant rights, racial, economic, and social justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early American Marxism is a repository of primary source Marxist materials dating from 1864-1946, collected by Tim Davenport. The website contains a historical background of significant groups established in the United States, including the First International, Language Federations, Socialist Labor Party, Socialist Party, Communist Party, Communist International, and other organizations. The primary resources are arranged by year, and summarized individually by Davenport.

dao.ns2:title: Early American Marxism: A Repository of Source Material, 1864-1946

daodesc.p: Early American Marxism: A Repository of Source Material, 1864-1946

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Earth First!, formed in 1979, is a international radical environmental movement created in response to the corporate environmental community. Earth First! supports different types of activism, including grassroots organizing, involvement in the legal process, and civil disobedience and monkeywrenching. Earth First!'s direct-action approach works to draw attention to the crises facing the natural world. Earth First! believes that life exists for its own sake, that industrial civilization and its philosophy are anti-Earth, anti-woman and anti-liberty. Earth First! has a quarterly online and print journal and a newswire.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ecoartivismo.net is a project of Fred Adam, Verónica Perales, and Andy Deck, known collectively as Transnational Temps. The project addresses environmental sustainability in the context of art and media activism. The website contains art projects and critique. The website is in Spanish and English.

did.unittitle: Econ-Atrocity / Econ-Utopia » Field Guide to the U.S. Economy Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Field Guide to the Economy website is the companion website to the book of the same title (by Jonathan Teller-elsberg, Nancy Folbre, James Heintz in 2006) The website, a collaborative effort of the Dancing Monkey Project and the Center for Popular Economics, is designed to develop economic literacy and encourage economic debate. The website has a blog called Econ-Atrocity, and a resources page, where they publish excerpts from the text and links to economic data.

dao.ns2:title: Econ-Atrocity / Econ-Utopia » Field Guide to the U.S. Economy

daodesc.p: Econ-Atrocity / Econ-Utopia » Field Guide to the U.S. Economy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The North American Earth Liberation Prisoners Support Network (NA-ELPSN), is the North American branch of the Earth Liberation Prisoners Support Network, which supports people accused or convicted of Earth and animal liberation activity, anti-nuclear activity, communities fighting development, peace action, indigenous resistance, anti-fascist actions. The website contains news on prisoners, a listing of prisoners supported by the network, resources, and ways to support prisoners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Ecosocialist Contingent is a grouping of socialist organizations and supporters, dedicated to fighting global warming and its chief cause, capitalism. The websites contains their manifesto, conferences, and news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ecosocialist Horizons seeks to advance ecosocialism as a world-view and as a movement capable of offering real answers to the crises caused by capitalism. They work to providing news and analysis of ecosocialist concern through a multi-media website and other publications, to educate members to produce creative work and to organize events, actions, and convergences to advance diverse struggles towards an ecosocialist horizon. The ecosocialist movement aims to stop and to reverse the process of global warming in particular and of capitalist ecocide in general, and to construct a radical and practical alternative to the capitalist system. The website contains sections on the economic crisis, the food crisis, and global warming. It also contains event listings and articles.

did.unittitle: Education for Liberation Network Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Education for Liberation Network, established in 1999, is a national coalition of teachers, community activists, researchers, youth and parents who educate low-income youth and youth of color to work for social justice by taking action in local communities to empower students. The network primarily functions as a listserv, but also contains a database of education materials, and projects page.

did.unittitle: Education for Peace in Iraq Center Archived Website

origination.corpname: Education for Peace in Iraq Center

scopecontent.p: Founded in 1998, EPIC: Promoting a Free and Secure Iraq works to improve human rights and humanitarian conditions in Iraq. EPIC works through educational programs and advocacy initiatives to stabilize Iraq by supporting Iraqi efforts to advance peace and development on the ground. The website contains news and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Education Notes provides news on current education issues and organizing activities for fighting for public education in cities throughout the United States. Education Notes was founded in 1996 as a monthly newsletter published by Norm Scott that transformed into a blog in 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), founded in 1990, is a civil liberties group that defends users’ rights in the digital world. EFF uses lawyers, policy analysts, activists, and technologists on behalf of consumers and the general public. EFF fights for freedom primarily in the courts, bringing and defending lawsuits and mobilizations. In addition to advising policymakers, EFF educates the press and public. EFF’s issues are defending free speech, privacy, innovation, and consumer rights. The website also contains a blog and campaign page.

did.unittitle: Encyclopedia of Trotskyism On-Line (ETOL) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encyclopedia of Trotskyism On-Line (ETOL) is a resource for the study of the international Trotskyist movement. It includes a "tree" of U.S. Trotskyist organizations, a list of pseudonyms, historical documents, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Environmental News Network (ENN), established in 1997, is a news wire dedicated to presenting news on worldwide environmental issues and promotes discussion between readers. In addition to publishing the website, they offer rss feeds and distribute a daily e-newsletter to 36,000 environmental readers. The website features sections on environmental policy, climate, energy, green building, pollution, ecosystems, wildlife, agriculture, and science and technology. The website also features original news stories and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Equal Justice USA, founded in 1990, is a national, grassroots organization working to build a criminal justice system that is fair, effective, and humane, starting with repealing the death penalty, increasing services for families of homicide victims, and refocusing resources towards criminal justice policies that reduce crime and support victims. They partner with state organizations to provide training and leadership development, and free consulting to build grassroots campaign. The website contains action alerts and news.

did.unittitle: Eugene V. Debs Foundation Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Eugene V. Debs Foundation was founded in 1962 to preserve the Debs home and open it as a museum for the public, as well as act as a repository for Debs’ papers and other artifacts. The Foundation also administers an award yearly to an individual that embodies "the spirit of progressivism, humanitarianism, and social criticism by Eugene V. Debs." The website also contains their biannual newsletter, a biography of Debs, information about the museum, and their essay contest.

did.unittitle: Experimental Party Disinformation Center Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Experimental Party Disinformation Center: Anarchic Entertainment for the Nation!The Experimental Party is an initiative of the "US Department of Art and Technology." A website active in 2004-2005 concerned with protesting the nomination, election, and inauguration of George W. Bush as President of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: F (Foreclose) the Banks, is an action campaign by Occupy Wall Street activists, which is working to end corporate and bank power in the United States. The website contains information on action campaigns and informational materials.

did.unittitle: Fairness & Accuracy in Reporting Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: FAIR (Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting), a national media watch group, has been offering criticism of media bias and censorship since 1986. FAIR advocates greater diversity in the press, structural reform in the media, and works to expose neglected news stories. FAIR publishes Extra!, a magazine of media criticism, and produces the weekly radio program CounterSpin. In addition, they have a listserv through which they distribute regular action alerts to their international network of activists.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Fair Vote: The Center for Voting and Democracy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: FairVote is an organization that acts to reform the elections process to achieve universal access to participation, a national popular vote for president, constitutionally protected right to vote, universal voter registration, instant runoff voting, and proportional voting. To achieve these goals, FairVote acts as a traditional think tank through research, analysis, educational resources and conferences, and also engages with leading reformers, thought leaders and the media to turn new ideas into widely accepted policy options.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Federal CURE, Inc (FedCURE) works as an advocate for the federal inmate population. FedCURE also raises awareness of the issues confronted by the federal inmate population. Their work includes reinstating parole; increasing good time allowances; providing for compassionate releases; restoring PELL grants; and creating opportunities for successful reentry into the community, for all federal offenders; and promoting a system that incarcerates fewer people and provides humane conditions for those who are incarcerated or under post-incarceration supervision via parole or supervised release. The website contains news postings, action alerts, and a chapters list.

did.unittitle: Federal Bureau of Investigation - Guantanamo Bay Investigation Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: United States. Federal Bureau of Investigation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains a survey of 493 Federal Bureau of Investigation personnel asking whether they observed aggressive mistreatment, interrogations or interview techniques at the Guantanamo Bay Detention Camp.

daodesc.p: Federal Bureau of Investigation - Guantanamo Bay Investigation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1915, The Fellowship of Reconciliation (FOR) holds programs and educational projects concerned with domestic and international peace and justice, nonviolent alternatives to conflict, and the rights of conscience in opposition to warfare. FOR promotes nonviolence and has members from many religious and ethnic traditions. It is a part of the International Fellowship of Reconciliation (IFOR), which has affiliates in over 40 countries. The website contains information on campaigns, events, and delegations. The website also has a multimedia page and a blog.

daodesc.p: Fellowship of Reconciliation Archived Website, May 8, 2008-ongoing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: FeministCampus.org was created by the Feminist Majority Foundation (FMF) to inform young feminists on college campuses about threats to abortion access, women’s rights, affirmative action, and lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender rights. FMF works with students on college campuses to effect change at the grassroots, national, and global levels. The Campus Program is built upon FMF’s philosophy that the most effective activism is informed activism, or study to action. Their program provides progressive students with opportunities to learn about feminist issues, develop their leadership and organizing skills, and connect with the larger pro-choice and feminist movements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Feministe is a feminist blog. The website features multiple different authors and guest-bloggers. The website features blog posts and analysis on race, women’s health, parenthood, politics, a book club, and other articles on feminist issues. The website also promotes its commenting community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Website documenting the Black Lives Matter movement following the police murders of Mike Brown and Eric Garner in 2014. The website includes listings for actions, movement demands, and resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This site was originally created to list actions across the United States organized in response to the Ferguson, MO grand jury decision in the killing of unarmed African-American teenager Mike Brown in 2014. The website later expanded to list other events pertaining to police brutality, racial injustice, and the Black Lives Matter movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fifth Avenue Committee, Inc. (FAC), established in 1978, is a community organization in South Brooklyn that advances economic and social justice. FAC develops and manages affordable housing and community facilities, creates economic opportunities and ensures access to economic stability, organizes residents and workers, offers student-centered adult education, and combats displacement caused by gentrification. The website contains information on their programming and event listings.

did.unittitle: Fight For The Future Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fight for the Future is a non-profit that helps organize strikes and petitions against web censorship. The website features petitions against the SOPA and PIPA censorship bills and other petitions and other campaigns.

did.unittitle: Fight Imperialism Stand Together Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fight Imperialism Stand Together (FIST) is a national youth revolutionary group affiliated with the Workers World Party, a Marxist-Leninist communist organization of Trotskyist provenance. The organization advocates for the equality of race, sex, orientation, and the working class. The website contains news listings and their blog. The site last updated in 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fighting Bob, founded in 2003, is an online opinion magazine named for Robert La Follette (1855–1925), a populist governor, U.S. Senator, and presidential candidate from Wisconsin who founded the Progressive Party. The website publishes opinion articles on mostly Wisconsin issues not covered by mainstream media. The editor is Ed Garvey.

did.unittitle: FirstGameWorld.Com: Occupy Wall Street Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Website that aggregates news articles about Occupy Wall Street

did.unittitle: First Voices Indigenous Radio (FVIR) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: First Voices Indigenous Radio: A Voice for Indigenous Issues, Concerns, Cultures and Customs (FVIR), is a weekly radio program broadcast on WBAI FM (New York, N.Y.) that gives a voice to Indigenous peoples worldwide (with a focus on North American Indigenous groups) to share their experiences, perspectives, and struggles. FVIR’s purpose is to ensure the continuance and survival of Indigenous cultures and Nations through. FVIR also works to educate by breaking down stereotypes. The program, hosted by Tiokasin Ghosthorse, airs on Thursday mornings at 9 AM.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Flood Wall Street was organized as a response to the call for non- violent direct action following the People's Climate March in 2014. On September 22nd, 2014, hundreds of people conducted a sit-in on Broadway in lower Manhattan, resulting in the arrest of over 100 people. The action sought to hold corporations and banks accountable for their role in creating the climate crisis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 4closure Fraud is a website designed to help people fight foreclosure through awareness and legal action. The website contains depositions, information on foreclosure laws, a news blog, a links page, and the website’s radio show.

controlaccess.subject: Foreclosure. Mortgages. Social responsibility in banking.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Frack Action is an action group that campaigns against the hydraulic fracturing (fracking). Fracking is the process of initiating and subsequently propagating a fracture in a rock layer, by means of a pressurized fluid, in order to release petroleum, natural gas, coal seam gas, or other substances for extraction. Frack Action works to raise awareness, expose false claims of the gas industry, and mobilize to protect the environment and public health from the environmental consequences of fracking.

did.unittitle: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Roosevelt Institute, founded in 1987, is a progressive non-profit organization devoted to carrying forward the legacy and values of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt by developing ideas and leadership to promote the United States’ health and security. The website features their Four Freedoms think tank and their Campus Network and Pipeline campaigns, which works to create young progressive leaders that promote the Institute’s values. The website also features information on the FDR presidential library and their Next New Deal blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Free Culture Foundation, formerly Students for Free Culture (found in Tamiment’s Education and Student Movements web archive), is an organization with the goal to end the private ownership over media, ideas, and technology; promote the advancement of free software, formats, and works; raise consciousness of intellectual property; and defend against privacy threats. The organization works through supporting local and student chapters, providing educational resources, organizing direct action campaigns, and sponsoring events and other projects. The website contains a blog, projects, volunteering opportunities, and resources.

did.unittitle: Freedom Road Socialist Organization Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Freedom Road Socialist Organization/Organicion Socialista del Camino Para la Libertad (FRSO/OSCL) was founded in 1985 when two small organizations, Proletarian Unity League (PUL) and the Revolutionary Workers Headquarters (RWH) merged. They are a network of revolutionary organizers that work to fight white supremacist capitalism. They work in the Black and Chicano movements and various immigrants’ struggles, and in labor unions, workers centers and labor/community groups and coalitions. The website contains information on their platform and news and analysis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Freedom Socialist Party (FSP) was founded in 1966 by former members of the Socialist Workers Party. The party is a revolutionary, socialist feminist organization, dedicated to the replacement of capitalist rule by a genuine workers’ democracy that will guarantee full economic, social, political, and legal equality to women, people of color, gays, and all who are exploited, oppressed, and repelled by imperialism. The website contains their publication, Freedom Socialist, their platform, and information on their affiliates and chapters.

daodesc.p: Freedom Socialist Party Archived Website, Feb 22, 2007-Dec 22, 2008

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Freegan.info website was created in 2003 as a project of the Activism Center at Wetlands Preserve in New York City. The website has evolved to offer a monthly calendar of local freegan skill share, discussion, a dumpster directory, links page, and social events. The website also works to support and connect the New York City branch with other Freegan groups throughout the world. Freeganism is an anti-consumerist lifestyle by people who employ alternative strategies for living based on limited participation in the conventional economy and minimal consumption of resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Free Press is a national, nonpartisan, nonprofit organization working to reform the media. Through education, organizing and advocacy, they promote diverse and independent media ownership, strong public media, and universal access to communications. Free Press was launched in late 2002 by media scholar Robert W. McChesney and Josh Silver. As of 2012 Free Press has nearly half a million activists and members and a full-time staff of more than 40. The website contains information on campaigns, education and research, and has related news content.

controlaccess.subject: Freedom of speech |z United States.
Freedom of the press |z United States
Mass media criticism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Free Speech TV, launched in 1995, is an independent, publicly-supported TV multi platform digital media service that works to build an equitable and sustainable society. In 2000, Free Speech TV launched the first national progressive television network when it was awarded a full-time satellite channel on DISH Network as a result of an FCC policy to set aside 4% of satellite channels for public interest channels. Free Speech TV is based in Denver, CO and is produced by Public Communicators Inc., founded in 1974. Promoting voices and perspectives under-represented in the media, Free Speech TV broadcasts independently-produced programs addressing social, political, cultural, and environmental issues, and produced the SourceCode series (2004-2007).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Free the Media is an autonomous network and cultural think tank whose purpose is to reclaim public space on the net and preserve free speech, privacy and access for all The website is made up of artists, activists, and technologists working collectively to create self-sustainable infrastructures and open source software tools that enable access and the free exchange of information in the digital world. The website also is a platform for exchange of ideas and issues that are put into action through live events and actions.

did.unittitle: Free University New York City Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Free University of New York City, first established May 2012, is an radical education movement that offers free education in open spaces in New York City. Their aim is to reform education to make it more accessible to those who cannot afford higher education. They view their education program as a direct action against the current, capitalist education system and work to democratize and radicalize education. The website contains information on their latest actions, their working group, and multimedia.

did.unittitle: Friends of the Earth International Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friends of the Earth International, founded in 1971, is an international environmental network, made up of 76 national member groups and some 5,000 local activist groups with over two million members worldwide. The federation promotes environmental and social justice, an environmentally sustainable society, and challenges globalization. Some of FOEI’s issues are an anti-agrofuels campaign, resisting oil and gas production, and deforestation. The website contains a blog with news updates on the organization and a resources page, which contains a link to their radio station, Real World Radio, also captured and their publications, including annual reports.

did.unittitle: From The Wilderness: Information on Peak Oil, Sustainablility, and the events surrounding 9/11 Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: FromTheWilderness.com was a website created by Michael C. Ruppert, an investigative journalist and a peak oil theorist. The website, established in 1998, also published a newsletter from 1998 to 2006, which covered political and governmental issues. The website was updated on a daily basis with articles regarding peak oil and other news and political articles. The website stopped operating in 2006, and moved to http://mikeruppert.blogspot.com/. Currently, Ruppert’s website is http://www.collapsenet.com.

dao.ns2:title: From The Wilderness: Information on Peak Oil, Sustainablility, and the events surrounding 9/11

daodesc.p: From The Wilderness: Information on Peak Oil, Sustainablility, and the events surrounding 9/11

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The GAIA International Festival for the Future of the Sea and the Earth took place from the 19th to the 27th June, 2010 in Calabria and Basilicata, Italy. The conference was an international gathering to address social and ecological problems affecting the environment. The event included forums, workshops, the Gaiart and Video International Festival, art exhibitions, and other entertainment to raise awareness and engage in many environmental related topics including economic localization, language for a transition to a sustainable world, renewable energy, slow food, climate change, waste-reduction/land-conservation, biodiversity, water issues, and social justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Generation Progress, formerly Campus Progress, is a national organization that works with and for "Millennials" to promote progressive solutions to key political and social challenges, with a special emphasis on access and other issues related to college education. They do this work through journalism, policy research, and collaboration. The organization focuses on issues including student debt, healthcare, immigration, gun violence, voting rights, gay rights, climate change, and civic engagement. The website contains news reports, activism tools, and action alerts.

did.unittitle: George Polk Awards in Journalism Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: George Polk Awards In Journalism (Long Island University)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The George Polk Awards in Journalism, established in 1949, are a series of journalism awards presented annually by Long Island University in New York. Polk, a CBS correspondent, was murdered during a Greek civil war while trying to reach the guerrilla leader Markos Vafiades for an interview. The circumstances of his death, and the investigations that were conducted following the discovery of his body in Salonika Bay, are matters of continuing speculation and controversy. The website lists the winners of the award, gives details on the nomination process, and gives information on the yearly Polk seminar. Note: The Tamiment Library, NYU holds the papers of the Newsmen's Committee to Investigate the Murder of George Polk, and a collection of papers of George Polk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Get Greener is an environmental activism website, founded by Andy Deck. The website provides links to environmental web projects, links to environmental activists and activism websites, news, and greenwashing (a form of spin in which green marketing is deceptively used to promote the perception that a company's policies or products are environmentally friendly).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Get Peaceful, created by artist Andy Deck, hosts the Anti-War Web Ring and Directory, which was formed in 2002 in an effort to coordinate opposition to the Iraq War. The website has a listing of resources, art projects, documentaries, satires, exhibitions, blogs, and other projects related to the ant-war movement. The website contains links to two of Deck’s projects, AntiWar404, the Surge Cycle.

controlaccess.subject: Iraq War, 2003-2011 |x Protest movements |z United States.
Peace movements |z United States.
Web portals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Global Exchange, founded in 1988, is an international human rights organization and resource center dedicated to promoting social, economic and environmental justice and educating the U.S. public about root causes of injustice and the impacts of U.S. government policies and corporate practices. The website contains information on their programs, reality travel tours, event listings, and news updates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Global Information Network (GIN) is an independent non-profit news organization headquartered in New York and specializing in disseminating news from reporters in the field in Africa, Latin America, Asia and other regions through its partnership with the Inter Press Service. It supplies news, analysis and features with a developing world perspective to ethnic and minority newsweeklies nationwide. Its stories have appeared in print, broadcast and web media in the United States for more than 20 years. Customers pay for stories by the month or per story, visitors cannot read full stories without an account.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Global May was initially established in 2013 to hold an international day of solidarity and actions on May 1, 2013. Actions included demonstrations, assemblies, workshops, conferences, flash mobs and other actions in open spaces in cities. The website contains information on individual cities’ actions. As of this writing, the website uses a social media aggregating service, RebelMouse, to bring together news and actions from global left actions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Global Revolution.TV is the main website of the Occupy Wall Street livestream broadcast and also brings video and news coverage of other "occupy" protests around the world. The team includes members of Mobile Broadcast News, Glassbead Collective, Twin Cities Indymedia and other independent journalists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Global Voices was founded in 2005 by Rebecca MacKinnon and Ethan Zuckerman. The website consists of news postings from ore than 500 bloggers and translators from blogs and citizen media throughout the world that is not emphasized by mainstream media. The website is also host to the Lingua project, which brings together volunteer translators to translate Global Voices. They also have an outreach program called Rising Voices.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: GOLES (Good Old Lower East Side) is a neighborhood housing and preservation organization that has served the Lower East Side of Manhattan since 1977. They are dedicated to tenants’ rights, homelessness prevention, economic development, and community revitalization. The website contains information on services, training, organizing, and news posting.

controlaccess.subject: Low-income housing.
controlaccess.geogname: Lower East Side (New York, N.Y.) |x Social conditions.

did.unittitle: Grand Rapids Institute for Information Democracy Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Grand Rapids Institute for Information Democracy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Grand Rapids Institute for Information Democracy (GRIID) was formed in 1998 in response the growing influence of the corporate media. GRIID acts as a media watchdog of the news in West Michigan and reports on how mainstream media does report accurately on critical issues like war, race, gender, health, the environment, consumerism, and elections. GRIID teaches and works with community and student groups on media literacy, and produces news stories, interviews and short documentaries.

dao.ns2:title: Grand Rapids Institute for Information Democracy

daodesc.p: Grand Rapids Institute for Information Democracy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Granny Peace Brigade is an anti-war demonstration group in New York City made up of senior citizens. They oppose war, occupation, rendition and torture, and the violence of poverty and racism. The website contains news, a blog, action alerts, resources, and information on their campaigns.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Graphic Witness: Visual Arts and Social Commentary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Graphic Witness was a site (last updated 11/7/2008) dedicated to social commentary through the presentation of graphic imagery by artists working from the turn of the 20th Century to the present, with related biographic data.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Graphix4change is an artistic and educational project designed to promote social and political change through the use of design and satire. The goal of graphix4change is to subvert everyday consumer images into a commentary on the current state of politics in America and the world. It is completely self-funded and does not rely on corporate advertising. Most files on the website are satirical images.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Grassroots Education Movement to Defend Public Education

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Grassroots Education Movement (GEM) educates and organizes educators, parents, students, and communities to defend public education. GEM works to stop privatization of schools, advocates equality and quality of public education services and rights for teachers and school workers. GEM also works to limit charter schools, supports teacher union rights, works to end the focus on high-stakes standardized testing and school closures, and raise awareness of racism and inequality in schools.

did.unittitle: Grassroots Global Justice Alliance Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Grassroots Global Justice is an alliance of U.S.-based grassroots groups who are organizing to build an agenda for power for working and poor people and building a popular movement for peace, democracy and a sustainable world. The website operates as a portal to connect grassroots leaders by creating spaces for dialogue and strategic thinking and educates on global political and economic forces that cause poverty, conflict, and environmental destruction. Issues and agendas are developed by and for working-class people, poor people, indigenous people and communities of color for global justice. The website contains tools for mobilization and also contains information of campaigns.

did.unittitle: Grassroots Immigrant Justice Network Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Grassroots Immigrant Justice Network works to promote community dialogue on immigrant rights issues, labor issues, and immigration reform and is formed by leaders in the immigrant rights and labor movements across the country who believe that the immigration system must be based on human rights, not on increased enforcement measures, militarization of the border, and the criminalization of immigrant workers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Gray Panthers, founded in 1970 by Maggie Kuhn and friends, all of whom were retiring from national religious and social work organizations, to discuss the common problems faced by retirees — loss of income, loss of contact with associates and loss of one of our society's most distinguishing social roles, one's job. The organization has expanded, and also supports a single-payer system of health-care, as well as an increase in welfare payments, supporting peace activity, lifelong public education, the rights of workers, reproductive rights, abolition of the death penalty, legalization of same-sex marriage, the legalization of medical marijuana, and environmental activities through advocacy, education and action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Green Anarchy, established in 2007, features news on anarchism and environmentalism.

did.unittitle: Green Party of New York State Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This is the website for the Green Party of New York State collective. It contained information on local caucuses, issues, and event listings.

did.unittitle: Green Party of the United States Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Green Party of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Green Party of the United States is a federation of state Green Parties. It was formed in 2001 as a successor to the older Association of State Green Parties (1996-2001). The Green Party is affiliated with the European Federation of Green Parties and the Federation of Green Parties of the Americas. The Green Party’s goals include environmentalism, non-hierarchical participatory democracy, social justice, and respect for diversity, peace and nonviolence. The website contains news, election results, and organizational information.

dao.ns2:title: Green Party of the United States

daodesc.p: Green Party of the United States

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Green Party Watch is a newswire website that contains news and analysis on the Green Party on the local and national level. The website contains information on Green Party candidates and event listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Greenwich House, founded in 1902 by Mary Kingsbury Simkhovitch, is a social settlement house in the Greenwich Village section of New York City. Initially founded to help New York’s immigrant populations adjust to life in a new country. The organization by offers social and health services, cultural and educational programs, and opportunities for civic involvement to New Yorkers of all ages and backgrounds, including a chemical dependency program, classes in music and pottery, a nursery, and a senior center.

did.unittitle: Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation, founded in 1980, works to preserve the architectural heritage and cultural history of Greenwich Village, the East Village, and NoHo. They do their work through educational outreach, school programs, preservation projects, and consultation services. The website contains event listings, accomplishments, and a blog.

dao.ns2:title: Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation

daodesc.p: Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation
