origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Guernica: A Magazine of Art and Politics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Guernica, founded in 2004, is a biweekly site that publishes poetry, fiction, art and photography from around the world, along with investigative and opinion pieces on international affairs and U.S. domestic policy. It also publishes interviews and profiles of artists, writers, musicians and political figures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Guerrilla Girls are an anonymous group of feminists devoted to fighting against sexism within the visual fine art world. Started in New York City in 1985 to protest gender and racial inequality in the art world, members are known for the gorilla masks they wear to keep their anonymity, as well as for taking pseudonyms of dead women artists. The website lists their art projects, videos, lectures and appearances, exhibitions, and action projects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Guerrilla News Network is an independent news organization with headquarters in New York City and production facilities in Berkeley, California. Our mission is to expose people to important global issues through cross-platform guerrilla programming.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Haiti Grassroots Watch operates as a "watchdog" website which produces text, video, and audio content on the aid and reconstruction of Haiti from the point of view of the Haitian majority. The website provides updates and critique on the reconstruction efforts, as well as structural causes and challenges. Haiti Grassroots Watch is a collaboration of two Haitian grassroots media organizations, Groupe Medialternatif/Alterpresse and the Society for the Animation of Social Communication (SAKS), along with two networks – the network of women community radio broadcasters (REFRAKA) and the Association of Haitian Community Media (AMEKA), which is comprised of community radio stations located across Haiti.

did.unittitle: HARLEM FIGHTBACK AGAINST WAR AT HOME & ABROAD Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Harlem Fightback Against War at Home and Abroad is a Harlem based protest group. The website is their blog highlighting action alerts.

dao.ns2:title: HARLEM FIGHTBACK AGAINST WAR AT HOME & ABROAD

daodesc.p: HARLEM FIGHTBACK AGAINST WAR AT HOME & ABROAD

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Havaar is a grassroots initiative founded by Iranians, Iranian-Americans, and allies to oppose all military action, United States led sanctions against Iran, and state repression. They work to find non-violent solutions to improve the lives of Iranians. The website contains their statement of principles and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Haymarket Books is a nonprofit, progressive book distributor and publisher and a project of the Center for Economic Research and Social Change. The website contains category listings, upcoming books, event listings, and news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Healthcare for the 99%, an Occupy Wall Street working group, is a group of community members, health activists, and health workers who see healthcare as a human right and advocate for a universal publicly-funded system that guarantees affordable and comprehensive healthcare. The working group does this through educational programming and political activism at the local, state, and national levels. The website contains news listings.

did.unittitle: Highlander Research and Education Center Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Highlander Research and Education Center was created in1932 (as the Highlander Folk School) by Myles Horton and Don West in Grundy County, Tennessee, to serve as a grassroots organizing and movement building organization in Appalachia and the South that supported racial justice and the labor movement. They work with people fighting for economic and social justice, against environmental degradation. Through popular education, participatory research, and cultural work Highlander works to give people the ability to develop leadership and help create and support strong, democratic organizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Holt Labor Library is a labor and radical history library that serves the labor, academic, and activist communities, established in 1992.Their goal is to provide a working library for labor and progressive studies accessible to the general public. Their collection includes 4500 books on labor and socialist history and Marxist theory, 3000 pamphlets, 80 subscriptions to labor and left periodicals, multimedia collection including videos, DVDs, audio tapes, and CDs, posters and other ephemera, papers related to socialist history in the United States, socialist and labor newspapers, and the personal archives of Fair Play for Cuba Committee, Anti-Vietnam War organizations, Teamsters for a Democratic Union, Committee to Aid the Monroe Defendants, and others. The website includes a catalog, their Luis digital exhibit, and library news.

did.unittitle: Home Is Where The Vote Is Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Home is Where the Vote Is, a project of the organization the New Bottom Line, was a campaign designed to reach out to candidates Barack Obama and Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential election to fix the housing crisis and provide aid to people whose homes are "underwater." (Underwater refers to the home having a mortgage loan larger than its market value.) The campaign called for the resettlement of mortgages to fair market value. The website features a blog, action alerts, and information on states most affected by the crisis.

dao.ns2:title: Home Is Where The Vote Is

daodesc.p: Home Is Where The Vote Is

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Housing Conservation Coordinators is a not-for-profit organization based in Clinton/Hell's Kitchen that seeks to preserve safe and affordable housing, advance social and economic justice, and fight for the rights of poor, low-income and working individuals and families. They provide services such as legal representation, tenant and community organizing, installation of energy efficient systems through their Weatherization Program, and technical training courses. The website contains information on legal and community services.

did.unittitle: Housing is a Human Right Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Housing is a Human Right is a multimedia project to record people’s experiences trying to obtain or maintain housing. The website contains stories in many multimedia forms, including audio recordings, videos, and written accounts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Housing Works is an organization and community that works to end homelessness and HIV/AIDS through advocacy, the provision of services, and entrepreneurial businesses, including thrift shops and cafes. The website contains information on HIV/AIDS advocacy and news, services, and event listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: HowToOccupy (also known as HowToCamp) is a website designed in order to promote the methods, techniques, and knowledge used in the Occupy Wall Street movement. It aims to teach grassroots practices for economic change; including techniques on civil disobedience, legal advice, web tools, camping, dealing with the police, and other tools.

did.unittitle: Hudson River Sloop Clearwater Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, founded in 1966 by musician and environmental activist Pete Seeger, seeks to preserve and protect the Hudson River and surrounding wetlands and waterways through advocacy, environmental action and public education. The organization is known for its sailing vessel, the sloop Clearwater, and for its annual music and environmental festival, the Great Hudson River Revival.

did.unittitle: I Am Mike Brown Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Collected livestream coverage of protests and events following the murder of unarmed African-American teenager Mike Brown by Darren Wilson, a Ferguson, MO police officer in 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Precursor to the We are the 99% tumblr blog. Contains media, photographs, and art related to the Occupy Wall Street movement.

scopecontent.p: iCausalities contains statistics lists military casualties of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. The website also contains news relating to the wars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Immigrant Solidarity Network (NISN) is a coalition of immigrant rights, labor, human rights, religious, and student activist organizations from across the United States. The network organizes action and letter-writing campaigns and publishes immigration related news and organizes conferences and mobilizations.

did.unittitle: INCITE: Women of Color Against Violence Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Incite! Women of Color Against Violence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: INCITE! Women of Color Against Violence is a national activist organization of radical feminists of color advancing a movement to end violence against women of color and communities through direct action, critical dialogue and grassroots organizing. INCITE! develops political projects and engage in strategies and projects that address both personal and state violence, including a radio show, rallies, training in self-defense, building and running a grassroots clinic, engagement in media justice and supporting communities to engage in community. The website contains resources, a newsletter, merchandise, and a forum.

did.unittitle: In Defence of Marxism Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is the website of the International Marxist Tendency, a Trotskyist organization, with roots in Great Britain.

did.unittitle: Independence Plaza North Tenant Association Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Independence Plaza North Tenant Association (IPNTA) is the tenant association of the Independence Plaza building complex in Tribeca. The association provides help with landlord/tenant issues, advocates and protects tenants during emergency situations, and works within the community on services and improvements. The website contains news and settlement agreements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Independent Media Center was established by independent and alternative media organizations and activists in 1999 for the purpose of providing independent coverage of the World Trade Organization (WTO) protests in Seattle. After the WTO protests, it expanded into a collective of independent media organizations and hundreds of journalists offering independent, non-corporate coverage. There are currently over one hundred and fifty Independent Media Centers around the world. Each IMC is an autonomous group that has its own mission statement, manages its own finances and makes its own decisions through its own processes.

did.unittitle: Informed Comment: Thoughts on the Middle East, History and Religion Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Juan Cole is Richard P. Mitchell Collegiate Professor of History at the University of Michigan. For three decades, he has sought to put the relationship of the West and the Muslim world in historical context. His most recent book is Engaging the Muslim World (Palgrave Macmillan, March, 2009) and he also recently authored Napoleon’s Egypt: Invading the Middle East (Palgrave Macmillan, 2007). He has been a regular guest on PBS’s Lehrer News Hour, and has also appeared on ABC Nightly News, Nightline, the Today Show, Charlie Rose, Anderson Cooper 360, Countdown with Keith Olbermann, Rachel Maddow, the Colbert Report, Democracy Now! and many others. He has written about Egypt, Iran, Iraq, and South Asia. He has commented extensively on al-Qaeda and the Taliban, the Iraq War, the politics of Pakistan and Afghanistan, and Iranian domestic struggles and foreign affairs. He has a regular column at Truthdig. He continues to study and write about contemporary Islamic movements, whether mainstream or radical, whether Sunni and Salafi or Shi`ite. Cole speaks Arabic, Persian and Urdu and reads some Turkish, knows both Middle Eastern and South Asian Islam.

dao.ns2:title: Informed Comment: Thoughts on the Middle East, History and Religion

daodesc.p: Informed Comment: Thoughts on the Middle East, History and Religion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inkworks Press, established in 1974, is an ecologically and socially conscious offset printer offering green printing services. They print booklets, posters, postcards, flyers, brochures, business suites, envelopes and other media. Inkworks is organized as a democratically run worker collective. Inkworks Press is a worker collective associated with the Network of Bay Area Worker Cooperatives and the United States Federation of Worker Cooperatives.

did.unittitle: Institute for Anarchist Studies Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Institute for Anarchist Studies (IAS), a nonprofit foundation established in 1996 to support the development of anarchism, is a grant-giving organization for radical writers and translators worldwide. IAS has funded some sixty projects by authors from countries around the world, including Argentina, Lebanon, Canada, Chile, Ireland, Nigeria, Germany, South Africa, and the United States and publishes the online journal Perspectives on Anarchist Theory, organizes the annual Renewing the Anarchist Tradition conference, and offers the Mutual Aid Speakers List.

did.unittitle: Institute for Policy Studies Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Institute for Policy Studies (IPS), founded in 1963, is a progressive multi-issue think tank that provides policy and research assistance to social justice organizations. The organization organizes projects that support three policy goals: peace, justice, and the environment. The website contains a blog, publications portal, projects page, and event listings.

did.unittitle: Institute for Social Ecology Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Institute for Social Ecology (ISE), established in 1974 and incorporated in 1981, is located in Bennington, VT and is an institution of higher education dedicated to the study of social ecology, an interdisciplinary field drawing on philosophy, political and social theory, anthropology, history, economics, the natural sciences, Marxism, anarchism, and feminism. The ISE has offered intensive summer programs, a year-round B.A. degree program, an M.A. degree program, workshops on issues such as biotechnology, fall and winter lecture series, internship opportunities, and a speaker’s bureau. In addition, the ISE is involved in research as well as publishing and activist projects. The website also holds the digital archives of multiple journals, which the ISE published.

did.unittitle: Institute for Southern Studies Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Institute for Southern Studies, founded in 1970, is a resource website for activists, community leaders, scholars, policy makers, and others looking to make social and economic change to their region. The Institute develops research and publication projects to establish organizations. The website contains their journal, Southern Exposure, reports, and a blog, Facing South.

did.unittitle: Institute for War & Peace Reporting Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Institute for War and Peace Reporting is an international media development charity, established in 1991. It runs major programs in Afghanistan, the Caucasus, Central Asia, Iran, Iraq, the Balkans, Congo DRC, Tunisia and Uganda. IWPR programs provide intensive hands-on training, extensive reporting and publishing experience to build the capacity of local media. The website contains reporting from their programs, information on their programs, and international news.

did.unittitle: Intellectual Decisions on Environmental Awareness Solutions (IDEAS) Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Intellectual Decisions on Environmental Awareness Solutions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: IDEAS is a national alliance that gives youth leaders tools to create solutions and implement sustainability initiatives in their communities, which include colleges and universities. Through a network of educational institutions, green businesses, and community organizations, IDEAS provides training, resources and support for young people to enact innovative IDEAS and work to solve energy, environmental and economic problems in their community.

dao.ns2:title: Intellectual Decisions on Environmental Awareness Solutions (IDEAS)

daodesc.p: Intellectual Decisions on Environmental Awareness Solutions (IDEAS)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Established in 1999, the Interactivist Network was a New York City-based collaborative which provided internet tools and services to activists groups, like training programs, media projects, skill sharing, and information exchange through forums and articles. The Interactivist Network worked to raise awareness and inspire use of new technologies. It was part of the ABC No Rio, and is currently in hiatus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The International Bolshevik Tendency (IBT) is a revolutionary socialist organization founded by former cadres of the international Spartacist tendency (today the International Communist League). They work in solidarity with the Revolutionary Tendency of the Socialist Workers Party to defend the revolutionary program against the centrist objectivism of the majority. They stand on the Trotskyist positions defended and elaborated by the revolutionary Spartacist League. The website contains their publication, 1917, other publications, articles, and other materials.

did.unittitle: International Communist League (Fourth Internationalist) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The International Communist League (Fourth Internationalist), founded 1998, is an international Trotskyist organization, "a proletarian, revolutionary and internationalist tendency committed to the task of building Leninist parties as national sections of a democratic- centralist international." The origins of the ICL are in the Spartacist League/U.S., which began as the Revolutionary Tendency in the Socialist Workers Party and was bureaucratically expelled in 1963. The ICL publishes the periodicals, Workers Vanguard and The Spartacist. The website also contains periodicals, a directory, and other literature.

did.unittitle: International Endowment for Democracy Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The International Endowment for Democracy (IED), was founded by progressive scholars, lawyers, and activists in 2006 to help people “bring back democracy” in the USA. Although founded in the USA and based in New York, its funding comes almost entirely from non-governmental organizations and individuals outside the USA. IED's first president is the university professor Bertell Ollman. They also maintain the Critical Democracy Library.

did.unittitle: International Freedom of Expression Exchange Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: International Freedom of Expression eXchange Network

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: International Freedom of Expression eXchange Network, created in 1992 in Montreal works to expose violations of free expression around the world and promote free expression. The website publishes news and runs advocacy campaigns. IFEX’s positions are based upon the principles of Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. IFEX numbers 95 independent organizations worldwide and is managed by the Canadian Journalists for Free Expression (CJFE).

did.unittitle: International Jewish Anti-Zionist Network Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The International Jewish Anti-Zionist Network is a Jewish network that opposes Israel and Zionism, rejects colonial expansion in Palestine, challenges Zionist organizations, rejects racism against Mizrahi Jews and Palestinians, and fights for a Palestinian Right of Return. The website contains news, statements, bulletins, boycott alerts, and republished articles. The website also features links to international chapters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: International Publishers is a publishing house historically associated with the Communist Party USA that publishes working class literature. The website contains an online catalog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The International Socialist Organization (U.S.), founded 1969, is a Trotskyist organization, and publishes Labor Notes, a national voice for progressive rank and file unionists (http://webarchives.cdlib.org/site/sw1862bf8f), the Socialist Worker and the International Socialist Review. Members are involved in helping to build a number of struggles: the movement to stop the war on Iraq, fights against racism and anti-immigrant scapegoating, the struggle for women's rights like the right to choose abortion, opposing anti-gay bigotry, and standing up for workers' rights. The website contains links to their publications, information on their branches, resources for socialists, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: InterOccupy is the hub of communications and a collaborative effort of the Occupy Wall Street movement, maintained by Inter-Occupation Communications Working Groups from local occupations across the United States. This website also hosts the Occupy Sandy hub, which works to distribute aid to those affected by Super Storm Sandy. The website hosts weekly conference calls that connect specific working groups to each other across occupations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1976 by James Weinstein, In These Times, is a monthly news and opinion magazine, published online and in print. It regularly reports on environmental issues, feminism, grassroots democracy, minority communities, labor, and the media. It publishes investigative journalism on corporate malfeasance and government wrongdoing. The website contains blogs by contributors to the magazine. Regular contributors include Noam Chomsky.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Inter Press Service - North America, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: IPS/Inter Press Service - North America, Inc. (IPS) was established in July 1997 in New York. The purpose of the organization is to enhance dissemination of newsworthy information to and from developing nations to the North American media, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), policy-makers at the United Nations, specialized UN agencies, learning institutions, and other organizations that are involved in social, economic and educational issues affecting primarily developing countries. IPS also works to correct the imbalance of news provided by the mainstream media and provide analysis on issues that are not normally covered by the mainstream press.

did.unittitle: Iraq Veterans Against the War Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Iraq Veterans Against the War was founded by Iraq war veterans in July 2004 at the annual convention of Veterans for Peace (VFP) in Boston to give a voice to the large number of active duty service people and veterans who are against this war, but under pressure to remain silent. IVAW calls for an immediate withdrawal of all forces out of Iraq, reparations for the human and structural damages Iraq has suffered, and full benefits, adequate healthcare (including mental health), and other supports for returning servicemen and women. The website contains information on their committees and campaigns, chapter listings, information on individual members, and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Jacobin is a print and online magazine focusing on news and commentary on the American left, offering socialist perspectives on politics, economics, and culture. The print magazine is released quarterly and reaches over 6,000 subscribers, in addition to a web audience of 400,000 a month.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Jericho Movement works to gain recognition that political prisoners and prisoners of war exist in the United States and to win amnesty and freedom for these political prisoners. The Jericho Movement was established in the spring of 1998, starting off with a march on Washington in support of political prisoners. Today, the organization works to raise funds to provide legal defense, fighting for adequate and quality medical care for prisoners, locating and compiling dossiers on political prisoners to help gain their amnesty.

did.unittitle: Jewish Alliance for Law and Social Action Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Jewish Alliance for Law & Social Action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Jewish Alliance for Law and Social Action (JALSA) is a membership-based non-profit organization based in Boston. The organization advocates social and economic justice, civil rights and liberties, reproductive rights, and opposes the death penalty.

dao.ns2:title: Jewish Alliance for Law and Social Action

daodesc.p: Jewish Alliance for Law and Social Action

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jewish Currents is a progressive, secular Jewish quarterly magazine that carries on the insurgent tradition of the Jewish left through independent journalism, political commentary, and a "countercultural" approach to Jewish arts and literature. Founded in 1946 as Jewish Life, the magazine was reorganized and re-launched in 1958 as Jewish Currents, with Morris U. Schappes (1907-2004) as its editor, a post he held for four decades. The magazine holds poetry contests, online art exhibitions, and book publishing. The website contains essays in quarterly issues of Jewish Currents magazine; seasonal supplements; blog posts at Blog-Shmog; seminars and events listings.

did.unittitle: Jewish Funds for Justice (JFSJ) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jewish Funds for Justice (JFSJ) was founded in 2006 when its legacy organizations, the Shefa Fund and Jewish Fund for Justice, merged.. JFSJ is a Jewish social and economic justice organization that helps strengthen low-income communities throughout the United States by community investing, grant making, and service learning guided by Jewish values and traditions. In 2011, Jewish Funds for Justice merged with the Progressive Jewish Alliance.

dao.ns2:title: Jewish Funds for Justice (JFSJ) Archived Website

daodesc.p: Jewish Funds for Justice (JFSJ) Archived Website, Jul 25, 2009-Jul 28, 2009

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jewish Peace Fellowship (JPF) was established in 1941, as a nondenominational pacifist organization based upon their interpretation of Jewish social values. JPF was founded to support Jewish conscientious objectors, and to help educate local draft boards --accustomed only to the Christian roots of conscientious objection--of the theological basis of the Jewish position on conscientious objection. JPF supports Jewish resistance to the arms race in the United States, Israel, and the world. The organization also opposes capital punishment, conscription, the Israeli occupation of Palestine, and other U.S. armed interventions.

did.unittitle: Jewish Voice for Peace Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jewish Voice for Peace is a national organization inspired by Jewish tradition to work for peace, social justice, and human rights. JVP supports nonviolent efforts in the United States and in Israel-Palestine to end the Israeli occupation of the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, and East Jerusalem, a resolution of the Palestinian refugee problem consistent with international law and equity, and an end to all violence against civilians and peace in the Middle East, and implement a US policy based on international law and democracy.

scopecontent.p: Jews for Racial and Economic Justice (JFREJ) is a membership-based organization founded in 1990 that engages Jews to pursue and win racial and economic justice including via systemic changes, in partnership with people of color, low-income, and immigrant communities in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: JEWS SAY NO! was founded in New York City in December 2008/January 2009 to protest against the blockade of Gaza and against Israel’s oppression of the Palestinian people. The organization holds demonstrations, performs street theater, supports and sponsors protest actions, and hosts discussions, supporting justice for the Palestinian people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jubilee USA Network, founded in 2000, Network is an alliance of more than 80 religious denominations and faith communities, human rights, environmental, labor, and community groups working for the definitive cancellation of debt owed by countries with high levels of human need, the cancellation of odious debt, and an end to the imposition of economic policies as a condition for debt relief. The website publishes news, resources, and a blog entitled, “Blog the Debt.” Jubilee USA promotes its mission through public education, grassroots organizing, media outreach, policy analysis and advocacy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: J Street established in 2008, is a Washington DC-based Jewish American political action organization that supports a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, which they believe is essential to the survival of Israel as the national home of the Jewish people. J Street advocates active American diplomatic leadership to achieve a two-state solution and a broader regional, comprehensive peace and to ensure a broad debate on Israel and the Middle East, particularly within the Jewish community. The J Street family of organizations is comprised of J Street, JStreetPAC, and the J Street Education Fund.

controlaccess.subject: Arab-Israeli conflict |x Foreign public opinion, American.
Jews |x Political activity |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: J Street U is the student run network that works on campuses through North America to promote peace, social justice, and a two state solution in Israel and Palestine. The website contains chapter contacts and listings, information on workshops and other education and advocacy, resources, and news. The organization is affiliated with J Street.

controlaccess.subject: Arab-Israeli conflict |x Foreign public opinion, American.
Student movements |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Justice Policy Institute is a national nonprofit organization that works to reduce the use of incarceration and the justice system and promote policies that improve the well-being of all people and communities. Their research and analyses identify programs and policies and use it to inform the media, policymakers and advocates. They also provide training and technical assistance supports to people working for justice reform. The website contains a blog, news updates, and research bulletins.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Justseeds Artists’ Cooperative is a decentralized network of 26 artists committed to making print and design work that reflects a radical social, environmental, and political stance, and that in concert with collective action, real change can be achieved. Justseeds produces collective portfolios, contribute graphics to struggles for justice, art installations, and other activities. The website features the art by the artists in the collective.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1949 by Lewis Hill, a pacifist, poet, and journalist, KPFA was the first of the Pacifica network of community supported radio stations in the USA. KPFA broadcasts on 94.1 FM and KPFB 89.3 FM, Berkeley, and KFCF 88.1 FM, Fresno, California. KPFA includes original and local programming; they also broadcast live music, demonstrations, cultural events and other events. KPFA broadcasts Democracy Now! and other Pacifica Radio programming as well. KPFA also works to promote freedom of the press, cultural diversity, serve as a forum for various viewpoints, and maintain an independent funding base.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: KPFK 90.7 FM is a Pacfica Foundation radio station, located in Los Angeles, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: KPFT 90.1 FM is a Pacfica Foundation radio station, located in Los Angeles, California. KPFT was founded by journalist Larry Lee in 1970 in Houston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The South Carolina Labor Party, founded in June 1996 at a convention of 1,400 delegates from hundreds of local and international unions as well as individual activists. The Labor Party platform includes issues such as healthcare and the rights to organize, bargain, and strike. They attempt to run candidates in South Carolina.

did.unittitle: La Lutta New Media Collective Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: La Lutta New Media Collective (NMC), founded in 1997, is a community-based organization promoting a greater level of social awareness through new media. La Lutta offers new media technical assistance to non-profit, community and grassroots groups, and is also a production house for these groups as well as students, artists, and other individuals.

did.unittitle: Lawyers Committee on Nuclear Policy Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1981, the Lawyers Committee on Nuclear Policy is a non-profit educational association of lawyers and legal scholars that engages in research and advocacy in support of the global elimination of nuclear weapons and a more just and peaceful world through respect for domestic and international law. LCNP serves as the UN office of IALANA, the International Association of Lawyers Against Nuclear Arms. LCNP provides legal and policy analysis to national and international policymakers, civil society, and media; publishes books and papers; advocates in UN and Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty settings, and in Washington, DC; works in disarmament and peace networks and campaigns; and provides legal assistance to individuals and organizations working for disarmament and peace. The website contains news, publications, and links to affiliated organizations.

did.unittitle: League for Industrial Democracy Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This website is the site for the contemporary League for Industrial Democracy, descended from the League founded in 1905 by Upton Sinclair, Jack London, Clarence Darrow, Norman Thomas and other writers and civic leaders. The League for Industrial Democracy was an American educational organization dedicated to increasing democracy in economic, political, and cultural life. The contemporary members of the League work for full racial equality, the abolition of poverty, the strengthening of trade unions and cooperatives, the expansion of civil liberties, the extension of public ownership and democratic economic planning, and the realignment of political organizations with a view toward making them more responsive to the will of the people. The website contains a blog and a forum.

did.unittitle: League for the Revolutionary Party - Communist Organization for the Fourth International Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The League for the Revolutionary Party (LRP), based in the United States, is dedicated to the restoration of authentic Marxism and the political independence of the working class with an effort to recreate the Fourth International. They are affiliated with the Communist Organization for the Fourth International (COFI). They publish the political and theoretical magazine Proletarian Revolution. The LRP upholds the method of permanent revolution. The LRP aims to resurrect the method of Trotsky’s Transitional Program. The website contains analysis on current events, theory, and translations of Marxist writers.

dao.ns2:title: League for the Revolutionary Party - Communist Organization for the Fourth International

did.unittitle: League of Revolutionaries for a New America Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: League of Revolutionaries for a New America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The League of Revolutionaries for a New America, founded in 1993, is an organization of revolutionaries that advocate for an end the injustices of capitalism through the education of communism. Rally, Comrades! is the political paper of the League of Revolutionaries for a New America. Rally, Comrades! examines and analyzes the problems of the revolutionary movement, and draws political conclusions for the tasks of revolutionaries at each stage of the revolutionary process. The website contains articles on technology, the economy, politics, the revolution, communism, the corporate state, and other movements.

did.unittitle: League of Women Voters Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The League of Women Voters, founded in 1920, is a nonpartisan political organization, encourages informed and active participation in government, works to increase understanding of major public policy issues, and influences public policy through education and advocacy. The league works to register and educate voters and improving elections and government. The website has a blog and a news outlet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left Business Observer (LBO), founded in 1986 by Doug Henwood, is an eight page monthly newsletter on economics and politics in the U.S. and the world. The website contains back issues from 1990, supplemental material, mailing list, and Henwood’s radio archives and books.

did.unittitle: Left Eye On Books Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left Eye on Books is an online magazine dedicated to progressive book news and reviews to help activists, writers, academics, and community workers become more aware of the diversity of literature. They highlight books published by mainstream and small presses, encourage and foster debate about left scholarship, and consider fiction from a left perspective. They are publication of Conducive Media. The website contains a book clubs, news blog, author interviews, book industry news, and reviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Left Forum is an annual conference (in the spring), and is the successor to the Socialist Scholars Conference (SSC), established in 1981. Left Forum seeks to link the critique of neo-liberalism to anti-capitalism, and to foster radical alternatives to the established order. The conference is held at Pace University in New York City, and has over 3,000 participants, over 300 panels, and 1000 speakers, related to a chosen theme. The website contains information on conferences since 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: LeftShift.org was formed in June 2005 with the goal of showing solidarity with revolutionary Cuba against the ever-present imperialist threats from Washington, DC and Miami. Left Shift also tries to educate the US public about Cuba and its revolution, the nature of the threats against it, and opportunities for our visitors (audience) to get involved in the solidarity movement. While the current focus is Cuba, LeftShift.org stands in solidarity with all people under the gun of U.S. and U.S.-backed imperialism–from Afghanistan to Haiti to Iraq to Palestine to Venezuela–as well as communities under attack within the borders of the U.S.

did.unittitle: Legal Services for Prisoners With Children Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Legal Services for Prisoners with Children

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Legal Services for Prisoners with Children, founded in 1978, challenges the expansion of the prison industrial complex and advocates for the civil rights and empowerment of incarcerated parents, children, family members and people at risk for incarceration through responding to requests for information, trainings, technical assistance, litigation, community activism and the development of more advocates. The website contains news updates, events listings, and a publications page that includes manuals and pamphlets.

The Lesbian Herstory Archives exists to gather and preserve records of Lesbian lives and activities so that future generations will have ready access to materials relevant to their lives. The archive was founded in 1975, by Joan Nestle and Deborah Edel. The website lists the collections, publishes newsletters, and information about exhibits. The website also has information on how to donate to the archive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Liberty Tree Foundation for the Democratic Revolution is a nonprofit organization that builds strategic pro-democracy campaigns. They focus on corporations and democracy; democratic culture and federalism; democratizing defense, education, and elections; and economic, gender, global, law, local, and media democracy. The website contains news, action alerts, and event listings. The website also contains their now defunct journal.

did.unittitle: Links International Journal of Socialist Renewal Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Links International Journal of Socialist Renewal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Links International Journal of Socialist Renewal is an academic journal for the Left in the post-Cold War era. The journal aims to foster discussion and dialogue between Marxists and socialists from different political traditions. It seeks to bring together those in the international left who are opposed to neoliberal economic and social policies, and reject the bureaucratic model of "socialism" that arose in the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and China. The publishers promote a socialism that's green, feminist and anti-racism. The website contains articles, past issues of the publication, and news listings.

daodesc.p: Links International Journal of Socialist Renewal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Living Liberally, founded in 2003 by David Alpert and Justin Krebs, provides an entrance into progressive involvement, using social interaction to promote political action. Living Liberally is built upon networks of local gatherings. These projects include: Drinking Liberally, a national network of social clubs; Laughing Liberally, a political comedy project; Screening Liberally, a politically-conscious film series; and Reading Liberally, a book tour of progressive authors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material presented on Lubitz TrotskyanaNet, launched in 2004, was written, compiled and edited by Wolfgang and Petra Lubitzand contains chiefly bio-bibliographical information, research tools, essays and miscellanies, related to Leon Trotsky, Trotskyism and Trotskyists. Contents include: alphabetical lists of names and pseudonyms of more or less renowned Trotskyists and ex-Trotskyists; biographical sketches or notes and selective bibliographies about a number of known Trotskyists, photograph galleries, and a bibliography of texts written by and about Leon Trotsky.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1983, MADRE is an international women’s human rights organization that works in partnership with community-based women's organizations worldwide to address issues of health and reproductive rights, economic development, environmental and economic justice, education, peace, violence against women, and other human rights. They provide resources and training to enable their sister organizations to meet these goals by addressing immediate needs in their communities and developing long-term solutions to the crises they face. The websites lists news, current campaigns, and resources.

did.unittitle: Make The Road New York Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Make the Road New York, founded in 2007 through the merger of Make the Road by Walking and the Latin American Integration Center, is a community organization in Staten Island, Brooklyn, and Queens. The organization works by expanding civil rights and civic engagement; promoting health; improving housing and fostering environmental justice; and promoting access and opportunity in education through community and electoral organizing, strategic policy advocacy, leadership development, youth and adult education, and high quality legal and support services. The website contains campaigns and news.

The campaign gives Americans the means to air grievances toward corporate banks and calls for banks to pay their fair share. The website contains "bills" sent by users posted to the website addressed to the banks.

The MIM now consists of many independent cells, many of which have their own indendendent organs both online and off. MIM(Prisons) serves these documents as a service to and reference for the anti-imperialist movement worldwide. Also archived herein is a collection of revolutionary art hosted by MIM.

did.unittitle: March on Wall Street South Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: March on Wall Street South was a demonstration and march, affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street Movement, during the Democratic National Convention (DNC) on September 2, 2012 in Charlotte, North Carolina. The march was meant to use backdrop of the DNC to raise awareness of their platform, which included economic justice, immigrant justice, and funds for education, healthcare, housing and other social programs. The website contains a blog with posting about news and reasoning behind the march, a schedule of events, and protest resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Margert Community Corporation is a nonprofit, community-based organization and is a New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) approved housing counseling agency that has been providing neighborhood preservation services, housing assistance, and housing counseling to low-income tenants and homeowners, the elderly, and persons with disabilities since 1980. Their primary service area is Far Rockaway, Queens. The website contains a calendar, photos, news, and housing counseling.

origination.label: creator

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Marxism-Leninism Today is an electronic journal containing articles and commentaries on the theory and practice of Marxism-Leninism; contemporary dialectical and historical materialism. Its goal is to be a resource where Marxist-Leninists can discuss and apply their science to all fields of study. It contains articles that are of particular interest to Marxist scholars, both Communist and non-Communist. Topics include philosophy, religion, African American history, labor history, trade union strategy, Marxist historiography, book reviews, and other articles. The website contains articles which can be browsed by topic.

did.unittitle: Marxist Education Press Publications Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Marxist-Humanist Initiative (MHI) began in April 2009 and is a collective that aims to contribute to the transformation of this capitalist world by developing the philosophy of Karl Marx (1818-1883) and Raya Dunayevskaya (1910-1987). The website contains their principles and by-laws, their publication, “With Sober Senses,” event listings, and other writings and publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Marxists Internet Archive (MIA) is an all-volunteer, non-profit public library, started in 1990. The MIA contains the writings of 592 authors representing a complete spectrum of political, philosophical, and scientific thought, spanning over 200 years, from the early 1800s to the present day. MIA contains these writings in 45 different languages, comprising over 110 GBs of data (as of 2014). Sections of the site include Selected Marxists biographies and writings, Library of Marxist writings, History of Marxism by country and International, subjects, and an encyclopedia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

It was organized by the May Day Solidarity Coalition, a working group of Occupy Wall Street. The website contains information and news about the event.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

The main use of May First/People Link is to provide web hosting for member organizations. The website lists their current projects. May First also hosts numerous discussion lists of various progressive groups or dedicated to various progressive causes / topics.

did.unittitle: Media Action Grassroots Network Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Media Action Grassroots Network (MAG-Net) is a project of the Center for Media Justice. It is a local-to-local advocacy network of grassroots community organizations working together for media change to end poverty, eliminate racism, and ensure human rights. With over 100 member groups nationwide, regional chapters, an online action network, a media justice learning community, and collaborative campaigns- MAG-Net works to advance media justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: Media Matters for America Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Media Matter for America, established in 2004, is a progressive research and information center dedicated to comprehensively monitoring, analyzing, and correcting conservative misinformation in the U.S. media. Media Matters monitors print, broadcast, cable, radio, and Internet media outlets for conservative misinformation and brings to light news that is not accurate or puts forward conservative agenda and notify the general public of misinformation by providing resources to rebut false claims.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Media Mobilizing Project (MMP), based in Philadelphia, works to build a media and communications infrastructure for a movement to end poverty. MMP produces and distributes video, radio, and web training for workers, immigrants, youth, and community leaders to get them involved the movement to end poverty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Meretz USA for Israeli Civil Rights and Peace is a US non-profit organization that supports peace between the State of Israel and its neighbors and the Palestinian people based on a negotiated land-for-peace solution. Meretz USA supports civil and human rights for Israeli citizens, regardless of ethnicity, race, religion, gender, national origin, or sexual orientation. Meretz USA is the successor to the Education Fund for Israeli Civil Rights and Peace, Americans for Progressive Israel, American Friends of Meretz, and American Friends of Ratz. Meretz USA is the US affiliate of the World Union of Meretz, a worldwide association of organizations with the same values. The Israeli affiliate of the World Union of Meretz is the new Yahad - Social Democratic Israel party.

origination.corpname: Metropolitan Council on Housing (New York, N.Y.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Metropolitan Council on Housing, founded in 1959, is a membership organization dedicated to preserving and expanding New York City’s supply of affordable housing. Met Council focuses on preserving rental housing and strengthening tenants’ rights. They work through grassroots organizing, lobbying, direct action, including rent strikes, and public education. Met Council has a monthly newspaper (TENANT), a weekly call-in radio show ("Housing Notebook"), forums, and a volunteer-staffed tenant hotline.

The organization was founded in response to the fatal shooting of Trayvon Martin by George Zimmerman on February 26, 2012. The organization is named for the hooded sweatshirt Martin wore when he was shot. The organization works through demonstrations and lobbying. The website contains event listings, curated music for the organization and actions, and a blog.

The website focuses on developments in Israel/Palestine, the American Jewish community, and American foreign policy. The website supports the movement for greater fairness and justice for Palestinians in American foreign policy.

In addition to a website, they publish a bimonthly magazine. The website focuses on three reporting sections, politics, environmental and culture coverage. The website also contains a photo essay and blog sections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: MoveOn, formed in 1998, is a political action committee that works to bring all Americans into politics to fight for a more progressive America and elect progressive candidates. MoveOn has two subgroups; MoveOn.org Civic Action primarily focuses on education and advocacy on national issues, MoveOn.org Political Action focuses on legislative issues and on helping to elect progressive candidates. Both organizations are entirely funded by individuals.

The websites features a find a credit union page and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On January 21, 2010, with its ruling in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, the Supreme Court ruled once again that corporations are persons, entitled by the U.S. Constitution to buy elections and run our government. Human beings are people; corporations are legal fictions. We, the People of the United States of America, reject the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling, and move to amend our Constitution to firmly establish that money is not speech, and that human beings, not corporations, are persons entitled to constitutional rights.

scopecontent.p: Ms. is a feminist liberal magazine founded in 1971 by Gloria Steinem and Letty Cottin Pogrebin. Currently published by the Feminist Majority Foundation, the website publishes stories on women’s status, women's rights, and women's points of view. They also publish stories found in the print version, feminist news page, a blog, and a feminist resource page.

They work through lobbying, electing pro-choice lawmakers, and educate on women’s rights. Their website contains news, personal accounts, action alerts, and multimedia.

scopecontent.p: NARAL Pro-Choice New York is a political and advocacy organization, whose mission is to guarantee every woman the right to make personal decisions regarding the full range of reproductive choices, including preventing unintended pregnancy, bearing healthy children, and choosing legal abortion. The website contains information on current and past projects, political endorsements, training manuals, reports, and news and event listings.

scopecontent.p: National Action Network is a civil rights organization in the Nation with chapters throughout the entire United States, founded in 1991 by Reverend Al Sharpton. They work to promote a civil rights agenda that includes the fight for one standard of justice and equal opportunities for all people regardless of race, religion, nationality, or gender. Their initiatives include criminal justice, voter protection, anti-violence and gun control, jobs creation, corporate responsibility, education, and decency. The organization works through a ministry as well as non-violent direct action. The website includes information on their campaigns and events, news, video, images, and Al Sharpton's blog.

did.unittitle: National Campaign for a Peace Tax Fund Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Campaign for a Peace Tax Fund, a national non-profit organization located in Washington, D.C., advocates for U.S. federal legislation that would enable conscientious objectors to war to have their federal income taxes directed to a special fund which would be used for non-military purposes alone. This fund would be called the Religious Freedom Peace Tax Fund, and the bill we seek to pass is called the Religious Freedom Peace Tax Fund Act, called H.R. 1191 in the current Congressional term. The website contains publications and resources, endorsements, and further information on the Peace Tax Fund Bill.

did.unittitle: National Coalition for the Homeless Archived Website

scopecontent.p: The National Coalition for the Homeless, formed in 1982, is a national network of people who are currently experiencing or who have experienced homelessness, community-based and faith-based service providers, and other activists and advocates whose mission is to prevent and end homelessness while ensuring the immediate needs of those experiencing homelessness are met and their civil rights protected. Their programs focus on public education, policy advocacy, and grassroots organizing on the issues of housing justice, economic justice, health care justice, and civil rights. The website contains information on their campaigns and advocacy, news, and publications.

did.unittitle: National Committee For Responsive Philanthropy Archived Website

scopecontent.p: National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, founded in 1976, is a non-profit organization that conducts research on and advocates for greater accountability, transparency and a focus on social justice in the philanthropic sector. The organization operates as a watchdog group for philanthropic organizations. The website contains information on campaigns and research, member organizations, action campaigns, publications, events, and news.

did.unittitle: National Committee to Free the Cuban Five Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: National Committee to Free the Cuban Five.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Cuban Five (Gerardo Hernández, Antonio Guerrero, Ramón Labañino, Fernando González, and René González) are five Cubans convicted in Miami of conspiracy to commit espionage, conspiracy to commit murder, and other illegal activities in the United States. The Five were allegedly in the United States to observe and infiltrate the Cuban-American groups Alpha 66, the F4 Commandos, the Cuban American National Foundation, and Brothers to the Rescue. The Five appealed their convictions and the alleged lack of fairness in their trial. A three-judge panel of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta overturned their convictions in 2005, citing the "prejudices" of Miami’s anti-Castro Cubans, but the full court later reversed the five's bid for a new trial and reinstated the original convictions. In June 2009 the US Supreme Court declined to review the case. In Cuba, the Five are viewed as national heroes and portrayed as having sacrificed their liberty in the defense of their country. The main objective of the website is to raise awareness about the Cuban Five and work for their freedom.

dao.ns2:title: National Committee to Free the Cuban Five

daodesc.p: National Committee to Free the Cuban Five

did.unittitle: National Committee to Reopen The Rosenberg Case Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: National Committee to Reopen the Rosenberg Case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After the trial, "The Committee to Secure Justice in the Rosenberg Case" was formed. This committee was led by David and Emily Alman. After the executions, the same committee became "The Committee to Secure Justice for Morton Sobell", a codefendant with the Rosenbergs. Sobell was also convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage and was sentenced to 30 years in jail. Approximately ten years later, the National Committee to Reopen the Rosenberg Case (NCRRC) was formed and has continuously been in existence ever since. Aaron Katz, a member of the original committee, served as director for 42 years, until his retirement in 2005. The current co-directors are Leonard Lehrman and Richard Corey. The Committee seeks to have the Rosenbergs and Sobell exonerated and to have the government publicly address and own up to its complicity in the terrible miscarriage of justice that took place in this case. The NCRRC also supports campaigns to redress the unjust incarceration and excessive punishment of prisoners; including the imposition of the death penalty on Mumia Abu-Jamal. The NCRRC deplores the dismal failure of our judicial system and calls for its review and reform.

scopecontent.p: The National Economic and Social Rights Initiative (NESRI), founded in 2004, is an organization that works to build a broad movement for economic and social rights, including health, housing, education, and worker’s rights. NESRI advocates for public policies that guarantee the universal and equitable fulfillment of human rights. The website contains information on programming, resources, news, and media.

did.unittitle: National Housing Law Project Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Housing Law Project is a nonprofit national housing and legal advocacy center established in 1968. They work to advance housing justice for low income people by increasing and preserving the supply of affordable housing; improving existing housing conditions, including physical conditions and management practices; expanding and enforcing low-income tenants' and homeowners' rights; and increasing housing opportunities for racial and ethnic minorities through litigation and policy advocacy. The website contains publications, information on training sessions, and a frequently asked questions section. The website also contains information on their Housing Justice Network, which is an informal network of more than 700 experienced housing advocates and clients from throughout the country.

did.unittitle: National Jobs For All Coalition Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: National Jobs for All Coalition, founded in 1994, works to build a movement for full employment in the United States at livable wages. They also work for work equality for normally disenfranchised groups, including women and minorities. It regularly produces short, readable articles and pamphlets on such subjects as the Social Security crisis, the moderate costs of a full-employment program, the importance of labor unions, and the undercounting of the unemployed. The website contains their publications and news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Lawyers Guild, founded in 1937, is a non-profit federation of lawyers, legal workers, and law students, who use the law to advance social justice and support progressive social movements. It was the first integrated bar association. The website lists their current campaigns, their chapters, and news.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: The National Low Income Housing Coalition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Low Income Housing Coalition, founded in 1974 by Cushing N. Dolbeare, is an organization that works for public policies that preserve existing federally assisted homes and housing resources, expands the supply of low income housing, and establishes housing stability as the primary purpose of federal low income housing policy. The website contains information on issues and initiatives, research, publications, and conference details.

did.unittitle: National Organization for Women Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Organization for Women (NOW), founded in 1966 by Betty Friedan, Rev. Pauli Murray, and Shirley Chisholm, is the largest U.S. organization of feminist activists, with 500,000 contributing members and 550 chapters in the United States. NOW's priorities include reproductive rights, constitutional equality, lesbian rights, promoting diversity, violence against women, and economic and social justice. The website contains action alerts and information on their chapters.

NOW's priorities include reproductive rights, constitutional equality, lesbian rights, promoting diversity, violence against women, and economic and social justice.This is the New York chapter website.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The United National Antiwar Committee was founded at a conference of 800 in Albany, NY in July, 2010. The UNAC is a national coalition of peace organizations and advocates a complete withdrawal of U.S. armed forces from all U.S.-occupied countries. UNAC uses mass action and other campaigns to achieve their goals. The website contains event listings, action proposals, and information on their yearly conference.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: National People’s Action, founded in 1972 by Shel Trapp and Gale Cincotta, is a network of grassroots activist organizations that advance a national economic and racial justice agenda. NPA is made up of over 26 member organizations. NPA supports three major campaign subjects: bank accountability, housing justice, and immigrant and worker’s rights.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The International Media Project, founded in 1994, is an independent, non-profit organization committed to investigative journalism, in-depth critical analysis, the promotion of civic participation and the dissemination of educational material. Its core focus is National Radio Project, which produces a weekly public affairs radio program called Making Contact. The website contains radio listings, information on production, and show listings.

did.unittitle: National Security Archive: The Torture Archive Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Security Archive announces (8/25/2009) the publication of the Torture Archive -- more than 83,000 pages of primary source documents (and thousands more to come) related to the detention and interrogation of individuals by the United States, in connection with the conduct of hostilities in Iraq and Afghanistan as well as in the broader context of the "global war on terror." The goal of the Torture Archive is to become the online institutional memory for essential evidence on torture in U.S. policy. Many of these documents are available in multiple locations on the Internet and in numerous private collections, thanks to landmark Freedom of Information Act and habeas litigation, leaks from whistleblowers, public relations releases from government, investigative reporting by journalists including the Torturing Democracy team, and Congressional investigations. But the disparate locations, enormous volume of documents, and lack of indexing or standard cataloging have presented real difficulties for users. With support from the Open Society Institute and the JEHT Foundation since 2006, the National Security Archive has undertaken to bring together all these materials in digital formats, organize and catalog them for maximum utility and access, and publish them online in multiple packages including a comprehensive searchable database. By combining released executive branch policy memoranda, legal documents from U.S. and foreign courts, and on-the-ground information about actual practices by the U.S. military and intelligence personnel, the Torture Archive presents a comprehensive view of the war on terrorism, its foundations and its implications. This initial launch of the Torture Archive includes the complete set of declassified Combatant Status Review Tribunal and Administrative Review Board files from the Pentagon, and thousands of documents resulting from FOIA litigation brought by the American Civil Liberties Union, the Archive and other plaintiffs. The Torture Archive will continue to add documents as they are released through Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) litigation or Executive discretion.

dao.ns2:title: National Security Archive: The Torture Archive

daodesc.p: National Security Archive: The Torture Archive

They publish a bimonthly newsletter called More Than A Paycheck and support and create war tax resistance campaigns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Women's Liberation is a collaborative effort between organizers from Redstockings of the Women's Liberation Movement (NY) and Gainesville (FL) Women’s Liberation, started in 1968. The National Women's Liberation is a grassroots organization that works for equality for women in political and economic sphere. The National Women's Liberation also addresses struggles particular to women of color and racism within the feminist movement through their Women of Color Caucus. The website lists their campaigns and chapters.

did.unittitle: National Women's Political Caucus Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Women’s Political Caucus (NWPC), founded in 1971 by Gloria Steinem, is a national multi-partisan grassroots organization that provides support to pro-choice women elected and appointed to office through recruitment, training, and financial donations. Local caucuses in communities across the country to help identify candidates needs and issues specific to their state or county. The Caucus Political Planning Committee vets women candidates for endorsement and the political action committee raises money to support endorsed candidates with campaign contributions. The Caucus also offers workshops on political appointments and collaborates with other women’s political organizations to promote good women candidates for gubernatorial and presidential appointments to key posts within the government. The website features an endorsements page, a chapter’s page, a training and education page, a photo page, and a news page.

did.unittitle: National Youth Rights Association Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Youth Rights Association (NYRA) is a youth-led national non-profit dedicated to fighting for the civil rights and liberties of young people. Their mission centers on challenging age discrimination against young people, both in law and in attitudes. They work to lower the voting age, lower the drinking age, repeal curfew laws, protect student rights, and fight against ageism. The website contains information on their local chapters, campaign and action alerts, blog posts, and a forum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly Thousand Kites, Nation Inside is an organization that provides a platform to connect and support individuals working to systematically change mass incarceration in the United States. The organization accomplishes its work through public speaking events, education of policy makers, and strategies to build safer communities. The website contains current and past campaigns of the organization, blog posts, audio, and video on reforming the criminal justice system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: David Rice (now known as Mondo we Langa) and Edward Poindexter, members of the Black Panther Party, were charged and convicted of the murder of Omaha Police Officer Larry Minard. Minard died when a suitcase containing dynamite exploded in a North Omaha home on August 17, 1970. The two men had been targeted by the FBI's COINTELPRO (Counter Intelligence Program), which operated against and infiltrated anti-war and Civil Rights groups. The website is their support page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Neighbors Helping Neighbors, works to empower low and moderate income Brooklyn residents to secure quality housing and build financial assets through education, organizing, and networking. The website contains a calendar and news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Netroots Nation provides an online and in-person outlet for exchanging ideas and learning how to be more effective in using technology to influence the public debate. Through an annual convention and a series of regional salons held throughout the year, they work to strengthen communities, inspire action and serve as an incubator for progressive ideas that challenge the status quo and ultimately affect change in the public sphere. The annual conference includes panels led by national and international experts; identity, issue and regional caucuses; prominent political, issue and policy-oriented speakers; a progressive film screening series; and the most concentrated gathering of progressive bloggers. Netroots Nation is a project of Bloggerpower.org, a 501(c)4 organization, with the generous support of the Netroots Arts and Education Initiative (NAEI).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The New Bottom Line is a national campaign led by a coalition of community organizations, congregations, labor unions, and individuals creating a movement that challenges established big bank interests. The website sponsors other campaigns, including the Move Our Money campaign and the Save Our Homes campaign. The website contains a news blog, and an events page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

The action campaign was organized by a coalition of social justice groups, including Occupy Wall Street, Center for Popular Democracy, ALIGN: Alliance for a Greater New York, New York Communities for Change, Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union (RWDSU), Strong Economy for All Coalition, and United NY. They work for affordable housing, keeping money out of politics, and relieving debt for working New Yorkers. The website contains the coalition’s inequality report, event listings, and flyers.

New Jewish Agenda (NJA) was a national, multi-issue membership organization active between 1980 and 1992, made up of some 45 local chapters. NJA was committed to participatory democracy and civil rights for all people, especially those marginalized within the mainstream Jewish community, including homosexuals.

The first book fair was in 2007, organized by the New York Metro Anarchist Alliance. The Book Fair includes two days of panels, presentations, workshops, and skill shares on to provide further opportunities to learn more and share your own experience and creativity. The goal of the book fair is to enable people to connect with one another as well as to provide broader access to the rich and varied field of anarchist ideas and practices.

The organization works on issues such as economic equity, non-toxic schools, foreclosure prevention, workplace justice, and affordable housing. scopecontent.p: NYCLASS (New Yorkers for Clean, Livable and Safe Streets (NYCLASS) is a non-profit animal advocacy organization committed to ending the New York City carriage horse industry. NYCLASS advocates for retiring the carriage horses to sanctuary, while modernizing the current industry to greener and humane alternative. They also advocate for the ban of puppy mills, ban of dogs and cats in pet stores, the increase in funding and reform Animal Care and Control of New York City, the building full service animal shelters in the Bronx and Queens, the protection of tenant's right to have a companion animal, the funding humane education in public school classrooms, the mandate of fire sprinklers in pet stores, the ban of the sale of fois gras, the protection of animals used in entertainment, circuses, and rodeos, and the protection of geese. They work through legislation. The website contains a blog and petitions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The May 1st Coalition for Worker and Immigrant Rights formed 2006 in response to the massive mobilizations of immigrants against the Border Protection, Anti-terrorism, and Illegal Immigration Control Act of 2005 legislation in New York and around the country. May 1st organizes annual May Day rallies and supports local labor and immigrant rights campaigns. They stand for immediate legalization for undocumented workers; jobs for all at union wages; education, healthcare, and pensions for all; end militarization of the borders; stop the deportations; build an independent movement of workers and oppressed people; solidarity with the Muslim community; support of the Dream Act youth and students; stop the attacks on public sector and all workers; end racial profiling; end the wars in Afghanistan, Iraq and the Middle East; and advocate for climate change. The website contains information on their current action campaigns and projects and flyers for current and former events.
