scopecontent.p: Next Left Notes (NLN) is an independent radical publication and blog connected to the 2006 re-incarnation of Students for a Democratic Society (SDS). They work to cover the New Left actions, conferences and other aspects of the movement. They provide news articles on left wing events in the United States, as well as commentary and photographic galleries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Niebyl Proctor Marxist Library is a Marxist library that works to help working-class people understand their role in history by maintaining and building an accessible library and archive, by organizing classes and discussions, and by providing community space and resources to promote culture and critical thinking. The website contains a catalog and online seminars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: No Compromise! is a militant, direct action publication of animal liberationists and their supporters. It includes a page on animal liberationist prisoners and a forum where activists can exchange information, share strategy, discuss important issues within the movement, and network.

did.unittitle: North American Animal Liberation Press Office Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: North American Animal Liberation Press Office

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The North American Animal Liberation Press Office (NAALPO) was founded to communicate the actions, strategies, and philosophy of the animal liberation movement that go unreported by mainstream media to the media and the public. NAALPO seeks to clarify the motivations and nature of actions taken in defense of animals. The Press Office also tries to provide a historical, social, and philosophical context for an objective understanding of the nature and motivation of illegal direct actions taken on behalf of captive animals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The North-Atlantic Left Dialogue, an initiative of the Rosa Luxemburg Foundation, is an attempt to develop a continuous working relationship between left and socialist intellectuals and academics in Europe (starting with Germans and Italians) and North America (USA/Canada) for the purpose of discussing the distinctive challenges to the political, social and cultural left working and struggling in the highly developed northern capitalist countries. They hope to contribute to the internationalization of the left and in the process establish a framework for thinking about reform demands which are feasible and appropriate for countries at a comparable stage of development. The website contains information and blog posts on their seminars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Northeast Anarchist Network, founded in Boston in 2007, is a network of northeast and mid-Atlantic region anarchist groups. The purpose of the network is to link and provide aid for anarchist groups across the Northeast and to help each develop working, sustainable models of autonomy, solidarity, and popular power, to support the struggles of working-class people and the solidarity of labor, advance awareness of class, and support the intersecting struggles of all oppressed peoples, and promote environmental protection of Earth.

did.unittitle: Northeastern Federation of Anarchist-Communists Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: North Eastern Federation of Anarchist Communists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Northeastern Federation of Anarcho-Communists (NEFAC), founded in 2000, is a bilingual (French and English) organization of revolutionaries from the northeastern region of North America who identify with the communist tradition within anarchism. NEFAC works against oppression, exploitation, work toward a classless, stateless, non-hierarchical society. In 2011, they changed their name to Common Struggle - Libertarian Communist Federation.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism--Northern California

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is the news web site of the Northern California Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism. Committees of Correspondence for Democracy and Socialism consists of people of all races and national backgrounds who are committed to the struggle for democracy and socialism. The name is taken from the history of the U.S. revolutionary war against British colonialism. In the 1770s, Committees of Correspondence were formed in all 13 colonies and became the catalyst for united action against British oppression. The CCDS was founded ca. 1990, in large part by dissident members of the Communist Party USA. The website contains news postings related to the Northern California branch of the CCDS.

did.unittitle: Northern Manhattan Improvement Corporation Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Northern Manhattan Improvement Corporation (NMIC), founded in 1979, is a tenant organization that serves Washington Heights and Inwood. They work to preserve affordable housing through legal services, community organizing, and building weatherization. They promote economic self-sufficiency through adult education, workforce development, and by stabilizing families through social services, health education, and domestic violence intervention. The website contains information on their programs, news, and annual reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Northern Sun, founded in 1979 in Harrisburg, PA, began selling t-shirts at anti-nuclear events. Over time, the company has evolved into a company that sells progressive, message-oriented t-shirts, button, stickers, and other products through a paper catalog and on its website.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Northland Poster Collective closed at the end of June, 2009. For thirty years it was an activist art organization and business devoted to using art in support of organizing, education and movement building. This site tells some of the story of Northland's years in narratives, testimonials and photos. There are also links to the ongoing projects that started under Northland's wing and are continuing to provide some of the services that Northland offered. There is even an opportunity for our friends, allies and others to post your own comments about Northland, its history and your connections to or observations of its presence among the struggles for social justice in our time. We are pleased to announce the opening of Northland artist Ricardo Levins Morales' new studio web site. The site features his posters and note cards which are available for purchase.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: North Star Fund, founded in 1979, is a New York City based and focused community foundation which supports progressive social and economic justice groups through grants. The North Star has distributed over $35 million to almost 1,700 groups during its existence. North Star's grantees have led efforts on issues ranging from better schools, housing and health care, to protecting civil liberties, stopping domestic violence, creating living wage jobs, and advocating for peace, freedom and human rights.

did.unittitle: Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition, founded in 1974, seeks social, economic, environmental, and racial justice for families and communities through community organizing that utilizes non-violent confrontation, negotiation, and principled compromise. Their campaigns include improving public education, preserving affordable housing, advancing immigrant rights, creating living wage jobs, and other programs. The website contains a blog, event listings, campaigns, reports, videos, and photo galleries.

dao.ns2:title: Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition

daodesc.p: Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Not An Alternative is a hybrid arts collective and non-profit organization with a mission to affect popular understandings of events, symbols, and history. They curate and produce work that questions and leverages the tools of advertising, architecture, exhibit design, branding, and public relations. Their programs are hosted at a variety of venues, including our Brooklyn-based gallery, No-Space. The website contains a blog and information on their collaborative space.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nothingness.org is an anarchist and Situationist website, whose largest component is the Situationist International Text Library, containing books, lengthy articles, excerpts from the journals Potlatch and Internationale Situationniste, newspaper articles, and other files. Note: there were four earlier captures of the Library alone, e.g. captures of the website Situationist International Text Library, which is no longer separately captured.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1997, the November Coalition is an organization that is against the militarization of the United States war on drugs and advocates for drug war prisoners. They also publish a bulletin called Razor Wire.

controlaccess.subject: Drug legalization |z United States.
Drugs |x Law and legislation |z United States.

did.unittitle: Nuclear Age Peace Foundation Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Nuclear Age Peace Foundation, founded in 1982, initiates and supports worldwide efforts to abolish nuclear weapons, to strengthen international law and institutions, and to educate youth peace leaders. The Nuclear Age Peace Foundation is a non-profit, non-partisan international education and advocacy organization. It has consultative status to the United Nations Economic and Social Council and is recognized by the UN as a Peace Messenger Organization. The website contains information on their issues, programs, and resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nukewatch, founded in 1979, is a Wisconsin-based environmental and peace action group, dedicated to the abolition of nuclear power, weapons and continued radioactive waste production. Nukewatch advocates nonviolence through education and action, and reports on nuclear issues in the Nukewatch Quarterly newsletter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The International Socialist Organization New York City District is committed to building an organization that participates in the struggles for justice and a socialist society. Their members are involved in the fight against police brutality, racism, anti-immigrant scapegoating, for women’s rights like the right to choose abortion, opposing anti-gay bigotry, standing up for workers’ rights, anti-war, and other struggles. They publish the International Socialist Review. The website contains information on their current campaigns, event listings, and principles and by-laws.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The New York City Student Assembly, first formed in October 2011, is a student group in solidarity with the Occupy Wall Street movement and for students from all universities in New York City to build a strong, visible student movement. The website contains news, media, and minutes from assembly meetings.

controlaccess.subject: Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Student movements |z New York (State) |z New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: NYU Disorientation, founded after May Day 2013, is a student collective establishing community and resistance at New York University. The website contains its newsletter, a calendar, resources, and a blog.

controlaccess.subject: May Day (Labor holiday).
Student movements |z New York (State) |z New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occucards is a nonprofit collective, established in Fall 2011, that produces educational outreach cards for Occupy Wall Street affiliated groups and other activists across the country to hand out at protests and other events. The collective designs, produces, and sells cards on topics such as corporate accountability, environmental issues, student debt, and healthcare. The website features the cards, a blog, and financial transparency.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Occu-Evolve is an affiliate group of the Occupy movement to focus on the evolution of the Occupy Wall Street movement and other progressive and economic justice movements in New York City. The website contains meeting listings of Occu-Evolve and affiliate groups, and campaigns.

controlaccess.subject: Occupy movement |z New York (State) |z New York.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupationalist is an impartial aggregate website of different media relating to the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website aggregates microblogging from Twitter, photographs from Tumblr, Foursquare check-ins, videos, lists meet-up events, news, and headlines.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occuprint is a print lab in collaboration with Occupy Wall Street and their Screen Printing Guild, which is one of OWS’s working groups. They published and print graphics and posters related to OWS. Occuprint first emerged when The Occupied Wall Street Journal published an issue of poster art of the global Occupy movement. The Occuprint website is meant to connect people with this work, and provide a base of support for print-related media within the #Occupy movement. The material on the website is open source. The website features posters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy.com is a non-profit media outlet affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street Movement. The website seeks to provide an open platform for artists, poets, musicians, writers, podcasters, filmmakers, and other creators to publish their work that promotes social, economic, and environmental justice. The website posts works by these creators and calls for submissions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy.net is a collection of tools for activists that provide people with software tools that align with the values of the Occupy Wall Street movement. All of the tools offered through Occupy.net are open source. The website maps, a forum, a directory, a wiki, projects, a classified section, and news regarding the Occupy movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy* Posters is a tumblr blog, established in 2011, containing posters created for the use in actions Occupy related movements. The asterisk in the name signifies a blank space for other Occupy groups, including location and issue-based groups. Posters are sorted by chronology, by topic, and by design type (including cartoons and infographics). Topics include social and economic justice, gun control, and political reform. The websites contains posters and examples of the posters in use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Albany is the Albany faction of the Occupy Movement, protesting in solidarity with Occupy Wall Street. The website contains general assembly and caucus meeting minutes, working groups information, and event/calendar listings.

did.unittitle: Occupy Alternative Banking Working Group Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This is the website of the Occupy Wall Street Alternative Banking working group. The group aims to push for better financial regulations, by evaluating and fostering alternative financial options, and by educating the public about the contemporary financial system to inspire activism. The website contains event listings, information on their projects, reports, research resources, and a blog.

dao.ns2:title: Occupy Alternative Banking Working Group Archived Website

daodesc.p: Occupy Alternative Banking Working Group Archived Website, Feb 24, 2015-ongoing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Anniversary Spots is a campaign to raise money to put out video commercials for anniversary of the Occupy Wall Street Movement on September 17. The campaign uses the website, Louder, a fundraising internet platform, to raise funds. The website contains short videos and fundraising totals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Arrests is a running total of protesters arrested affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street Movement since September 17, 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Caravan, launched in June and July of 2012, was an educational road show in solidarity with the Occupy movement. The website features information on the events, the route, and a forum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Colleges is a college student activist group in solidarity with the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website posts news feeds on university and city occupations.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.

Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Comix is a comic blog featuring art inspired by and in solidarity with the Occupy movement.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement)--Comic books, strips, etc.
Social responsibility in banking.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Data is an Occupy Wall Street Movement affiliated website that gathers data to analyze and create visualizations that are argument for their grievances on topics such as economic inequality, identity-based discrimination and inequality of opportunity, corruption, lobbying, campaign finance, militarization, the financial crisis, the criminal justice system, mortgages and foreclosures, and other themes. The website contains map visualizations, data sets, code for processing visualizations, and tutorials to create visualizations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy DC is a nonviolent occupation of public space in solidarity with Occupy Wall Street and Occupy movements. Occupy DC was in McPherson Square in Washington during the Fall 2011 and Winter 2012, DC. The website contains event and action notices, news related to the occupation in DC, a blog called the Occupied Washington Times, a livestream, and a radio station.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Design, formed in 2011, is a graphic design project in solidarity with the Occupy Wall Street movement. The project’s goal is to create freely available visual tools around a common graphic language to unite occupy protesters. The site includes a showcase of existing designs, a how-to guide for demonstrators, a graphic toolkit for designers, and a platform for the community to suggest ideas for designs.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Occupy Wall Street’s Practical Change Working Group

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Educated is an affiliate website of the Occupy Wall Street Movement’s Practical Change Working Group that works to educate activists on issues and their root causes. The website works as a knowledge aggregator and provides a list of primer books, articles and commentary, and Author interviews. The website also contains blog and a forum for user contributions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Face is a graphic design project to create a new symbol and "face" for the Occupy Wall Street movement. The artwork featured on the website was created by Paul-Felix Montez.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Foreclosure grew out of the foreclosure working group at Occupy Greensboro, North Carolina, now affiliated with the national Occupy Wall Street movement. Occupy Foreclosure mostly works out of the American Southeast to protect homeowners against foreclosure and make them aware of the resources to prevent foreclosure. The working group also works to make homeowners aware of corporate malfeasance and bank fraud that led to the housing bubble and recession of 2007-2009. The website contains information about their satirical film, "Let's Lose Our House," action updates, and news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Graduation, affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street movement, is a group which advocates student loan debt forgiveness. The website contains news and stories from students.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Occupy Wall Street Music Working Group

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy Guitarmy is part of the Occupy Wall Street Music Working Group, which was founded as part of the Occupy Wall Street general assembly. They are a leaderless, participatory musical group that plays in the streets for progressive social change. The group organizes song shares and teach-ins. The website contains information about their current and past performances and events. The website is a tumblr blog that mostly contains videos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Healthcare, affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street movement, works to build a nation-wide equitable, affordable, and universal healthcare system. They also believe in a patient-centered system built around prevention and wellness to improve health, as well as monetary incentives. They support the Affordable Healthcare Act and other political campaigns. The website contains a blog, personal stories about the failures of the current healthcare system, and information about doctors in support of the campaign.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The website contains information to the June 1, 2013 attempted reoccupation of Liberty Plaza in New York City by activists affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street Movement. The demonstrations were in solidarity with protesters against plans to replace Taksim Gezi Park in Cairo, Egypt with a shopping mall. The website contains event listings and a forum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Judaism mobilizes Jewish participation in Occupy Wall Street, bringing the Jewish prophetic voice to bear on issues of social and economic injustice, and brings the values of Occupy back into the Jewish community. Occupy Judaism is nonsectarian, nondenominational, and open to Jews and their non-Jewish partners. The website features a blog, videos, and information on their events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy Money Cooperative (OMC) is a venture to establish transparent, low-cost financial services to all. The first project of OMC is the “Occupy Card,” which is a prepaid debit card with a transparent fee structure, featured prominently on the website. The website contains fundraising information, a blog, and information about the co-op and structure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy National Gathering, which took place on July 4, 2012 in Philadelphia, was a gathering of groups in solidarity with the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website contains the findings from the gathering, news, solidarity groups, and upcoming actions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy Network is a discovery portal for the Occupy Wall Street (OWS) movement and is the home of the OWS Newsletter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy News is a news website that aggregates news on over 175 occupations that are part of the Occupy Wall Street movement across the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: OccupyOurHomes is a website inspired about the Occupy Movement. The website works to negotiate with Wall Street banks and homeowners instead of foreclosing on homeowners. They believe that everyone has the right to affordable housing. Activists occupy foreclosed homes to work for change. The website contains videos, articles, and resources on how to protect homes from foreclosure.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Wall Street People’s Think Tank, formed in September 2011, holds open dialogues throughout New York City. The website features summaries and recordings of these conversations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Pics is a blog that posts pictures and videos from the Occupy Wall Street Movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupyr is a social networking website and provides web-infrastructure and tech support for the Occupy Movement. Occupyr aims to assist in unifying protesters into actionable plans to strengthen the movement. The website has a livestream, news feed, forums, an art page, and a chat room dedicated to the Occupy movement.

did.unittitle: OCCUPYSMS: Mutual Aid Platform Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: OccupySMS, established in the wake of Superstorm Sandy in October 2012, expedites mutual aid by connecting people through text message by seeking and offering aid based on specific location and needs in areas without power or Internet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Stories, founded in November 2011, aims to collect and organize stories and observations from the Occupy movement. Most of the stories on the website are of a personal nature, detailing stories on individual experiences of those involved in the movement. The website also has has a forum for discussion.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Student Debt is a blog in solidarity with the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website collects user submitted stories on student debt that demonstrates the student debt crisis. The website contains demands, media, press releases, and resources.

did.unittitle: Occupy Student Debt Campaign Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy Student Debt Campaign is an Occupy Wall Street movement campaign that advocates for tuition free public higher education, zero interest student loans, transparency of private university and colleges’ financial records, and student loan forgiveness. The website contains a Pledge of Refusal that is framed as a debt strike threat (debtors pledge to withhold payments once a million others have signed). The website contains resources, stories of debtors, and an FAQ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy technology lives as a storehouse for technological resources and ideas for the occupy movement.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

did.unittitle: Occupy the Auctions / Evictions Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy the Auctions, affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street movement, works to stop predatory and for-profit bank evictions, foreclosures, and auctions of small businesses and homes, mostly in San Francisco. Organizers work through action alerts, research, and protests. The website contains a blog and sign-up forms.

did.unittitle: Occupy the Board Room Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy the Board Room is a site that provides those with a valid email account an opportunity to choose a "pen pal" in the top 1%, to whom they can voice their frustrations about America’s economic issues.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy the Bronx is Bronx’s contingent of the Occupy movement in solidarity with Occupy Wall Street. The website contains action alerts, meeting minutes, a forum, and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy the Caucus, formed in Des Moines, IA, to occupy the Iowa caucuses in January 2012. They plan on occupying the presidential campaign headquarters in Des Moines, Iowa and other political events throughout the state for a week leading up to the caucus. The occupation plans to use the spotlight of the Iowa caucuses to make economic change.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy the Nation, established in late 2011, aggregates news related to the Occupy Wall Street and other occupations in solidarity with Occupy Wall Street. The website contains event listings, working group pages, videos, and a resource page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy The Pipeline is a grass-roots, not-for-profit environmental working group of the Occupy Wall Street Movement, founded in the spring of 2012, to oppose the construction of the Spectra Pipeline through non-violent direct action and civil disobedience. The Spectra Pipeline is a high-pressure, large-diameter, fracked-gas pipeline under construction in Manhattan's West Village, which is set to go on line November 2013. The website contains hydraulic fracturing (fracking) related news and events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Resist RNC, endorsed by occupy groups, was a coordination website for the protests and demonstrations around the Republican National Convention (RNC) in Tampa, Florida from August 27-30, 2012. The website contained event listings for all actions and counter- programming in Tampa during the RNC. Events included demonstrations related to economic rights, human rights, anti-war, and the environment. The website also features resources for activists planning events and protests. It also has a news blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Together is a website that lists events and actions around the world in solidarity with the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website lists major action projects of the Occupy movement, contains lists of occupy groups, and offers links to occupation planning websites.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Union Square is the website for the occupation of Union Square in New York City by individuals affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website posts occupy-related news, resources to support and get involved in occupy, organizing materials, and event listings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: OccupyWallStreet.org is the main website for the Occupy Wall Street Movement. This website contains news related to other Occupy movement sites, protests and demonstrations, and other social justice movements in solidarity with Occupy Wall Street. Occupy Wall Street (OWS) is a people-powered movement that began on September 17, 2011 in Liberty Square in Manhattan’s Financial District, and spread to over 100 cities in the United States and actions in over 1,500 cities globally. OWS works to fight corporate banks’ power over the democratic process. The website contains links to other Occupy movement websites.

did.unittitle: Occupy Wall Street Bike Coalition Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy Wall Street Bike Coalition (OWSBC) is a working group within the Occupy Wall Street Movement that provides bike swarm tactics for Occupy actions, free bicycle repairs, and fittings for bikes. OWSBC sees cycling as a sustainable transportation alternative. The group holds cycling meet-ups as well. The website contains event listings.

did.unittitle: Occupy Wall Street Care Packages Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a collection of notes, cards, and letters of support enclosed with contributions and care packages sent from across the United States and around the world to Occupy Wall Street.

controlaccess.subject: Distributive justice.
Financial sector of the American economy.
Occupy Wall Street (Movement).
Social responsibility of business.

did.unittitle: Occupy Wall Street Library, The People's Library at Liberty Plaza Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The People’s Library is the collective, public, open library of the Occupy Wall Street movement. The library was located in Liberty Plaza in Zucotti Park in New York City during the height of the Occupy Wall Street Movement in late 2011. The facilities there and the collection were destroyed during the November 15 raid on Liberty Plaza. The Library consists of a book sharing system that lends free books in and out of the OWS storage facility and to Liberty Plaza and actions around New York. The website contains a catalogue of books, publications produced by the Library, and a blog.

scopecontent.p: The Occupied Wall Street Journal is a print and online newspaper produced by an affinity group of the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website contains news regarding the movement, analysis, and human interest pieces regarding the movement. The first newspaper was published in October 2011.

did.unittitle: Occupy Wall Street National Gathering Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy National Gathering was a gathering of Occupy Wall Street Movement activists in Kalamazoo, Michigan from August 21-25, 2013. The website contains logistical and scheduling information on the gathering. The website also contains news on other gatherings across the country.

daodesc.p: Occupy Wall Street National Gathering, Aug 29, 2013-Aug 28, 2014

did.unittitle: Occupy Wall Street Review Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy Wall Street Review is the literary review of the Occupy Wall Street movement.

did.unittitle: Occupy Wall Street S17 Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: S-17 2013 is the organizational website for the second anniversary actions (on September 17, 2013) of Occupy Wall Street at Liberty Plaza (formerly Zuccotti Park) in New York City. The website contains information about the events, actions, teach-ins, and marches held on the anniversary. Events are related to issues including economic fairness, politics and justice, war and conflict, social equality, and environmental protections.

did.unittitle: Occupy Wall Street Screen Printers Co-op Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Occupy Wall Street Screen Printers Co-op

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Wall Street Screenprinters Co-op is a print production facility established during the initial occupation of Zuccotti Park by the Occupy Wall Street Movement in 2011. The money raised from the print shop during the occupation was used to General Assembly’s General Fund and Occupy’s Workers Cooperative. The co-op produces prints for Occupy events, custom print orders, and other community needs. The organization uses fair labor practices and prints on sustainable sourced clothing and materials. The co-op operates on a donation structure; products are on a pay-what-you-wish scale. The website contains a blog, a product line, their mission statement, and sustainability resources.

daodesc.p: Occupy Wall Street Screen Printers Co-op

scopecontent.p: October 2011 began as an informational website regarding a demonstration in McPherson Square in Washington DC in October 2011. It became an informational website related to the occupation in Freedom Plaza, which was in solidarity with the Occupy Wall Street Movement. The website contains daily updates on the status of the occupation, a calendar of events, videos, and a blog.

scopecontent.p: Occupy Wish List is a craigslist-type website which lists materials and supplies needed by the Occupy Wall Street movement and sustain the occupations in cities throughout the country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly Occupenial, Occupy with Art, founded in 2011, is an affinity group of the Arts and Culture working group for the Occupy Wall Street movement. The group consists of artists who produce art, cultural events and projects with a particular focus on OWS as a social art process. The website serves as an information hub for current and past art-related activities in the OWS movement. The website contains a blog that provides updates on works in progress and event information, jobs posting, videos, and photos of art projects.

scopecontent.p: Occupy Congress, established in late 2011, is a collective affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street street movement. The collective organized an action on January 17, 2012 with members of Occupy DC. The website contains meeting minutes, videos, event listings, action updates, and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: off our backs is a feminist news journal that was first published in 1970. Their mission is to provide news and information about women's lives and feminist activism, educate the public about the status of women around the world, serve as a forum for feminist ideas and theory, be an information resource on feminist, women's, and lesbian culture, and seek social justice and equality for women worldwide. The website features access to back issues.

did.unittitle: One Nation Working Together Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One Nation Working Together works to build a more unified, sustainable future by providing immediate relief for those unemployed, extending jobless benefits, supporting COBRA, mortgage assistance, and other initiatives for those currently out of work, and targeting help for populations and communities in need.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: OneWorld Group, founded in 1994, is a network that pioneers digital media innovations to help communities and organizations to bring about a fairer and greener world. The website contains information on their OneClimate and Mobile4Good campaigns, educational guides, headlines, videos, and job listings.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: New York City Neither East Nor West.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On Gogol Boulevard (OGB) was the irregular bulletin of New York City Neither East Nor West, networking East and West alternative oppositions and printing news and documents unavailable in the corporate and "left" media, using mostly material from Communist/ex-Communist countries. The OGB News Service had regular sections in The Shadow, Profane Existence, Fifth Estate, Black Fist and other papers and are now also published on the internet. OGB supported publishing articles on "Third World" and land-based indigenous people’s struggles, supporting activists with anti-authoritarian and anti-Stalinist perspectives. OGB also worked to promote freedom, workers rights, women's, minority and gay rights, environmental, self-determination and anti-militarist issues, and any struggle pursuing paths outside the capitalist and state bureaucratic models.

did.unittitle: On The Issues Magazine Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On the Issues Magazine Online is a successor to the print publication, On The Issues Magazine, a progressive, feminist quarterly print publication from 1983 to 1999, both published by Choices Women’s Medical Center, Merle Hoffman, President and CEO, located in Long Island City, New York. The website is a feminist news and opinion magazine. The website contains a blog, the Cafe, and articles.

did.unittitle: Open Letter from American Jews Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This website is for a 2002 open letter from American Jews, calling for peace between Israelis and Palestinians in the Middle East. The majority of the signers are American Jewish educators. The website contains the petition, images of the newspaper ad, and a list of the original signers.

did.unittitle: Organization for Black Struggle Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Organization for Black Struggle was founded in 1980 by activists, students, union organizers and other community members in St Louis, Missouri, with the aim of building black power. The websites contains information about the organization's political platform, news and events, and the national mobilization against police violence following the 2014 police killing of Mike Brown in Ferguson, MO.

did.unittitle: Organizing for Occupation | Housing Justice in NYC through Direct Action Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Organizing for Occupation (O4O) is a group of New York City residents from the activist, academic, religious, homeless, arts, and progressive legal communities to respond to the housing crisis. The group advocates affordable and safe housing for all. The group works through non-violent direct action to end homelessness and foreclosures. The website contains a calendar, a mailing list, and links page.

dao.ns2:title: Organizing for Occupation | Housing Justice in NYC through Direct Action

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Other 98%, established in 2010, is a grassroots network that works to remove corporate lobbyists out of DC, hold elected officials accountable, and fix our democracy to make Washington work for the other 98%. The website contains a blog, fact sheets, media, press, and videos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: OWS Direct Action is the action working group of the Occupy Wall Street movement. The website contains information on meetings, their direct action campaigns and days, their eco-action campaign, resources, and passed proposals.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Pacifica Foundation was founded in 1949 as an alternative to commercially-driven radio media. Pacifica's mission is to promote peace and justice through communication between all races, nationalities and cultures and work to contribute to the democratic process through public discourse and promotion of culture. The Pacifica Network includes five sister radio stations in New York, Washington DC, Los Angeles, Berkeley, and Houston along with many affiliated independent radio stations throughout the United States. Pacifica broadcasts via satellite and Internet and has an extensive sound archives. Pacifica contributes to independent community radio through collaboration, interactivity and program exchange throughout the network.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pacifica Radio Archives (PRA) preserves the audio collection that consists of work generated by and produced in association with Pacifica Radio and makes it available for research and reference use. Chronicling the progressive political, cultural and artistic movements of the second half of the 20th century, Pacifica radio programs include documentaries, performances, discussions, debates, drama, poetry readings, commentaries and radio arts. The types of material focused on reflect the memory, traditions and evolution of Pacifica Radio. The intellectual content of the collection emphasizes a common theme of social justice covering cultural, health, historical, political, psychological, racial, religious, philosophical and social aspects of our society over a variety of subjects. PRA also assesses and serves the programming, production and research needs of Pacifica Radio (including Pacifica personnel, listeners, the media and the research community).

did.unittitle: Palestinian BDS National Committee Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Palestinian BDS National Committee, launched in 2005, is a network of Palestinian support groups that calls for boycotts and sanctions against Israel. The website contains news, analysis, statements, and information on current campaigns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paper Tiger Television (PTTV), established in 1981, has been creating investigative and alternative media. The programs produced at PTTV inspire community productions and activism around the world. Its archive includes shows that provide critical analysis of media, educate about the communications industry and highlight issues that are absent from mainstream information sources. Through the production and distribution of public access series, media literacy/video production workshops, community screenings, videos on the website, and grassroots advocacy PTTV works to challenge and expose the corporate control of mainstream media. PTTV believes that increasing public awareness of the negative influence of mass media and involving people in the process of making media is mandatory for the long-term goal of information equity.

did.unittitle: Parents for Occupy Wall Street Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The parents for Occupy Wall Street website is a solidarity page of parents who support the Occupy movement. The website contains a blog, a campaigns page, and a videos page.

did.unittitle: Park West Village Tenants' Association Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Park West Village Tenants Association (New York, N.Y.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Park West Village Tenants’ Association, first active in 1974, is a voluntary, non-profit, membership organization whose purposes are to protect the rights and welfare of tenants in Park West Village (PWV); keep PWV tenants informed of their rights; represent PWVTA members in negotiations with Park West managements; represent the concerns of PWVTA members to outside organizations and to elected officials and government agencies; and support and participate in campaigns by various organizations; to expand tenant rights; strengthen rent regulations; preserve affordable housing programs; and protect the ability of low-income and moderate-income tenants to remain in their homes. They are affiliated with Tenants and Neighbors and the Metropolitan Council on Housing. The website contains resources, a renters’ guide, photos, and history.

did.unittitle: Partners for Progressive Israel Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Partners for Progressive Israel (formerly Meretz USA) is a progressive American Zionist non-profit organization that works for peace between Israel and its neighbors, as well as advocating a two-state solution for Israel and the Palestinian people. The organization also advocates for equality and justice for all of Israel's inhabitants. Partners for Progressive Israel works through its projects and direct involvement in Israel with American Jews and Israeli progressive groups. The website contains statements, projects, programming, boycott information, and a blog.

did.unittitle: Party for Socialism and Liberation Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Party for Socialism and Liberation, a revolutionary Marxist organization formed in 2004, seeks to bring together leaders and organizers to aim for revolution in the United States and promote socialism. They stand for defense of the existing workers’ states, the national liberation movements, and for workers and oppressed people around the world. The website contains information on the Party for Socialism and Liberation in the United States, and its newspaper Liberation. The site features news and analysis of contemporary events, and reports from activists involved in the anti-war movement and labor movement, and other issues. The website also contains information on their campaigns and additional publications.

daodesc.p: Party for Socialism and Liberation, Aug 17, 2009-ongoing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pax Christi USA is the US branch of the international Catholic peace movement, Pax Christi. Pax Christi USA has over 400 local groups. Pax Christi USA rejects war, preparations for war, and every form of violence and domination. It advocates primacy of conscience, economic and social justice, and respect for creation. The website contains information on their programs and resources and also contains a mailing list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Peace Action (originally from the merger of the Nuclear Weapons Freeze Campaign and the Committee for a SANE Nuclear Policy), founded in 1987, is a national grassroots organization that organizes campaigns to end the nuclear threat, to create a more peaceful economy, and to support nonviolent resolutions to international conflicts. The website contains information on issues, news, action alerts, a media center, and a resources page.

did.unittitle: Peace Action New York State Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Peace Action of New York State and the Peace Action Fund of New York State are the New York affiliates of Peace Action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Peace Alliance, established in 2005, is an alliance of organizers and advocates that use civic engagement and legislative action to promote peace building. The website contains information on their advocacy campaigns, actions and event listings, and multimedia tools.

did.unittitle: Peace and Freedom Party Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Peace and Freedom Party is California’s feminist socialist political party, founded in 1967. It is committed to socialism, democracy, ecology, feminism and racial equality. The website contains their by-laws, platform, newsletters, and news listings on current campaigns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Peace Brigades International is an international NGO that promotes nonviolence and protects human rights since 1981. Their work is based on the principles of non-partisanship and non-interference in the internal affairs of the organizations we accompany. PBI sends teams of volunteers backed up by an international support network to accompany human rights defenders and communities in areas of conflict. The website contains news, publications, strategies, field projects, and annual reviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: September 11th Families for Peaceful Tomorrows is an organization dedicated to finding nonviolent solutions to war and terrorism. Their goals are to promote dialogue on alternatives to war, while educating and raising the consciousness of the public on issues of war, peace, and the underlying causes of terrorism; to support and offer fellowship to others seeking non-violent responses to all forms of terrorism, both individual and institutional; to call attention to threats to civil liberties, human rights, and other freedoms in the U.S. as a consequence of war; to

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: PeaceSmiths, founded in 1972, are a community organizing group that promotes peace and justice and assists in discovering and promoting peaceful alternatives to war and promoting and protecting civil rights. Their work includes projects related to education, activism, culture and mutual help. The website contains news, election information, and poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Penn South or the Mutual Redevelopment Houses is a limited-equity housing cooperative development located in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, originally sponsored by the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union in 1962. The website contains information on joining the cooperative and a newsletter.

did.unittitle: People for the American Way. Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: People For the American Way (PFAW) was founded in 1981 by Norman Lear, Barbara Jordan, Father Theodore Hesburgh, and Andrew Heiskell. Key issues for PFAW are maintaining the separation of church and state, as well as civil rights and liberties and economic and social justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: People’s World, established online in 2009, is a national news website that reports on workers' rights, peace, equality, social and economic justice, democracy, civil liberties, women's rights, protection of the environment, and more. The website is affiliated with the Community Party USA and descended from the Daily Worker, the Communist Party’s newspaper from 1924-1991. The website publishes articles and opinion pieces. The Spanish language edition of the website is called Mundo Popular.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: People of Color at Occupy Wall Street

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: People of Color, Occupy Wall Street is the tumblr blog created in response to the lack of racial diversity represented at the Occupy Wall Street occupations. Their goal is to develop critical consciousness within the movement and extend the movement’s reach to include those most affected by the current crisis. The website lists working group meetings and sub committees of the working groups.

did.unittitle: People of Color Organize Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: People of Color Organize! was the successor to Illvox.org, established in June of 2007. In 2010, the URL changed to http://www.peopleofcolororganize.com/. Illvox supported Anarchist People of Color and its efforts. People of Color Organize! was a website journal and media source for activists who support direct action for social, racial, and economic justice. The website features debates, event listings, and commentary from the revolutionary left on matters of race, national oppression, and self determination efforts. People of Color Organize! focuses on people of color and their activism, community organizing, theory and perspectives. In 2013, this website was subsumed by the Party for Socialism and Liberation, which can be found in Tamiment's Communism, Socialism, Trotskyism Web Archive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 2000, Peoples Production House was a journalism training and production institute focused on producing stories that highlight stories not covered by the mainstream media. They teach students, immigrants, and working families how to produce news and analysis. People's Production House works to produce news from all perspectives because they believe diverse media is a human right. They have trained over 1000 individuals, of whom 95% are underrepresented minorities from low-income backgrounds. In 2013 they merged with Rev-.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Philadelphia Unemployment Project, established in 1975, organizes the poor and unemployed to fight for economic justice, to bring about changes to benefit millions of unemployed and impoverished. PUP also builds connections with partners in labor, religious, community civil rights, and women’s movements with the unemployed. PUP’s sister organization the Unemployment Information Center has also played a role by providing research, direct services and organizing support to jobless Philadelphians and PUP since 1976.

did.unittitle: Physicians for a National Health Program Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Physicians for a National Health Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Physicians for a National Health Program (PNHP), advocates a comprehensive single-payer national health program. PNHP was established in 1987 and advocates reform in the United States healthcare system. PNHP also educates physicians and other health professionals of healthcare reform, performs research on the health crisis, coordinates speakers and forums, participates in town hall meetings and debates, contributes scholarly articles to peer-reviewed medical journals, and appears regularly on national television and news programs advocating for a single-payer system.

did.unittitle: Physicians for Social Responsibility (PSR) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1961, Physicians for Social Responsibility works as a medical and public health voice against nuclear war, global warming, and toxic degradation of the environment. PSR consists of health professionals, activists, and students in medical and health programs. In 1985, PSR shared the Nobel Peace Prize awarded to International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War for building public awareness and pressure to end the nuclear arms race.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Picture the Homeless, founded in 1999 in the Bronx, is an organization that promotes social justice around issues like housing, police violence, the shelter-industrial complex, and homelessness. Picture the Homeless is organized and run by homeless people to end homelessness. The organization sponsors campaigns that work to end homelessness and raise awareness.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Platypus Affiliated Society, established in December 2006, organizes reading groups, public forums, and research and journalism focused on problems and tasks inherited from older left movements. The website contains news, multimedia from forums, and the Platypus Review, their journal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Ploughshares Fund, founded in 1981, is a fund that grants money to individuals and organizations to implement strategies to seek the peace and nuclear disarmament. The website contains information on how to apply to a grant, grant database, a blog, ways to donate, and a report on the elimination of the worldwide nuclear stockpile.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Political Affairs is an online magazine of theories, ideas, politics and culture of the socialist and democratic traditions and visions of the United States from a working- class point of view. The website features stories from the labor movement; from associations of every trade and profession; from the struggles of communities of color and diverse nationalities against racial injustice and inequality; and the movements of women, youth, seniors, the disabled, and of gay, lesbian, bi-sexual and transgender communities for equality. They seem to be affiliated with the Communist Party USA. The website contains sections on features, culture, editor’s blog, education, and news analysis.

did.unittitle: Political Economy Research Institute Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Established in 1998, the Political Economy Research Institute (PERI) at University of Massachusetts Amherst promotes human and ecological well-being through original research. PERI publishes research and policy initiatives on issues of globalization, unemployment, financial market instability, central bank policy, living wages and decent work, and the economics of peace, development, and the environment. The website has information on their research areas, news, and publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Political Research Associates is a progressive think tank devoted to supporting movements that are building a more just and inclusive democratic society. They expose movements, institutions, and ideologies that undermine human rights through their quarterly, Public Eye, and special reports. They also seek to advance progressive thinking and action by providing research-based information, analysis, and referrals. The website features the quarterly, activist resource kits, news, and other multimedia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Formerly october2011.org, Popular Resistance was related to the occupy movement in Washington DC in Freedom Plaza. As of this writing (November 2013), Popular Resistance operates as a clearinghouse of news from the left movement of the 2010s. The website publishes news and resources related to campaigns involving direct action, nonviolent resistance, and civil disobedience, including, but not limited to Occupy Wall Street related campaigns. The organization believes that the United States government puts corporate greed before the needs of people and the environment. The website contains events and action listings, news, their core issues, their newsletter, and their weekly TV show, Resistance Report.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Practical Anarchy, founded in 1991, magazine is a quarterly publication that is published by the Alternative Media Project. The website contains articles and back issues.

did.unittitle: Pratt Area Community Council Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Pratt Area Community Council (PACC), formed in 1964, is a community organization in central Brooklyn. PACC works to preserve and develop safe and affordable housing as a basic human right; to support local commerce through which small businesses serve the market needs of community residents; to sustain and develop an economic, racial, and cultural diversity; and to inform and organize members of the community. The website contains news, event listings, program listings, and a blog.

did.unittitle: Prison Activist Resource Center Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prison Activist Resource Center (PARC) is a prison abolitionist group that works to expose institutionalized racism, sexism, able-ism, heterosexism, and classism within the Prison Industrial Complex (PIC). PARC works to build strategies to build safety in communities without reliance on law enforcement and PIC. PARC also works to expose prisoner neglect and/or torture of people imprisoned in the United States, support a moratorium on prison construction, and build awareness of prison issues outside of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prisoner Solidarity operates as a communication tool between prisoners and people on the outside. It publishes updated research, news, opinion pieces and educational material from activists, writers, prisoners, and the concerned public. The website contains a newsletter, news updates, and a page on the 1993 Lucasville Uprising.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prison Radio is a radio and activist project that produces the commentaries of several prisoners, including Mumia Abu-Jamal. The project's political aims include analyzing the prison-industrial complex and attempting to present a more humanistic view of prisoners to the public. The website contains a multimedia page, a news page, and a blog.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: PrivacySOS.org, a project of the American Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts, works to combat the rise of surveillance technology after the attacks on September 11, 2001 and provide information on actions to take to protect individual privacy. The website contains a blog, their "Surveillance in the Age of Total Information Awareness" report, resources to protect privacy, and information on the different types of surveillance used by the United States government.

did.unittitle: Private Manning Support Network Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Private Manning Support Network is an organization dedicated to freeing Private Chelsea (formerly Bradley) Manning from serving a 35 year prison sentence for providing classified information to WikiLeaks. In August 2013, the organization changed its name when Manning announced she would like to begin to be known publicly by the name of Chelsea Elizabeth Manning, pursue hormone therapy, and be referred to with female pronouns. The organization raises funds for Manning, posts news about Manning and on other cases related to government surveillance and whistle-blowing, as well as a campaign to pardon Manning. The website also contains a significant amount of information on the trial that took place in 2013.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Progressive Caucus of the California Democratic Party

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Progressive Caucus of the California Democratic Party works to reform the Democratic Party and promote social justice. The website contains information on regions, multimedia, events, foreign policy, legislative policy, a calendar, and a blog.

dao.ns2:title: Progressive Caucus of the California Democratic Party

daodesc.p: Progressive Caucus of the California Democratic Party

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Progressive Congress was founded in 1992 by the Congressional Progressive Caucus (CPC) and leaders in the progressive movement. The Progressive Congress focuses its efforts around four key policy areas, peace and global security, energy independence and environmental sustainability; civil rights, civil liberties, and human rights; and public health, education and economic opportunity. Progressive Map is the Wiki page of Progressive Congress.

did.unittitle: Progressive Democrats of America Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Progressive Democrats of America (PDA), founded in 2004, is a progressive political organization and grassroots political action committee (PAC) operating inside the United States Democratic Party. PDA action priorities have included an end to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, Medicare for all, voters rights, healthcare reform, and economic and environmental justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Progressive Jewish Alliance (PJA) was founded in 1999 by Jewish (Los) Angelenos seeking to assert a progressive Jewish presence in the campaigns for economic and social justice in Southern California, including campaigning for improved working conditions for low wage workers, to reform the criminal justice system, and to promote tolerance by facilitating Muslim-Jewish dialogue. PJA merged with the Jewish Funds for Justice in 2011. For newer crawls, please see Progressive Jewish Alliance (PJA) and Jewish Funds for Justice captures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Progressive Labor Party (PLP), established in 1962, is a militant communist faction that works to eliminate capitalism and institute communism through a revolutionary movement and a mass Red Army. PLP organizes workers, students and soldiers to turn capitalism driven wars into a revolution for communism. The website contains issues of its newspaper, Challenge, multimedia, news postings and analysis, a history of the party, and a blog.

did.unittitle: ProgressiveMap: A Project of ProgrssiveCongress.org Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Created by ProgressiveCongress.org, theProgressiveMap.com is a wiki for collaboration within and outside of Congress in the progressive movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Progressive Portal, founded in 2001, is an independent grassroots organization that works on a range of progressive issues and promotes increased activism through letter writing and other simple online activism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Progressive Radio Network (PRN) is an independent, listener supported station that focuses on distributing content on topics such as health, news, politics, art, culture, women’s issues, and other issues. Some broadcasters on PRN include Gary Null, Jim Garrison, Michio Kaku, Jim Hightower, Greg Palast, Caryn Hartglass, Mitch Rabin, Michael Toms, Danny Schacter, Richard Martin, James Turner as well as the weekly radio programs of The Nation Magazine (Radio Nation with Laura Flanders), Global Research News Hour, The Wisdom Forum, Free Speech Radio News and many more.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Project Censored, founded in 1976 by Carl Jensen, is an investigative journalism and media criticism project. The website works to publish news left unpublished by the mainstream media and raise awareness of censorship of news and media accountability. Project Censored highlights independent news sources and has a weekly radio show. The website contains news, investigative research and reporting, an events page, and a blog, called the Censored Notebook.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Project South is a Southern-based leadership development organization that uses popular education, partnership and alliances, and organizing to build political, educational, and economic power at the grassroots of low-income communities. The website contains information on their current projects and programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: ProLibertad Freedom Campaign was a support website for the Puerto Rican nationalists who were imprisoned in the United States for sedition in the early 1980s and Puerto Rican political prisoners in general. The organization worked to release the prisoners, eleven of which were offered clemency in 1999 by President Bill Clinton. As of 2013, one prisoner, Oscar López Rivera, remains in prisoner. The website was defunct by late 2011, at that point two other prisoners, Avelino Gonzalez Claudio, and Norberto Gonzalez Claudio, also remained in prison. It contains writings by the prisoners, a radio show, newsletters, video, and a history of the organization and cases.

daodesc.p: ProLibertad Freedom Campaign Archived Website, Sep 28, 2007-Oct 14, 2011

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Prometheus Radio Project founded in 1998, builds, supports, and advocates community radio stations and works to empower community voices and movements for social change. Prometheus Radio Project supports community groups at every stage of the process, including the technology of building community radio stations, facilitate public participation in the FCC regulatory process, and sponsor events promoting awareness and support of media democracy and LPFM (low-power FM) radio.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Center for Media and Democracy (Madison, Wis.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: PR Watch is the Center for Media and Democracy’s online magazine. Established in 1993 by John Stauber, CMD’s mission is to promote transparency and an informed debate by exposing corporate spin and government propaganda and by engaging the public in collaborative, fair and accurate reporting and analysis. CMD has been publishing PRWatch since 1994 and transitioned from print subscription to online publication in 2008. They also sponsor "open content" media to enable citizens to participate in creating media content.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Public Citizen, founded in 1971, is a political advocacy group that works to represent all citizens in Washington D.C. in U.S. Congress, the executive branch, and the courts. Public Citizen has worked to challenge the practices the pharmaceutical, nuclear and automobile industries, and mega-corporations. Public Citizen is a nonprofit organization that does not participate in partisan political activities or endorse any candidates for elected office. Public Citizen initiatives include Congress Watch, the Energy Program, Global Trade Watch division, the Health Research Group and the Litigation Group

did.unittitle: Puerto Rico - Solidarity Network / Red Solidaria PR-SN Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Puerto Rico Solidarity Network is an organization that works to inform and build support for the Puerto Rico working class labor, community, environment, and student grassroots struggles and also work to promote and develop connections in New York and across the United States.

origination.corpname: Queer/LGBTIQA2Z Caucus at Occupy Wall Street

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Queer/LGBTIQA2Z Caucus is a caucus within the Occupy Wall Street Movement that works to empower people of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer, asexual, two-spirited, and gender neutral orientation and their allies. The group provides a forum to discuss queer issues and educate people of queer culture and concepts. The website contains event listings and news on the group.
