scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: QuestionCopyright.org, founded in 2007, that works to expand the range of acceptable public debate about copyright and reframe the way artists and other look at copyright. The website supports programs that highlight the restrictive effects of distribution monopolies, and help creators and their allies realize the potential of freedom-based distribution and do not equate copying with theft, with plagiarism, or the abuse or destruction of the original work. The website promotes actions through video, art project, and other campaigns.

did.unittitle: R.A. Forum > Research on Anarchism Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: R.A. Forum / Research on Anarchism (English language site) principally consists of articles, mainly scholarly, on all aspects of anarchism, including its worldwide history, with an interdisciplinary perspective. It also contains news, audio (talks and music), and films/DVDs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Radical Art Caucus’ (RAC) primary mission is the promotion of art and art historical scholarship that addresses problems of oppression and possibilities for resistance. RAC seeks to provide an intellectual and professional environment for the discussion of labor and social justice issues specifically related to contemporary practices of art and art history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Mid-Atlantic Radical Historians Organization (MARHO) was formed during a conference at Fordham University in January 1973, attended mostly by professors at colleges and universities in the metropolitan New York area. he journal seeks to "address issues of gender, race, sexuality, imperialism, and class" and stretch "the boundaries of historical analysis to explore Western and non-Western histories." In addition to articles on the theme of any given issue, the journal is often comprised of sections dedicated to teaching and public history, as well as reviews of television, books, museum exhibitions, and other media. The website contains call for proposals for future issues, descriptions of recent issues, subject guides, and back issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Radical Homosexual Agenda is a contingent of New York City LGBTQ community that work to gain rights beyond marriage. RHA works for affordable housing and healthcare, an end to war and the prison industrial complex. The website contains action alerts and has been inactive since 2009.

controlaccess.subject: Gay rights |z New York (State) |z New York.
Sexual minorities |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1982, the Radical Philosophy Association is an international organization whose members struggle against capitalism, racism, sexism, homophobia, disability discrimination, environmental ruin, and all other forms of domination, drawing upon a variety of radical traditions including phenomenology, Marxism, anarchism, post-structuralism, post-colonial theory and environmentalism. Its efforts center on conferences and publications. The RPA also publishes the journal Radical Philosophy Review.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Radical Reference, launched in 2004, is a collective of library workers that support activist communities, progressive organizations, and independent journalists by providing professional research support, education, and access to information. The website provides reference to activists and independent journalists related to their activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Radical Women (RW) is a socialist feminist, grassroots activist organization that provides a radical voice within the feminist movement and trains women to be leaders in the movements for social and economic justice. The organization promotes union action and international solidarity, combats racism in the women's movement and views capitalism as part of the reason why women are oppressed. Radical Women was founded in 1967 by Gloria Martin. It is affiliated with the Freedom Socialist Party (FSP). The website contains event notices and activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Radios Populares (RaPo), founded in 2002, is a Chicago-based collective that collaborates with communities working for social justice to build low-power FM community radio stations. Their work is grounded in a solidarity model which builds alliances between Radios Populares, media activists, and community organizations of the social justice movement. The radio collective also works for media justice and community control over media content.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reaching Critical Will, created in 1999, is a project of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (WILPF) that works for complete disarmament, the abolition of nuclear weapons, the reduction of global military spending, and demilitarization of politics and society. Reaching Critical Will was designed to increase the quality and quantity of NGO preparation and participation in UN disarmament processes and of NGO interaction with governments and the United Nations; to provide logistical support in facilitating activities during relevant conferences tailored for policy-makers and the public; and to provide accurate and timely reporting on all relevant conferences and initiatives so that those unable to attend can stay informed. The website contains information on conferences and assemblies, the non-proliferation treaty, publications, news, action alerts, and contacts.

did.unittitle: Real Cost of Prisons Project Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: The Real Cost of Prisons Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Real Cost of Prisons, started in 2000, seeks to broaden and deepen the organizing capacity of prison/justice activists working to end mass incarceration. The Real Cost of Prisons Project brings together justice activists, artists, justice policy researchers and people directly experiencing the impact of mass incarceration to create popular education materials and other resources which explore the immediate and long-term costs of incarceration on the individual, community, and the nation level. The website contains a blog, pages on different types of media, including comic books, videos, music, and other writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rebuild the Dream uses current technology and media to mobilize, organize, and broaden the base of people working to fix America’s economy and "defend the American Dream." The website contains a list of proposed economic solutions, a video page and teach-in materials.

did.unittitle: Redstockings: Women's Liberation Studies Archives for Action Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Redstockings was a name taken in 1969 by one of the founding women's liberation groups of the 1960's to represent the union of two traditions: the "bluestocking" label disparagingly pinned on feminists of earlier centuries--and "red" for revolution. Redstockings today is a grassroots, activist "think tank", for defending and advancing the women's liberation agenda. The Archives for Action is a project Redstockings established in 1989 to make the experiences of the 1960’s movement more widely available for new understandings and improved strategies. The movement also supports a national health care system and equal job benefits for women.

dao.ns2:title: Redstockings: Women's Liberation Studies Archives for Action

daodesc.p: Redstockings: Women's Liberation Studies Archives for Action

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Red Wedge Magazine, which published its first issue in August 2012, is an arts and cultural publication written and edited by revolutionary Marxist activists, artists and cultural workers. The magazine focuses on art from the socialist perspective, and includes writings on topics such as solidarity, internationalism, feminism, sexual liberation, anti-racism, and workers’ self-emancipation. The magazine explores the connection of art and culture to economic and political issues. They publish articles on theoretical and historical currents of art, reviews, commentary, and audio-visual materials. The website contains issues of the magazine, articles, and other media.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Refuse & Resist! was a human rights activist group founded in New York City in 1987. They opposed censorship, war, acts of police brutality, advocated against the death penalty and other acts of violence. They supported political prisoners, undocumented immigrants, the poor, and reproductive rights. Refuse & Resist! worked through nonviolent resistance, including speaking out in schools, communities and in the media; organizing forums and meetings; demonstrating in the streets; creating and performing cultural works; and contributing financially. The organization officially dissolved in 2006 and the website ceased updating in 2008. The website contains news listings, their CounterAttack magazine, and their artists network.

did.unittitle: Religion and Socialism Commission Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Religion and Socialism, first published in 1977, is the biannual publication of the Religious Socialists. The Religious Socialists are part of the Democratic Socialists of America (DSA) and the organization is open to DSA members of all faiths whose socialism is in some way inspired by their spiritual identity. The website contains issues of their publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprieve is a London based organization that uses the law to enforce the human rights of prisoners, from death row to Guantánamo Bay, and provides legal support to prisoners unable to pay for it themselves.Reprieve prioritises the cases of prisoners accused of the most extreme crimes, such as acts of murder or terrorism, as it is in such cases that human rights are most likely to be jettisoned or eroded. Reprieve focuses on cases involving the world’s most powerful governments, especially those that should be upholding the highest standards when it comes to fair trials. Reprieve has 25 full-time staff in London, five Fellows in the USA, two Fellows in Pakistan and countless volunteers around the world.

scopecontent.p: Restore the Fourth, founded on July 4th, 2013, is an organization that aims to end all forms of unconstitutional surveillance of digital communications by the United States government, specifically they seek to discontinue the mass electronic data mining program, PRISM, ran by the National Security Agency. The website contains a blog, event listings, and information on local chapters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rethinking Marxism, launched in 1988, is a peer-reviewed journal produced by the Association for Economic and Social Analysis and published by Routledge/Taylor & Francis. The Association for Economic and Social Analysis was created in the late 1970s a non-profit educational organization that fosters the discussion of Marxist theory. Issues contains full-length scholarly articles, art (including photoessays and fiction), Remarx essays (short, current pieces that intervene in political and theoretical debates), reviews (of books, films, conferences, exhibits, demonstrations, and more), and correspondence. The publication focuses on Marxian economic, cultural, and social analysis. The website contains back issues, information on previous and upcoming conferences, and other multimedia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: REV-, founded in 2000, is an organization that produces campaigns for social justice, youth media arts, research and development, and activities that promote socioeconomic change and cultural equity. In 2012, they merged with People’s Production House. The website contains news and a complete listing of their projects.

The website contains issues of their newspaper, Revolution, the Revolutionary Communist Party’s platform, works and a biography of Avakian, and other publications and reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

The website contains information on book readings, events, an online book store, and additional information on the Revolutionary Communist Party and Bob Avakian.

Rising Tide advocates for the end of extraction of fossil fuels and the prevention of construction of new fossil fuel infrastructure. They work through grassroots community organizing, publishing educational materials, organizing direct actions and protests, and holding public education events. The website contains news, press releases, publications, and their annual conference.

RSF also conducts research, holds conferences, and engages in other activities intended to increase both scholarly and public awareness of the ideas contained in Henry George’s works. The website contains information about funding, Henry George, and their online library.

Rolling Stone was founded in San Francisco in 1967 by Jann Wenner (who is still editor and publisher) and music critic Ralph J. Gleason. This is the politics section of the website.

scopecontent.p: The Roosevelt Campus Network, founded by Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute in 2004, is a student policy organization that engages students in progressive activism and promotes their ideas for change. The Campus Network has over 10,000 members organized through more than 85 chapters across the country. Chapters foster debate and dialogue on campus, teach policy courses, engage with local policymakers, generate policy, and promote student ideas through conferences and publications. The website contains information on grant funding, news and events related to grantees, and information on the Rosenberg case.

The organization uses the arts as a rehabilitative and therapeutic tool for men and women in prison. The website contains information on the Prison Art Gallery, their art consignment program, and their annual Kennedy Center show.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Sanctuary for Independent Media, established by the Media Alliance in 1977, is a telecommunications production facility dedicated to community media arts, located in Troy, NY. The mission of Media Alliance is to address common needs of nonprofit organizations providing electronic media programs and services to artists, organizations and the general public in areas including, but not limited to, production, distribution, exhibition, research, preservation, appreciation, and to further development of this field. The Sanctuary hosts screening, production and performance facilities, training in media production and a meeting space for artists, activists and independent media makers. The Sanctuary is also host to an online video channel, called Sanctuary TV.

Save the Internet works to protect internet freedom, fight for net neutrality, to connect everyone to high-speed internet, to open the public airwaves, and to secure mobile freedom. The website contains a blog, a videos page, and action page. They oppose the Stop Internet Piracy Act and the Protect Intellectual Property Act, two pieces of proposed Congressional legislation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The School of the Americas Watch (SOA Watch) is an independent organization that seeks to close the US Army School of the Americas and stands in solidarity with the people of Latin America and the Caribbean, to close the SOA/Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation (WHINSEC) and to change oppressive U.S. foreign policy that the SOA represents. SOA Watch works through vigils and fasts, demonstrations and nonviolent protest, as well as media and legislative work. SOA Watch was founded by Maryknoll Father Roy Bourgeois and a small group of supporters in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Science and Society is a peer-reviewed interdisciplinary journal of Marxist scholarship, published quarterly since 1936. . It publishes original studies in political economy and the economic analysis of contemporary societies: social and political theory; philosophy and methodology of the natural and social sciences; history, labor, ethnic and women's studies; aesthetics, literature and the arts. The website contains the current and back editorials, current and back contents, information on the submission process and editorial board, book reviews, and a history of the publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: See Sharp Press, founded in 1984, is a radical and anarchist small press. They have published over 40 books and nearly 50 pamphlets on music, anarchism, atheism, psychology, and modern (non-12-step) alcohol/drug abuse, and self-help. The website features book and pamphlet listings, reviews, and submissions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Sentencing Project was founded in 1986 to provide defense lawyers with sentencing advocacy training and to reduce the reliance on incarceration. The organization works for an effective criminal justice system by promoting reforms in sentencing law and practice, and alternatives to incarceration. It also raises awareness of inequities in the criminal justice system through the publication of research, media campaigns and strategic advocacy for policy reform. The website contains statistics and information on incarceration, racial disparity, drug policy, juvenile justice, voting rights, and collateral consequences. The website also features news and advocacy campaigns.

scopecontent.p: Since 2006, Fellows with the Center for Policy and Research have been analyzing government data to illuminate the interrogations and intelligence practices of the United States. The findings have been quite revealing, showing that what’s found in the data is often the best divulger of the truth. The reports have been introduced into the Congressional record by the Senate Armed Services Committee, the Senate Judiciary Committee, the House Armed Services Committee, and as part of a Resolution by the European Parliament.

SWOP-NYC projects include working on advocacy and policy campaigns, providing direct support to SWANK, event organizing, and other initiatives. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Sex Workers Project (SWP) provides legal services and training, and engages in documentation and policy advocacy for sex workers. Using a harm reduction and human rights model, the organization protects the rights and safety of sex workers who by choice, circumstance, or coercion remain in the industry. SWP provides information to policymakers, activists, and the media on the human rights abuses faced by sex workers and those who are at risk for engaging in sex work and use documentation-based advocacy, policy analysis, training and education, and collaboration with community-based service providers to advance practical, long-term solutions to the problems faced by sex workers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Shalom Tenants Alliance is a coalition of residents of New York City apartment buildings owned and/or managed by the (Oheb) Shalom family. The website operates as a way to share information on anti-tenant practices, to fight for tenant rights, and to document specific incidents of harassment and illegal activities practiced by the Shalom family and to preserve tenant rights for residents in their buildings. The website contains a building listing, event listings, resources, and action alerts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Showdown in America is a campaign of the National People’s Action that works to fix the financial system in the United States. Their main solutions to fix the crisis include repairing the foreclosure crisis, investing in communities to create jobs, stopping bankrupting taxpayers, ending discriminatory lending practices, and providing workplace protection. The website contains news, action alerts, research, and investigative stories.

scopecontent.p: Shut Down Indian Point Now is a resource and rally site which calls to shut down the Indian Point nuclear power plant, which is in Buchanan, NY in the Hudson River Valley. The website contains action alerts, events, news, resource information, and other renewable energy options.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: SignOn.org is a petition service provided by MoveOn.org Civic Action. The website allows anyone to create a petition and use access to tech tools that let the user stay in touch and organize with petition's signers. The website features the most active petitions. In 2013, the name was changed to MoveOn Petitions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sista II Sista, founded in 1996, is a Brooklyn-wide community organization and collective of women of color based in Bushwick. Sista II Sista works to empower women of color and fight against injustice. The organization runs workshops and other programs to create community organizers. The website has been inactive since 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

The Sister Fund provides grants, technical support, communication tools and interfaith dialogue and networking opportunities in the form of public programs and events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: SisterSong Women of Color Reproductive Justice Collective, formed in 1997, is a network of local, regional and national grassroots agencies representing five primary ethnic populations/indigenous nations in the United States (African American, Arab American/Middle Eastern, Asian/Pacific Islander, Hispanic, and Native American/Indigenous) to educate women of color and policy makers on reproductive and sexual health and rights, and to work towards the access of health services, information and resources that are culturally and linguistically appropriate.

The journal publishes articles and essays on critical examinations of social movements and critical assessments of radical political thought. The journal also publishes poems, news critique, book reviews, leftist travelogues, and other works. The website contains access to the current copy and their archives.

scopecontent.p: Founded in 2002, smartMeme offers tools, training, and strategy support to organizations and movements working for social and ecological justice and social change. The smartMeme Strategy and Training Project is a nonprofit collective that works to apply meme theory and a narrative analysis of power to strengthen social change efforts. The website contains a blog, training materials, and information on projects. The organization became Center for Story-based Strategy (CSS) in 2013.

As both political philosophy and personal lifestyle, social anarchism promotes community self-reliance, direct participation in decision-making, respect for nature, and nonviolent paths to peace and justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Social Democrats USA (SDUSA) is a direct descendent of the Socialist Party USA., founded in 1972. The website archived is the website for the re-foundation of the party following the death of Penn Kemble in 2005. The organization was officially re-formed at a conference in 2009. Their aim was to form a center-left party that could win local elections. The website ceased to update in 2011.

did.unittitle: Socialism and Democracy Online Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Socialism and Democracy Online is the journal of the Research Group on Socialism and Democracy. Socialism and Democracy publishes scholarly articles on socialist politics and vision. The perspective is broadly Marxist, encouraging not only critique of the status quo, but also informed analysis of the different approaches to bringing about fundamental change, and seeking to integrate issues of race, gender, sexuality, ethnicity and nationality with the traditional focus on class. Articles reflect many disciplines and their authors include activists, independent scholars, and poets, as well as academics. The website contains featured articles, articles from the current issue, back issues, and links.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Socialist Action is a national group of activists committed to the emancipation of workers and the oppressed. They work to revitalize the anti-war, labor, anti-racist, feminist, student and other social movements and bring activists together from different backgrounds into a revolutionary workers’ party. Their ultimate goal is a truly democratic society. The website contains a detailed platform, news, pamphlets, and Marxist educational resources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Socialist Alternative, founded in 1981, is a national organization that campaigns against United States two party system and advocates for a socialist alternative. They campaign for a mass workers party to represent the interests of workers, youth, and the environment. They advocate for a living wage for all; money for jobs and education, not war; environmental sustainability; equal rights for all; and socialism. Socialist Alternative is in political solidarity with the Committee for a Workers' International. The website publishes a newspaper, Socialist Alternative, and news on healthcare, US and world politics, the environment, and the workers movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Socialist International, established in 1951 by the Frankfurt Congress, is the worldwide organization of social democratic, socialist and labour parties. It currently brings together 162 political parties and organizations from all continents. The website contains their constitution, committees, commission, congresses, and library. The homepage contains news updates on the organization.

did.unittitle: Socialist Labor Party of America Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Socialist Labor Party (SLP) is the original party of socialism in America. Organized as the Workingmen's Party in 1876, the Party was renamed in 1877.Its longtime leader was Daniel De Leon (1852-1914), Marxist author and editor of The People, the SLP newspaper. As the only nationally organized party of socialism in America until 1900, the SLP attracted Socialists of all tendencies to its ranks. However, the Marxist element became dominant by 1890, when the Party was reorganized on a Marxist basis. The SLP has played a prominent role in the economic and political life of the United States. It ran the first socialist presidential campaign in 1892, and fielded national tickets in every presidential campaign through 1976. The SLP's goal is a classless society based on collective ownership and control of the industries and social services, these to be administered in the interests of all society through a Socialist Industrial Union government composed of democratically elected representatives from all the industries and services of the land. Production would be carried on for use instead of profit. The SLP program for achieving this revolutionary change from capitalism to socialism is based on the Marxist tenet that socialism can be achieved only through the classconscious action "of the working class itself." The Socialist Industrial Union program, as the SLP program is known, developed by Daniel De Leon (1852-1914), is a continuation of Karl Marx's ideas on a workers' government. In all essentials--political and economic classwide organization, the breakup of the state, workers' democracy, the seizure of social power by the organized producers and their socialist reorganization of the economy--the SIU program of the SLP conforms to the democratic premises underlying Marx's concept of socialism.

It contains information about their political campaigns and status as a legal national political party under the Federal Election Commission. The organization allocates money from its election fund to support their candidates for public office. The organization’s coordinator also acts as a campaign advisor. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Socialist Party USA, established 1973, is a descendant of the Socialist Party (U.S.), founded in 1901, and strives to establish a radical democracy that places people's lives under their own control and advocates for a non-racist, classless, feminist socialist society. The Socialist Party fights for progressive changes compatible with a socialist future. They support militant working class struggles and electoral action, independent of the capitalist controlled two-party system, to present socialist alternatives. The website contains more information on their platform, their party publication, The Socialist, event listings, organizing assistance, and electoral action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Socialist Register is an annual journal, founded by Ralph Miliband and John Saville in 1964 as ‘an annual survey of movements and ideas’ from the standpoint of the independent new left. Each volume is focused on a topical theme and analyses which cut across intellectual disciplines and geographical boundaries. The website contains the current issue, an archive of older issues, and an announcements page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Socialist Viewpoint Publishing Association publishes Socialist Viewpoint in the interests of the working class. The editors take positions consistent with revolutionary Marxism. Socialist Viewpoint magazine has been edited and distributed by a group of revolutionaries who share a common political outlook stemming from the old Socialist Workers Party of James P. Cannon, and Socialist Action from 1984 through 1999.

did.unittitle: Society for the Study of Social Problems Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Society for the Study of Social Problems

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The SSSP's stated purpose is to promote and protect sociological research and teaching on significant problems of social life and, particularly, to encourage the work of young sociologists; to stimulate the application of scientific method and theory to the study of vital social problems; to encourage problem-centered social research; to foster cooperative relations among persons and organizations engaged in the application of scientific sociological findings to the formulation of social policies; to foster higher quality of life, social welfare, and positive social relations in society and the global community and to undertake any activity related thereto or necessary or desirable for the accomplishment of the foregoing purposes. The SSSP has twenty-two special problems divisions, each with its own newsletter, that provide members with common interests the opportunity to interact more intimately with one another. The SSSP promotes dialogue through presentations at the annual meeting, and through listservs and newsletters throughout the year; publishes research in the journal Social Problems; presents awards to community groups; supports graduate students, young scholars and activists with professional support, leadership opportunities, and scholarships; passes and acts upon public resolutions; and fosters the generation of new ideas. Since many of the Society's members are sociologists, the SSSP holds annual meetings in the same location and time as the American Sociological Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Soh Daiko, founded in New York City in 1979, was the first group in the Northeastern United States. Taiko, a kind of traditional Japanese drumming used for ritual celebrations and festivals also became a contemporary performing art of mass drumming in the 1960s. Soh Daiko’s performances blend movement and choreography with music; its repertoire includes traditional compositions from Shinto music tradition, adapting existing taiko compositions and performing original arrangements by its own members. The group has participated in local New York City cultural festivities, it has performed across the United States, Canada, and the United Kingdom, and has been featured in segments on public radio and television. The website contains event listings, videos of their performances, images, and information about recruitment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: SolidarityEconomy.net is an online 'think tank without walls' dedicated to critical debate and analysis for the mass movements of today. We are part of a global network of activists, organizers and intellectuals who believe that solving our most pressing political, economic, social and environmental problems requires a revolutionary transformation on a global scale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Solidarity, founded in 1986, is an independent socialist organization dedicated to forming a broad regrouping of the U.S. left and publishes the periodical Against the Current. They oppose capitalism, advocate for reproductive rights, other feminist demands and an ecologically balanced society, support the struggles of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender activists, fight against US imperialism, and socialism. The website contains their platform, their webzine, and publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Center for Media and Democracy publishes SourceWatch, a collaborative resource for citizens and journalists looking for documented information about the efforts of corporations and the wealthy to sway public opinion, in order to promote transparency and an informed debate. SourceWatch focuses on the for-profit corporations, non-profit corporate front groups, PR teams, and others who try to influence public opinion on behalf of global corporations and the government agencies they have captured.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Southern California Library, located in Los Angeles, is a people's library dedicated to documenting and preserving the histories of communities in struggle for justice and using the Library’s collections to address the challenges of the present so that all people have the ability, resources, and freedom to make their own histories. The Library holds collections that span the breadth of social and political movements in Los Angeles--from labor, civil rights, education, and housing, to immigration, war and peace, and civil liberties. These collections include over 400 manuscript collections, as well as books, periodicals, subject files, pamphlets, posters, photographs, films, audiotapes, and more

SFC chapters exist at over 40 colleges and universities around the world. Students for Free Culture was founded by two Swarthmore students after they sued voting-machine manufacturer Diebold for abusing copyright law in 2003. did.unittitle: Tamiment Library & Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University. Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives at New York University form a unique, internationally-known center for scholarly research on Labor and the Left. The primary focus is the complex relationship between trade unionism and progressive politics and how this evolved over time. Archival, print, photograph, film, and oral history collections describe the history of the labor movement and how it related to the broader struggle for economic, social, and political change. In 1977 the Robert F. Wagner Archives was established as a joint program of the New York City Central Labor Council and the Tamiment Library. The Wagner is the designated repository for the records of the Council's more than 200 member unions. Today the Library has an extraordinary research collection documenting the history of organized labor in New York and the workers who built the City. Tamiment has one of the finest research collections in the country documenting the history of radical politics: socialism, communism, anarchism, utopian experiments, the cultural left, the New Left, and the struggle for civil rights and civil liberties. It is the repository for the Archives of Irish America, the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives, and a growing Asian American labor collection.

We are creating a design studio for the progressive arm of the nonprofit sector in order to support the sector’s ability to create new forms of effective social intervention and the exploration of new ways to be interventionists. We believe that creating a space for design and intentionally supporting the development of a sector-specific design practice is imperative in order for the sector to break out of its box of exhausted forms. scopecontent.p: The Feminist Theory Website provides research materials and information for students, activists, and scholars interested in women's conditions and struggles around the world. The goals of this website are: 1) to encourage a wide range of research into feminist theory, and 2) to encourage dialogue between women (and men) from different countries around the world. Hopefully, this will result in new connections, new ideas, and new information about feminist theory and women's movements. The Feminist Theory Website has three parts: 1) various fields within feminist theory; 2) different national / ethnic feminisms; and 3) individual feminists. All of these parts are updated and expanded regularly. To access these pages, please click on the buttons in the left column.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Groundswell Collective, founded in 2006, is a loose affiliation of artists that work at the intersection of art and activism. The collective is interested in how art relates to social movements and to use of the creativity of the radical left to create an impact in society. The collective uses various different media and the website maintains a blog, catalogs art and runs an online store and barter network.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Huffington Post is a liberal/progressive American news website and content aggregating blog founded by Arianna Huffington.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Icarus Project, founded in 2002, is a support community designed to create a network of people living with and/or affected by experiences diagnosed in the contemporary language as Bipolar, Manic-Depressive, or other psychiatric conditions. The website provides an outlet for people who want to view their conditions as “gifts” as opposed to a disease or disorder. The website contains information on their support network, art shows, articles, and a blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This site contains articles from the Militant newspaper, a socialist newsweekly published in the interests of working people. The Militant is associated with the Socialist Workers Party, a U.S. Trotskyist organization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Multitude is a discussion forum designed to help Occupy Wall Street protesters organize and formally communicate online. The website contains three main areas of interest, planning, movement philosophy, and reform. The website ceased to exist in summer 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Initially founded in 1980, The Nuclear Resister is a news source that reports on nonviolent resistance to war and the nuclear threat. They publish a quarterly newsletter and blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Peace Pentagon is the website for information on the building that houses multiple different peace organizations, including the War Resisters League, Paper Tiger Television, Deep Dish TV, Libertarian Book Club, A.J. Muste Memorial Institute, and Socialist Party. The website also represents the group Friends of 339, which is working to prevent the sale of the building. The building is located at 339 Lafayette Street.

did.unittitle: The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press (RCFP) is an American nonprofit organization, founded in 1970, that provides free legal assistance to and on behalf of journalists. A number of prominent journalists presently sit on the organization's steering committee, including Dan Rather, and Judy Woodruff and, prior to his death, Walter Cronkite. Its offices are located in Arlington, Virginia.The RCFP actively aids in defending reporters facing subpoenas and court orders to disclose the identity of confidential sources. The Reporters Committee is also involved in a variety of First Amendment, shield law, freedom of information, and other free speech activities, including state open records and meetings law compliance. The organization publishes a quarterly magazine, The News Media and The Law. In addition, the Reporters Committee files legal briefs on a variety of issues that affect a journalist's ability to gather and disseminate news and also maintains a 24-hour legal defense hotline for journalists and media lawyers.

scopecontent.p: Situationist International Text Library is part of Nothingness.org, an anarchist and situationist website. The Library is an ongoing project of uploading pieces of Situationist-related literature. Entire books, lengthy articles, excerpts from the journals Potlatch and Internationale Situationniste, newspaper articles, and other files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Socialist magazine and website are published by members of the Socialist Party USA. The website contains information on the Socialist Party's platform, issues of the magazine, and articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Struggle for Free Speech at CUNY, 1931-1942, is a permanent online exhibition at the library of the City College of the City University of New York. This exhibit describes a series of events that took place at the City College of New York (the oldest of all CUNY colleges) during the 1930s and early 1940s that posed challenges to notions of academic freedom and civil liberties.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: University of Missouri--Kansas City. School of Law

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This website is an archive dedicated to the Trials of the Scottsboro Boys, which was a set of trials, convictions, reversals, and retrials of an alleged gang rape of two white girls by nine black teenagers on a Southern Railroad freight run on March 25, 1931. The results of the trial opened southern juries to blacks, exacerbated sectional strife, and divided America's political left.

dao.ns2:title: The Trials of The Scottsboro Boys

daodesc.p: The Trials of The Scottsboro Boys

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Yes Men are a radical culture jamming activist duo and network of supporters created by Andy Bichlbaum and Mike Bonanno. To date, the duo has produced two films: The Yes Men (2003) and The Yes Men Fix the World (2009). In these films, they impersonate and ridicule corporate criminals and others, a practice that they call "identity correction". They create and maintain fake websites similar to ones they intend to spoof. They espouse the belief that corporations and governmental organizations act in dehumanizing ways toward the public.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Center for American Progress Action Fund

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Think Progress is a project of the Center for American Progress Action Fund. The Center for American Progress Action Fund is a nonpartisan organization. Through this blog, CAPAF seeks to provide a forum that advances progressive ideas and policies. The site features blogs by Alyssa Rosenberg and Joe Romm, and has sections titled: economy, green, health, justice, LGBT, Security. ThinkProgress was voted "Best Liberal Blog" in the 2006 Weblog Awards and chosen as an Official Honoree in the 2009 Webby awards. It was also named best blog of 2008 by The Sidney Hillman Foundation, receiving an award for journalism excellence. In 2009, ThinkProgress was named a "Gold Award Winner" by the International Academy of Visual Arts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1997, the Third Wave Foundation is a feminist, activist foundation that works nationally to support young women and transgender youth. Through strategic grant-making, leadership development, and philanthropic advocacy, they support groups and individuals working towards gender, racial, economic, reproductive and social justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This Stops Today came together to respond to the Staten Island grand jury’s failure to indict police officers in the killing of Eric Garner in 2014. The organization called for eleven days of action to reflect the eleven times Eric Garner told police officers "I can't breathe" before he died. This website includes listings of actions in New York City.

daodesc.p: This Stops Today Archived Website, Dec 10, 2014-Ongoing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thousand Kites, founded in 1998 by Appalshop, is a community-based performance, web, video and radio project centered on the United States prison system to engage citizens. It uses media to open communication with incarcerated people, corrections officials, the formerly incarcerated, grassroots activists, and ordinary citizens to organize around United States’ criminal justice system. The website contains a radio station, event listings, news, stories, other campaigns, and other media. In 2013, this site became Nation Inside.

did.unittitle: Tidal: Occupy Theory, Occupy Strategy Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Occupy Theory explores the theoretical implications of the Occupy Wall Street movement and provides an academic assessment of the movement by people within the movement. The website also includes their publication, Tidal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tikkun, founded in 1986, by its longtime editor Michael Lerner and other progressive Jews, creates space for the emergence of a Religious Left to counter the power of the Religious Right. The spiritual progressive ideas of Tikkun are amplified through the consciousness-raising efforts of the Network of Spiritual Progressives (NSP), the interfaith educational and social action organization of the magazine. The website contains articles on religion, politics, the environment, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, book reviews, poetry and fiction, and an art gallery.

did.unittitle: TIME'S UP! NYC Direct Action Environmental Organization Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1987, TIME'S UP! is a New York City based direct-action environmental group that uses events and educational programs to promote a more sustainable, less toxic city. TIME’S UP! works to educate people about the environmental impact of everyday decisions, including transportation use and food purchasing. TIME’S UP! sponsors many ride events to promote cycling and a bike co-op program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tomdispatch was launched in 2001 by Tom Engelhardt launched Tomdispatch as an e-mail publication offering commentary and collected articles from the world press. In December 2002, it became a project of The Nation Institute, and became a blog publishing commentary and working as "an antidote to mainstream media." The site now features Tom Engelhardt's regular commentaries and the original work of authors ranging from Rebecca Solnit, Bill McKibben, and Mike Davis to Chalmers Johnson, Michael Klare, Adam Hochschild, Robert Lipsyte, Elizabeth de la Vega, and Nick Turse. The website works to publish news and stories uncovered by the mainstream media.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: TomPaine.com, founded in 1999 by John Moyer, is an online public affairs journal of progressive analysis and commentary. The website contains an opinions section, headlines, and a link to their parent site, Institute for America’s Future.

did.unittitle: TradeJustice New York Metro (formerly NYC People's Referendum on Free Trade) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: TradeJustice New York Metro (formerly NYC People's Referendum on Free Trade) is a grassroots coalition of groups and individuals in the New York metropolitan are united in opposition to agreements modeled after the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Their goals are to prevent passage of future agreements, repeal agreements that have passed, create a dialogue on alternatives to the NAFTA model, and get popular control over the decision-making process on international trade policy. They aim to achieve these goals through lobbying and accountability campaigns.

did.unittitle: Transnational Temps art collective Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transnational Temps is an art collective focusing on environmental and media issues. The projects also critique corporate dominance. It was founded by Fred Adam, Andy Deck, and Veronica Perales Bianco. The website contains their earth web art projects and proposals, workshops, and papers written by the collective. The website is in English, French, and Spanish.

did.unittitle: Trayvon Martin Organizing Committee Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Trayvon Martin Organizing Committee is an organization that advocates for justice for Trayvon Martin. Martin was fatally shot by George Zimmerman on February 26, 2012. Zimmerman was tried on June 24, 2013, and found not guilty the following day. The organization believes that Martin’s death was a race based murder and Zimmerman was not arrested because of white supremacy and classism inherent in the criminal justice system. The website contains information about rallies in response to the not guilty verdict, as well as reports from the rallies’ aftermath.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The purpose Trotsky.net is to provide an overall view of the ideas and struggles of Leon Trotsky. Trotsky played a leading role, together with Lenin, during the 1917 Russian Revolution. The website primarily consists of a selection of Trotsky's writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Truthout is a full-service news agency dedicated to establishing a voice for independent journalism and provides citizens with reader-supported news instead of advertiser-supported news. Truthout works to spread reliable information, critical thought and progressive ideas. Truthout was started by fashion photographer Marc Ash in direct response to the mainstream media's coverage of the 2000 election. NOTE: this website contains content created by Truthout only, not material compiled from external sources.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Truthdig is a news website that provides coverage of current affairs as well as assembling content from a progressive point of view. The site is built around reports by authorities in their fields who conduct in-depth exploration of contemporary topics. The site also presents a diversity of original reporting and aggregated content culled by the site's editors and staff.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: U.S. PIRG (Public Interest Research Groups), founded in 1970, is a federation of independent, state-based, citizen-funded organizations that advocate for the public interest against special interest groups. The group’s main issues include healthcare reform, corporate tax loopholes, consumer protection, and ending taxpayer subsidies for agribusinesses. They use investigative research, media exposés, grassroots organizing, and advocacy and litigation to make change. State PIRGs are active in 47 states, with a federal lobby office in Washington, D.C.. The website contains a news blog, action alerts, and information on their campaigns and issues.

did.unittitle: Union for Radical Political Economics (URPE) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1968, the Union for Radical Political Economics (URPE) is an interdisciplinary association devoted to the study, development and application of radical political economic analysis to social problems. URPE presents a continuing critique of the capitalist system and all forms of exploitation and oppression while helping to construct a progressive social policy and create socialist alternatives. URPE organizes local study groups, speaking and writing projects, and political events. URPE’s international members in Latin America are involved in discussions, visits, and exchanges. URPE publishes the Review or Radical Political Economics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A directory by state of national and local unions in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Union Square Awards, established in 1998, awards grants to social activists, community organizers, arts organizations, and other activism in New York City. Over $16 million has been distributed to 238 organizations, since the awards founding. The website contains information on past awardees, grants, and award programs.

did.unittitle: United for a Fair Economy Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: United for a Fair Economy, founded in 2010, raises awareness that concentrated wealth and power undermine the economy, corrupt democracy, and deepen the racial divide. They work to solve these issues through projects that include tax reform, closing the wealth divide, and corporate responsibility. The website contains information on their projects, issues, and a blog.

did.unittitle: United for Peace and Justice Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: United for Peace and Justice, founded in 2002, is a coalition of more than 1400 local and national groups that organizes opposition to U.S. military involvement in Iraq and Afghanistan, against nuclear weapons, and for economic and social justice. The website contains action alerts, news listings, event listings, and other resources.

did.unittitle: United Neighborhood Houses of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: United Neighborhood Houses of New York, founded in 1919, is a collective of settlement houses that promotes neighborhood-based, multi-service approach to improving the lives of New Yorkers in need and their communities. The organization provides services for youth, children, immigrants, seniors. One of their main focuses also includes housing stability, which provides community building in public housing and advocates for programs to prevent homelessness. The website contains event listings, news, programming, and advocacy campaigns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: United New York is an economic justice organization that works to create job opportunities for New Yorkers and advocates raising taxes on corporations to pay for city public services. The website contains photographs and videos from events, news listings, and reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Urban Justice Center, founded in 1984, serves New York City vulnerable residents through a combination of direct legal service, systemic advocacy, community education and political organizing. The center has nine main projects, including the Community Development Project, the Domestic Violence Project, the Homelessness Outreach and Prevention Project, the Human Rights Project, the Iraq Refugee Assistance Project, the Mental Health Project, the Peter Cicchino Youth Project, the Police Reform Organizing Project, the Sex Workers Project, and the Street Vendor Project. The website contains a projects page, a media page, a reports page, and an events page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1979, the US Peace Council is a multi-racial, pro-working class, anti-imperialist organization committed to peace, economic and social justice and to international solidarity with the peoples of the world. The group promotes the prohibition of all weapons of mass destruction, the abolition of foreign military bases, universal disarmament under effective international control, and negotiations instead of use of force in the settlement of differences between nations. It is affiliated with the World Peace Council, the world’s largest peace organization and an NGO member of the United Nations. The website contains resources, news, petitions, issues of focus, and information on chapters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The US Social Forum, which first met in 2007 in Atlanta and again in 2010 in Detroit, was a gathering of social justice activists in the United States which grew out of the World Social Forum process, bringing together activists, organizers, people of color, working people, poor people, and indigenous people from across the United States. The goal of the gathering was to build unity around common goals of social justice, to build ties between organizations present at the event, and to help build a broader social justice movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formed in 2011, the USTOGAZA, is a coalition of organizations that plans to launch a boat, called "The Audacity of Hope," during the next Freedom Flotilla to the Gaza Strip to participate in an international effort to break the blockade of Gaza and to end the occupation of Palestine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Utopian Magazine, first published in 2000, is an anarchist publication which looks to reform political parties using utopianism and revolutionary anarchism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: VeganThis was a blog that promotes the vegan lifestyle and promotes awareness of animal cruelty in the dairy and animal industry, of vivisection and animal testing, and of human complicity in animal cruelty by eating animal products. VeganThis also publishes animal rights activism campaign and alerts. At the end of 2011-early 2012, the website became Because We Must, an environmental website now captured in the Green Movements and Environmental web archive.

did.unittitle: Veteran Feminists of America Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Veteran Feminists of America (VFA) is an organization of the second wave of the feminist movement that took place in the 1960s to the 1990s. VFA is a source of information about the Second Wave women's movement for journalists, historians and other writers, honoring the achievements of Second Wave feminists, and bringing together pioneer feminists in a continuing campaign to educate and motivate young people through the example of feminist action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Veterans For Peace is a veterans educational and humanitarian organization dedicated to the abolition of war, founded in 1985. The website contains a newsroom, action alerts, resources, and personal accounts by members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is the New York chapter of the Veterans for Peace Organization.

Veterans--Political activity

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Viewpoint Magazine is an online review of contemporary politics, from a "proletarian viewpoint at the level of theory." The first issue is from October 2011, in response to the Occupy Movement. The website contains the current issue, and a blog.

did.unittitle: Voices for Creative Nonviolence Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Voices for Creative Nonviolence is a nonviolent resistance organization, founded in 2005 in response to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. The organization works to raise awareness of the negative impacts of United States militarism on invaded countries and their populations. The website contains newsletters, event listings, and campaigns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Voters For Peace is a charity for education and research that works to end the occupation of Iraq and prevent future wars. Their mission is to mobilize anti-war voters into a political force and provide voters with the information and tools they need to be effective peace advocates; this includes educating their friends and family on the occupation, writing letters to the media, and holding congressional and presidential candidates accountable. The website contains war news analysis and action alerts.

controlaccess.subject: Iraq War, 2003-2011 |x Protest movements |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This website contains the Freedom Socialist Party launch of the 2012 presidential write-in campaign. The ticket featured New Yorker Stephen Durham for U.S. president and Seattleite Christina López for vice president. They stand for full employment, restoring funds and programs that aid seniors, the poor, children, single mothers and the homeless, simplifying the tax code to raise taxes for the wealthy, equal rights and opportunity for all regardless of race, age, gender, nationality, sexual orientation, immigration status, or physical ability, ending US militarism, wars and occupations, voters’ rights and ballot access, "planetary environmental sanity," and other issues. The website contains news, videos, and information on the candidates.

controlaccess.subject: Internet in political campaigns |z United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Established in 2009, Waging Nonviolence is a newswire website, focusing on news and writing analysis related to struggles for justice and peace internationally. The website is broken up into categories of news including conflict, culture, region, issues, series, columns, and experiments. The website also has a blog.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Women's Action for New Directions Education Fund

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: WAND (Women's Action for New Directions), founded in 1982 as Women's Action for Nuclear Disarmament, is an organization that works to empower women to act politically to reduce violence and militarism and redirect the federal budget away from the military and toward unmet human and environmental needs. The website contains information on upcoming trainings and events, their issues, resources, and WiLL, their lobbying group.

did.unittitle: War Is A Crime Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: War is a Crime (formerly After Downing Street) is a nonpartisan coalition of over 200 veterans groups, peace groups, and political activist groups that has worked since May 2005 to pressure both Congress and the media in order to hold the Bush administration accountable for crimes and abuses of power. The website publishes news related to peace and social justice issues. The website contains information and blog posts by peace activist and radio host David Swanson.

controlaccess.subject: Iraq War, 2003-2011 |x Protest movements |z United States.
War crimes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: War Resisters League, founded in 1923, is a secular pacifist organization that challenges military recruitment, organizes and trains for nonviolent direct action, and offers on-the-ground education. Their projects include the GI Resistance Support Project, the Bite the Bullet: War Profiteering Education and Action Network, the quarterly magazine WIN: Through Revolutionary Nonviolence, advocacy of and support for war tax resistance, demonstrations, and local and regional anti-war organizing projects. The website contains information on chapters, publications, resources, news, and event listings.

did.unittitle: WBAI Radio (New York, NY) Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: WBAI is a New York City based radio station that first went on air as WABF in 1941 and moved to 99.5 FM in 1948. The station took a respite from broadcasting in 1953, and came back on the air as part of World Broadcast Associates, Inc (WBAI) in 1955. In 1960, WBAI joined the Pacifica Foundation. WBAI is a progressive and independent news and talk radio station, which broadcasts Democracy Now! and other programming.

did.unittitle: WE ACT for Environmental Justice Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: WE ACT for Environmental Justice is an environmental organization, founded and incorporated in 1988 to address ongoing West Harlem community struggles around the poor management of the North River Sewage Treatment Plant and the targeting of Northern Manhattan for a sixth MTA bus depot at a site across from an intermediate school and a large housing development. The organization works to inform, educate, train and mobilize the predominately African-American and Latino residents of Northern Manhattan on issues that impact their quality of life: air, water, indoor pollution, toxins, land use and open space, waterfront development and usage, sanitation, transportation, historic preservation, regulatory enforcement, and citizen participation in public policy making. The website contains information on the WE ACT’s current projects, other affiliated organizations, events, and publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: We Are Many is the official website of the documentary being created based on the February 15, 2003 anti-war protest. The website works to collect stories of people who participated that day and create a digital archive of the events.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: United States. Federal Bureau of Investigation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Weather Underground Organization, also known as Weathermen, described itself as a revolutionary organization of communist men and women. The FBI's analysis of its motivations, beliefs, and international travels are outlined in this 420 pp. summary, released under the Freedom of Information Act.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wellstone Action, founded in 2003 and named for the late Paul Wellston (formerly U.S. Senator from Minnesotta) and Sheila Wellstone, is a national center that provides training and leadership development in the progressive movement. The organization works to train underrepresented communities to engage in civic life. Wellstone trains campaign workers, candidates, activists, students, domestic and sexual violence advocates, labor organizers and unions, Native American community leaders, and non-profit leaders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: We the Blog, a blog of the Experimental Party, debated the Experimental Party platform (to form a more Artistic Union; to enhance the Social Condition; to provide for the Avant-Garde, etc.), and provided in depth analysis of inside-the-beltway political machinations (and how it reflects on our relationships with the international community). It also offered discussion among media artists, cultural critics and other creative people who are repositioning themselves as new leaders in the governance of this planet. The site was active from about February 2003 to February 2005.

scopecontent.p: The We the People Campaign, began in 2011, works to end and raise awareness of corporate power in the media and the legislative process through reporting and grassroots actions. The website contains a toolkit to educate activists, a blog, and links to other action projects.

did.unittitle: William Moses Kunstler Fund for Racial Justice Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: William Moses Kunstler Fund for Racial Justice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: William Kunstler (July 7, 1919 – September 4, 1995) was a prominent civil rights and civil liberties lawyer and civil rights activist, among whose notable clients were the Chicago 8, the American Indian Movement, and the prisoners at Attica Prison (New York State). Kunstler was a board member of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) and the co-founder of the Law Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR). The William Moses Kunstler Fund for Racial Justice supports the WMK Racial Justice Fellow at the Center for Constitutional Rights, makes grants, and helps to coordinate and implement projects and initiatives in the interest of racial justice. For the past five years, the Fund has helped organize vigils of families affected by the Rockefeller Drug Laws in New York City and throughout the state and has helped mobilize families and publicize the harsh sentencing and racially biased enforcement of drug legislation throughout the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Win Without War, formed in 2002, works to install a more progressive national security strategy. They have worked to demilitarize U.S. policy in Afghanistan, continue the timely withdrawal of troops from Iraq, and secure America and its values by closing Guantanamo Bay. The website contains a blog, news postings, fact sheets, multimedia, and legislative actions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Without Walls was founded by a collective of Jewish educators, and is currently made up of two branches, a Jewish branch working in supplementary schools, synagogues and day schools, and a branch which works with non-Jewish youth, in the areas of group-building, community activism, and social justice.

did.unittitle: Witness against Torture: A Campaign to Shut down Guantanamo Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At our inception, with the December 5-17, 2005: Walk to Guantanamo to Visit the Prisoners, Witness Against Torture was a group of friends who-- as Americans and Catholics-- walked to Guantanamo to visit the prisoners, to perform a work of mercy, to respond to the victims of the war on terrorism. Once we returned from that journey, we began to organize more broadly to shut down Guantanamo, working with interfaith, human rights and activists' organizations. We have planned a series of nonviolent direct actions to expose and decry the administration's lawlessness, build awareness about torture and indefinite detention amongst Americans and forge human ties with the prisoners at Guantanamo and their families.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Women’s eNews, launched in 2000, is an online news website that covers international and national issues that concern women and their allies. The website writes on a variety of topics including politics, religion, economics, health, science, education, sports, and legislation. The website also contains a monthly column in the media, called Uncovering Gender, and weekly editorial cartoons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Women’s Fightback Network is an independent women’s blog led by a multinational group of women who represent workers and poor people, young and old, lesbian, and transgender and organizes through mass action. The network is anti-war and against sexism, racism, and LGBT oppression. "Stop the U.S. war on women, at home and abroad!" is a main slogan of the Women's Fightback Network.

did.unittitle: Women's International League for Peace and Freedom (WILPF) Archived Website

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Women's International League for Peace and Freedom was founded in 1915 during World War I, with Jane Addams as its first president. WILPF works to achieve through peaceful means world disarmament, full rights for women, racial and economic justice, an end to all forms of violence, and to establish those political, social, and psychological conditions which can assure peace, freedom, and justice for all. WILPF works to create an environment of political, economic, social and psychological freedom for all members of the human community, so that true peace can be enjoyed by all.

WILPF works to achieve through peaceful means world disarmament, full rights for women, racial and economic justice, an end to all forms of violence, and to establish those political, social, and psychological conditions which can assure peace, freedom, and justice for all. WILPF works to create an environment of political, economic, social and psychological freedom for all members of the human community, so that true peace can be enjoyed by all. This is the New York City branch website.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Women’s Media Center, founded in 2005, is a progressive women’s organization that advocates wider coverage of women’s issues in the media. They do this through media advocacy campaigns, media monitoring for sexism, creating original content, and training women and to participate in media. The website contains a blog, a solutions page, and an action page.

did.unittitle: Women Against Military Madness Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Women Against Military Madness (WAMM), found in 1982, is a nonviolent, feminist organization that works to create a system of social equality, self-determination and justice through education, action and the empowerment of women. WAMM’s purpose is to dismantle systems of militarism, economic exploitation, and global oppression. The website contains event listings, action alerts, programming, and their newsletter, Worldwide WAMM.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Women Against War, founded in 2002, is an anti-war activist organization, that also focuses on the cost of the Iraq war to women and children. The website contains information on current projects.

controlaccess.subject: Iraq War, 2003-2011 |x Protest movements |z United States.
Women and peace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Women and Prison: A Site for Resistance, founded in 2004 by Beyondmedia’s Education, publishes stories of women’s experiences in the criminal justice system. The website promotes strategies and actions that challenge the system. The website seeks to create a connection between the issues facing incarcerated women and the issues facing poor women, drug-addicted women, women of color, lesbians, and women in prostitution. The website contains personal stories and news updates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Women Occupy is a feminist organizing group, established by CODEPINK: Women for Peace, affiliated with the Occupy Wall Street Movement. The group works to aggregate and create resources of relevance to women and allies committed to confronting patriarchy, heterosexism, and transphobia. They also provide women with resources for creating safer spaces and feminist organizing for general assemblies. The website contains resources for organizing, a discussion forum, and a news blog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Workers Solidarity Alliance is an anti-capitalist, anti-authoritarian organization of activists who believe that working people can build a new society and a better world based on the principles of solidarity and self-management. WSA also publishes ideas and action, which was created in July, 1981 as an independent anarcho-syndicalist semi-annual print magazine. After Workers Solidarity Alliance was founded in November, 1984, ideas and action became the magazine of WSA (with issue #5), and continuing through the publication of issue #17 in 1997. It now exists as a blog on the WSA website.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Workers World is the newspaper of the Workers World Party, a Marxist-Leninist communist party of Trotskyist orientation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Workers World Party was founded in 1959 as a Marxist-Leninist Party. The party advocates for a mass movement led by workers to promote socialism and end the United States two party system. The website contains international and national news, news on anti-war movement, immigrant rights, the economy, gay rights, the environment, prisoner rights, anti-racism, women’s rights, and other news. The website also contains editorials, books, and their Spanish version of the website, Mundo Obrero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Working Class Vegan is a website that presents an abolitionist approach to animal rights theory which maintains that all sentient beings, humans or nonhumans, have one right: the basic right not to be treated as the property of others, in a clear and consistent manner to the working class, and makes veganism accessible to all, especially low-income households and underprivileged neighborhoods. WCV supports only those campaigns and positions that explicitly promote the abolitionist agenda, and rejects sexism, racism, heterosexism or other forms of discrimination against humans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1998, the Working Families Party (WFP) is New York progressive political party formed from community organizations, neighborhood activists, and labor unions. The party's main issue concerns are jobs, health care, education and energy/environment. The organization cross-endorses candidates who support their platforms. The website lists endorsed candidates, issues, and action alerts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Working Theater, founded in 1985 in New York, produces plays with working class themes, and that are affordable for working class people. This official website contains information about past and current productions. The Working Theater commissions new plays and performs about ten plays a year.

did.unittitle: Workmen's Circle / Arbeter Ring Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Founded in 1900, The Workmen’s Circle / Arbeter Ring fosters Jewish identity and participation in Jewish life through Jewish, especially Yiddish, culture and education, friendship, and the pursuit of social and economic justice. The organization was formed by Jewish immigrants to face challenges of assimilating to the new culture and fighting labor practices, and was rooted in the labor and socialist traditions.
